133207713.review:
Soul Hackers 2 is definitely the most polarizing entry in Atlus' JRPG lineup that I've personally played. There's a lot of good here but also a fair amount of bad. I'm going to get the parts of the game I do not like out of the way first so anyone reading this knows what the sour parts of the game were for me personally and then can weigh it against the later positives in order to make a decision on whether or not to buy it.

- Cons

The dungeon design in this game is abysmal. Dungeon's like these would have been expected back in the early Playstation 1 days but nowadays? No. Dungeons are linear, boring, and repetitive. The biggest offender of it for me is the "Soul Matrix" side dungeon that allows you to unlock skills for members of your party. The rewards for getting through it are worth it, but it's a slog every step of the way. Genuinely would rather go through Tartarus in P3 again instead of dealing with another obnoxious teleporter "puzzle".

The story is painfully short. I beat the entire game in just under 50 hours and that's with me doing every request, getting 91% on the compendium, upgrading my weapons to the max etc. Point is, I did almost everything. I really wish there was a bit more of the main story present in this game as it is the more interesting part of the game. The requests are all basically boiled down to "go here, do one of three things, go back." Very few of the requests are unique and the ones that are do not stand out at all.

Lastly, day 1 DLC. While I didn't buy the game on day 1, the fact that DLC was released for it on its release date that added a decent chunk of story and content is extremely cringe. Atlus please stop cutting content just to resell it as DLC. 

- Pros

The soundtrack for this game goes hard. Really hard. Unsurprising considering most of the music Atlus does goes hard, but it should be stated nonetheless. 

Characters are all well written and fun. While my opinion of some characters at the start was a bit mixed, towards the end of the game I genuinely really liked and cared for all of them. Ringo in particular is by far my favorite protag Atlus has made so far. I really like the snarky personality she was given, she's fun to listen to and I like how she interacts with the other members of the party a lot.

Story while short is good, I just wish there was more of it like I said before. It has some really good twists I wasn't expecting and some pretty good story beats. Genuinely one of the better written stories Atlus has made in recent years.

133125976.review: While this game doesn't have the same quality of plot like other mainline SMT or Persona games, it's still quite enjoyable due to the character interactions, soundtrack and aesthetic. Totally worth picking up during a sale.

132798495.review:
Really enjoyed the game. Had a few issues but overall a good game that does a lot of things better than a lot of other recent Atlus games. 

First off, the graphics. I love the visual style of this game. Its like P5 with its comic book aesthetic, but dialed to 100. The colors pop out very well. All the characters look extremely vibrant. My greatest praise goes to the demons. While using the same models as P5 and SMTV, with the use of colors and textures the demons look better then they ever have been. Going back to P5 after this makes that game look kinda dull. One thing this game does worse than P5 though is the UI design. P5 still clears this game in that sense, but the UI is still miles better than SMTV. 

The music is also very good. Its not as good as the previous atlus game, but there still are a lot of good songs. The jewelery shop theme, all three of the boss themes, and the hideout theme come to mind the most. The reason for lack of songs is probably budget. 

Now for gameplay. I am going to get the negatives out of the way first. The dungeons suck. But, they arent as bad as people say. People went through p3 and p4's dungeons, and never complained, even though they were way worse. And do not tell me those games are old so its okay, all the Atlus games that preceded p3 and p4 had way better dungeons. While the dungeons in this game are bland mazes, they function as a place to do combat, which imo is amazing. 

The combat in this game is amazing. I know people complained about human party members, but this game does them perfectly. Demons in this game function like Personas. You equip them to party members and they give you stat boosts, skills, and elemental affinities. How this is different than the modern Persona games is that finally every party member can change out their demon. In P3 having mc being the only one with more than one persona worked because of the AI party members, in p4 and p5 it sucked. All the party members might as well not be there as there is zero customization to them while the mc just does everything. It is so lame. Instead SH2 works like the older persona games, where you only have four party members who are all extremely customizable. Not only can each member freely use any demon, you can also customize them by increasing their elemental affinities and giving them accessories so each party member feels different. This customization goes into the gameplay as it really does have that SMT feel of making the perfect party to fight the boss, making it very satisfying. Managing your demons by fusing them is as fun as ever, especially since they brought back smtiv's fusion search functions. Ringo's Aion skills also add a lot of strategy. They allow fast swapping out of demons like in Persona, but puts a limit on it so its not OP. Another Aion skill is increasing stacks, which segways into the main battle mechanic. The Sabbath system. In this system when you get a weakness you build a stack. At the end of your turns you summon a demon for each stack and you can do an all out attack for a lot of damage. I really like this system since it becomes a puzzle for getting the most stacks. Later on you will unlock Aion skills and passive upgrades which give more stacks depending on if certain conditions are met. It becomes a puzzle to see how high you can get the stack. 

Now for story, I will keeo it brief to avoid spoilers. I really liked it. Its simple, has good twists, and is very personable to the characters. The characters are all interesting with their motives, and the writing quality is a leaps better than P5's (p5's writing is doo doo so ig its not a high bar). This game avoids p5's writing pitfalls by not having mean spirited humor, making all characters equally shine, and also being more concise. Characters mostly do not repeat the same plot points a million times. I also find the plot point of most people yearning the apocalypse interesting. Is it the best story ever told: no. But imo the plot still clears smtv, and persona 3-5.

Overall I recommend this game. My only issues are the dungeons, and I guess the lack of budget. The side content also has that feeling but it still reinforces the satisfying gameplay loop. Another issue is the dlc, which is disgusting I agree. I still think the base game is good enough though, also p5 had 80 dollars worth of dlc which had even more overly priced costumes and op personas but no one cared for some reason. 

In short, if you like the gameplay side of smt with fun battles, and if you like simple but satisfying stories, you will probablt like this game. Most of the issues are budget issues, and overall I was able to look past them. The hate is overblown for this game, reminds me of the TLOU2 hate, where people were more mad because the game wasnt what they were expecting. If this game interests you, please play it.

132707159.review: I'm not new to SMT games, but I've never played the original Soul Hackers, not have I played any of the Devil Summoner titles. That being said, I went into this pretty much treating it as it's own title, not holding it against any of the other related SMT games. To keep it short and simple, it was a decent game overall. The gameplay is okay, the demon encounters are.. frequent, the available demons and fusions are sufficient enough to make it through the game without major struggle. However, the story and it's pacing are far from perfect. I enjoyed the story, but there  is so much nothingness happening for the first half of the game, and then the story suddenly goes balls to the walls and gets interesting. Unfortunately, many players will probably lose interest before that point, especially when you consider that some of the dungeons are absolutely miserable. It's clear that some of them are designed to straight up waste your time and artificially prolong the game. If you can bear it until the end of the game, you will definitely be satisfied, as the story and everything does have a very good (and very Atlus-y) payoff.

132360644.review:
I hate this rating system.

It's hard to give this game a "not recommended" when in fact, the truth is somewhere in the middle. 

It's not a bad game at all. It's also not spectacular if you've played other games in the SMT universe. This game is a Cyberpunk interpretation of a SMT game. The world is quite interesting and the characters are well written. But just not enough time and effort was put into the game that it needed.

To summarize, the game seems like it had a great blueprint with a lot of potential on paper, but due to a shoestring budget or other reasons, the game was never given the chance to blossom. The world while interesting, is bare bones. You are not told enough about the events that led up to the world you are now inhabiting. 

There aren't any Social Links/Confidants (Persona) to flesh out the world. Instead, you have one place that you can meet with your party members where you accumulate "Soul Points" in order to unlock gates in their respective mini-dungeons. The mini-dungeons of each character are repetitive and predictable.  

Speaking of the dungeons, they are also mundane. Each dungeon plays the same, and while they might have small differences in size and scope, they are essentially the same kind of place and suffer from severe repetition.

The story had potential but felt incomplete. The story, which is good on paper and could have had some really compelling moments, was held back by some instances of clumsy writing and the main event scripting which felt a bit rushed.

The only place the game shines is the gameplay. It's good ol' SMT Devil Summoner gameplay. The gameplay does all the heavy lifting for the game because otherwise, I would have gotten bored and stopped around the 20th hour. 

So much potential wasted. If you have never played a SMT or Persona game and can get it on discount, then you should pick it up. Otherwise, save your money and wait for the next Persona game.

131959228.review:
Soul Hackers 2, itself as a game, does not deserve the review beating it has taken. As a bridge between social sim Persona and Hardcore JRPG SMT, it does quite well. A solid 8, not groundbreaking but a fun time.
The main focus of the story is Ringo and her crew travailing a horrible stagnant and stale corporate future, in order to save mankind from causing its own destruction.

The gameplay is standard SMT/Persona fair, turn based combat plus creature collection. Its not particularly hard if you have any JRPG experience and tends to border on being too easy.

The world and dungeon design is not that good tbh. granted it sets the tone of living in a corporate and stagnant city , with a thin veneer of glamour masking the hollowed out reality of a post industrial city. Yet this boils down to a lot of corridors in train tunnels and empty corporate buildings when dungeon diving. Except the Soul matrix part of the game, which is more like long pathways in "cyber space" and teleporter puzzles. I enjoyed the soul matrix until I ran into those puzzles. I wish that they were just number/colour coded. My advise is save before you jump.

On the down sides, its a bit short, the teleporter puzzles suck and thats about it. I even liked the music , even if it was limited it wasn't grating. 

HOWEVER the DLC practices are obscene. If it wasn't for the high prices it could almost be forgiven, but locking away series regular demons was too much, it felt like whaling. Costumes and extra missions are one thing (not great behaviour, but all too common ) but that was a step too far.

Other notes is that this port runs ok. You will get stutter on your first battle of that play session, but other then that its not too noticeable, when running around and such.

Overall I did enjoy my time with it and 100% completed it. I liked the combat chatter from team mates and the enemies making the characters have bags of personality. I enjoyed the style of the character design and the music. The story is So-so to good, with great character moments thrown in and some good voice acting from Ringo and Milady's VA in particular. 

I look forward to any sequels that may come.

I would say that this game is easily worth its money at £30 or about that. I wouldn't bother with the DLCs at all. The challenge battles arn't worth it, though the character introduced is fun.

131826337.review:
I went into this game with tempered expectations and really enjoyed it. As a fan of DRPGs and Atlus' PS2-era output I felt right at home, and the QoL updates fixed a lot of issues. 

Pros and cons:
+ Great all-adult cast of relatable companions
+ Ringo is an amazing protagonist
+ Some good gimmicks in the dungeon navigation
+ Navigating between dungeons, shops etc. is snappy
+ Fun core loop
+ Battle system is easier than many SMT games but still has depth
+ Not too long (50h avg. doing all optional base-game content)
+ Great music
++ Disco jacket

- Low budget is apparent in dungeon visual design & character portraits
- Character designs look like they all came from different games
- Extremely predictable JRPG tropes in the plot (YMMV)
- Some plot points felt too sudden or forced
- Soul Matrix is a bit too large & monotonous

131520458.review:
Overpriced but still kinda fun. All the criticisms are valid. I barely recommend. 

If Soul Hackers was a riff on the earlier SMT formula, this is certainly based on SMT4. 3D environments, requests, etc. I couldn't help think of other games in the greater series when playing this.

The core feeling I got was Tartarus from Persona 3. I remember many, many hours of running around and grinding and without the cheat DLC, I'd sure be grinding SH2 right now. Two major problems are it reminds me of P3P, where most of the fun exploration was replaced by menus, and that many of the dungeons end up being blind teleporter mazes. 

The story reminded me of Strange Journey not for any thematic reason, just it barely existed and the party members were basically "Stupidly selfless" good, "Rage Against the Machine" evil, and "I'm not getting involved" neutral. Similarly, the choice of endings (if there is one, I'm unsure) is a pick-a-path in the last 15 minutes of gameplay.

Combat is overly simplified. Now weaknesses just add to a meter that does more damage at end of turn. It loses a lot of complexity and people interested in deep SMT tactical battles are out of luck.

It is graphically very nice and the voice acting is above average. I can see where the money went, but this is very much Atlus' B series, with their A price. 

I guess I had almost 28 hours in it, but as the game went on, I needed more and more frequent breaks. That's not the way things should be. I don't want my time back, but this is "Pad playtime by grinding: The Game." Get it on sale, and be sure you're interested in grinding and obnoxious mazes. If you're expecting Persona 5, you'll be very disappointed. If you're expecting Strange Journey or Devil Summoner in 3D, that's less likely to end in heartbreak. But that price point.

131101705.review:
I enjoyed my time with Soul Hackers 2 and would overall give it a thumbs up.  It's the usual as far as turn based weakness exploiting SMT combat goes - so if that's up your alley you're likely to get some good mileage here.  The story is pretty well done and the voice acting is phenomenal.  The game is also short enough to where the things that bothered me didn't get out of control, but there are some noticeable issues for sure.

-Dungeons are bland and barely vary throughout the entire game until the last dungeon.
-You will hear the same 4 songs for 90% of the play time.
-Lots of content that should be available with the main game is gated by NG+.

That third point is the most frustrating to me.  There is a mechanic in place where certain answers to situations will increase your link to a party member, which in turn governs how far you can venture into their psyche which functions as another dungeon to explore as well as fleshing out their characters further.  There are a finite amount of these points available per playthrough, so playing multiple times to see it all is required.  The game also only has one real route through the main story so everything else will play the same, making the whole process even sillier.

All that being said, I DO still recommend the game.  It's not the strongest offering from ATLUS but it's far from weak, and especially worth picking up on a decent sale.

130937665.review:
I liked Soul Hackers 2, the visuals are stylish, the story is pretty well written with some cool philosophical stuff, the music is stellar, the animated art that emotes along with the conversation is soooo coool and immersive. The characters in the game are all pretty well written and Ringo is a great example of an interesting Main Character. I really hope that the MC in future games can be an actual character instead of a card board cut out going forward! If you just want a good looking game with a solid story then it's pretty good. This issues with the game come from the fact that it's an ATLUS game and has some siblings that are hard to be compared to.

This is NOT a Persona game, so if you are coming off of that Persona 5 PC release looking for a fix, you won't find it here. There's no life sim, and no dating. I honestly kind of feel the same can be said for Shin Megami fans looking for their next fix too, as this game lacks the press turn systems that create challenging but fair combat in that side of the franchise.

Instead it uses a new system called the Stack that I think is interesting and forces you to utilize items more, but has some issues. The stack instead of giving you extra turns for exploiting a weakness creates a stack of damage that will be dealt at the end of your teams round, and there will sometimes be additional effects added to that depending on the demons you have. You will unlock more ways to make the stack stronger as the game progresses as well. Ultimately while I find the stack interesting it does not pair well with the typical difficulty of a Shin Megami game. I originally started playing on Hard, but had to switch it down to normal just because I felt the stack didn't give me enough agency to deal with the deadly enemies I was facing. Even on normal a lot of the fights didn't feel like the stack contributed enough to give me any sort of advantage or survivability. 

Overall I don't think this game is a bad game, but it's not your typical Shin Megami game. If you are aware of that I think you can come in and enjoy it for being a game with a good story, good characters, and great music. Though honestly I'd turn down the difficulty and just focus on the story.

130614982.review:
I never posted a review for a game before because I feel like everyone is going to have a different opinion about a game regardless. However, I am going to have to make one just for this game in particular. So pardon my lackluster compositional skills. 

I feel like this game gets a lot more negative criticism than it deserves. So here's my take on it as someone who has recently gotten into the series starting with, of course, Persona 5. From there, I went on to play Persona 3, Persona 4, Persona 4 Golden, Persona 5 Strikers, and SMT3: Nocturne. I also played some of the non-RPG titles like all of the Persona dancing games and the fighting games. So that is where I am at in terms of the series. If you have been into the series for quite some time, then chances are that there are a lot of elements of this game that are going to turn you off and you are not going to like my review so may want to stop reading right about now. However, for those of you who are relatively new or are on the fence about this game due to negative reviews like I was, I feel that you should give this game a chance even if you have to wait for a sale. 

Gameplay: This game is actually pretty damn fun - mainly because it still has that addicting SMT gameplay. In terms of difficulty, this is probably the easiest out of any of the SMT games that I have played as it is pretty easy to get demons that can resist any element. There plenty of side quests in addition to the main quest even though they don't really get anywhere that interesting in the end, but offer additional combat and rewards that can help make the game even easier and unlock certain dungeons/maps. If anything, I think this adds accessibility to the game especially for those that are not familiar with the SMT series or are not fans of the difficulty spike in certain games of the series especially towards the end. Those of you looking for that challenging SMT gameplay may want to skip this one. I'm personally into both the challenging games and this accessible level of difficulty for this game. There is also new game+ available so that adds some replayability to the game too. I personally don't do new game+ stuff anymore since I have limited time for video games these days. 

Story: It is your typical JRPG trope-filled prevent the end of the world with the power of friendship kind of storyline. The characters are pretty likeable in my opinion although a bit flat. They help make the atmosphere feel pretty chill unlike Nocturne where everything feels empty and depressing (yeah, I know it is supposed to be post-apocalyptic) even though some people are into that. To each their own.

Art Direction: I like it. Personally, not a fan of the other SMT games with the gothic doll-like artwork so it was not hard for me to like the artwork in this. 

Environment/Level Design: Other people seem to think that the dungeons are repetitive or tedious. If you think that the level design is repetitive, then you need to play Dragon Age 2. If you think that the maps in this game are tedious, then you need to play SMT: Nocturne. 

Music: Pretty good, but not Persona 3,4, or 5 level of good. 

Performance: This game never had any form of instability and it never crashed for me. I feel like it was optimized well for the PC and I had smooth frame rates the whole time. The game did not seem to be graphically demanding in the first place evidence being that my GPU fans did not activate when I played this game and I am rolling with a 5600xt with a Ryzen 7 3700X when I played it. 

If you are into ratings, then I would personally give this game an 8.5/10.

130308477.review:
I've finished this game twice now, once on the PS5 version and once on PC. Obtained true ending on both.

For context, Megaten has been my favorite video game franchise since 2015, and Devil Summoner: Soul Hackers is one of my favorite games in the entire franchise. When Soul Hackers 2 was announced in early 2022, I felt a combination of optimism and skepticism going into this game. On one hand, I was so happy that ATLUS was making a new Megaten game that wasn't Mainline SMT or Persona, which still gives me hope that there will be future games for other Megaten spinoffs (devil survivor 3 PLEASE)

On the other... this game looked like a very big departure from the first game. It took awhile to *somewhat* get over that hurdle for me, but once I did (and after going through the game twice), I can say that - while flawed from a dungeon crawling perspective, I really enjoyed my time with Soul Hackers 2.

In my opinion, I think that the best part of this game is the story, which might just be the best Megaten story since SMT IV. The main party of this game are some of the most charming characters I've seen from ATLUS, and Ringo might just be my favorite protagonist in all of Megaten. She's wonderful. The plot is simple, but works very well throughout most of the game due to solid writing and great voice acting. Furthermore, I appreciate the emphasis of Detective Work throughout the game, which is seen throughout all of Devil Summoner. While this doesn't feel like a Soul Hackers sequel in my opinion, I think this game works great as a Devil Summoner title (should've called it Devil Summoner: Aion)

The combat system called "Sabbath" is similar to the demon coop system in Strange Journey, and while it starts of slow, it really does open up greatly the more you progress through the game. While I don't think it's the best combat in Megaten, I find it to be very solid on its own and remains fun through the rest of the game.

The same cannot be said for the Dungeon Crawling. As a whole, these might be some of the worst dungeons in all of Megaten. The Soul Matrix (the game's optional dungeon which provides very powerful upgrades and additional story for the party) is the biggest offender to this. Boring designs, repetitive music and visual design, large amounts of dead/open space, etc. The main story dungeons also suffer from these issues, although as the game progresses, there is slightly more variety in both music and visual design. After the November Patch, dungeon crawling is less annoying with the addition of a sprint button, but this only mitigates the bad dungeon crawling. Coming directly after SMT V (where the open areas of Da'at had really incredible level design), it's crazy how much of a stepback this game was.

Overall, I really enjoyed my time with this game. Soul Hackers 2 goes on sale often, so if you're a fan of ATLUS or are just looking for a solid JRPG, I do recommend buying it! Although reception and sales were middling for this game, I do hope for future titles in Megaten that aren't Mainline SMT and Persona. Personally, I think it's likely with how well SMT V and the P5R ports sold, so I'm looking forward to what's next from ATLUS.

129492667.review:
The hate I hear from the game because it doesn't compare from the first Soul Hackers game. after completing hard difficulty first walkthrough because a challenge is always fun. I did have fun however noticing its flaws, played few other well known Shin Megami Tensei titles, Soul Hackers 2 didn't exactly grasped me like the first Soul Hackers. What makes Soul Hackers unique from other SMT titles and Persona? 

Firstly, we all know Status Aliments is a common thing however one Aliment "Bomb" is only in Soul Hackers. To see it back in Soul Hackers 2 made it exciting, as well for demons in a unique race name "Zomas" that was later mention in the story. However I knew the "Demon Compendium" didn't have a whole lot of demons like SMTV, not even ONE "Zoma" to fuse for. The hype for it died down for it. A returning character from the first Soul Hackers, and Devil Summoner came in and that was "Madame Ginko" but in all honestly, I just wasn't hype for it unfortunately, same applies for Yatagarasu and Phantom Society. Vision Quests are back but I find first Soul Hackers to be more entertaining. 

The characters from your party are great, the voice acting is fantastic. Saizo has relationship problems and shows how being a devil summoner messes/changes your life, which made me love a lot. Milady is cold, hides information from the group, eventually later gets expose on some stuff but all of that would've been solve if she just opens up to them a little more, especially since the dire situation everyone is in. Arrow is average, don't hate him, don't love him either. Couple moments where I was hype for him. Ringo has amazing personality and succeeds serving as a protagonist that always puts a smile on my face. Picking out choices as her is great to see her reaction. Voice acting amazing. Figue unfortunately didn't get enough screen time until the climax happens, eventually making me dislike her. Other adversaries that oppose Ringo and the gang are good, Iron Mask and his Zenon was good, both of their looks awesome. Without spoiling much, his writing could've use some work, but I love seeing him whenever I got the chance too. 

Story felt/is repetitive since the first person that died, and this kept going throughout. It was horrible because I'd really love to see more about the characters, how they got there, how they die ETC. If they did this, it probably would make me care about the characters lot more and get an understanding what sort of motive they wanted to aim at. Ichiro onda for example since the beginning, his slight shown of Braze made me want to know more about him, along with Arrows Sensei. The Developers love having their characters say "Soul Hackers". 

The day one DLC was a disaster, especially when they announced DLC from previous Soul Hackers cosmetics, a favorite character, and well known demons that SHOULD'VE already been in the game BASE. So no thank you. 

Gameplay; unfortunately it wasn't challenging. Hit a weakness, hit more weaknesses, you deal more damage from what's known as "Sabbaths" or "Stacks" if you're only a persona fan, basically an "All Out-Attack!" move. Yes, the battle is that of Persona look, you get four party members equip with demons with little stuff. Landing a improper move in battle, they don't punish you for it unlike SMT or even PERSONA games. You just get rewarded for it as long as you have a demon to block that move incase the enemy reflects on it. You don't lose a Stack, the enemy doesn't get stronger, NOTHING like that, so then the battles just feels.. well.. boring. Sometimes I wish it was just Ringo or with Arrow and Four/Three other demons which you don't see in battle unless its a Sabbath. If it had more actual team building, it would've been more fun, but Soul Hackers 2 just didn't have any sadly. No momentum/flow at all. If it were to have first Soul Hackers battle system, battles would've been NUTS. Little interaction with characters like reviving an ally, making jokes during battle was entertaining. Some may find it annoying, it can get old but I personally didn't mind. Customizing your COMPS was actually really fun for me! 

Dungeons; My god where do I begin. It was very repetitive, boring, last dungeon looked appealing. I disliked the Soul Axis dungeons, the portals were disgusting. I had to look up a guide online in order to pick which portal that would lead me to a gate. This made SMTV exploration look like a masterpiece to be honest. The Matrix doesn't chance at all, not even giving a little personality base around the character you wish to visit. Heck if they even add a red color in the background, I'd notice a little difference. The Music was the same thing, Matrix, if an enemy ambushes you, regular battle theme, EVEN when facing the bosses. I really wish it was different, R.S maybe having a hip hop battle theme, those bosses have the same music, god even Iron Mask bro. Missed Opportunity like how? It's a SIN. Dungeons hardly have any traps, and not enough puzzles. It sucks. Navigator to warn you enemies near by was super annoying. If they just left it out and keep a signal on right corner that changes colors showing you're on the clear or not, I'd be happy for cause I can see game, thank you. 

Anyways, lots of repetitive stuff in this game. I feel little emotional by characters but wasn't enough. I knew not to expect much from Atlus making 3D. I don't know how they didn't do it well on this one despite making great sellers in the past SMT that are 2D. I'm more emotional on that than the game itself. Please do better Atlus, I know you can, it's just not this one sadly. 6/10

129274567.review:
Guess I´ll keep this short. The overall experience was around 6/10 in my opinion.
After finally getting my hands on and devouring Persona 4, I decided to check and see what else Atlus has been up to. I´d never even hear d of Soul Hackers before this and from the demo footage it looked kinda cool. Now it´s 60 something hours later, and my opinion boils down to a resounding ''meh''. 

The story itself starts of well enough, introducing interesting concepts and showing a fair bit of promise. Unfortunately it seems content to never really explore some plot points, there are a fair few cases of loose threads just being left hanging, and by the halfway point it seems as if the story was being rushed violently to it´s conclusion. The characters likewise show a lot of promise, and in true Atlus style there are a few systems in place to help the player spend time with and get to know them better. Unfortunately I never found myself becoming invested in any of them, and any character motivations came of as fairly dull at best. There are a fair few things to enjoy about them on the surface, but when you begin to dig there really isn´t to much to find.

As for the gameplay itself it should be nothing to unfamiliar from Persona, although it felt more akin to Shin Megami Tensei. You have a fairly decent hub world to explore, various NPCs to interact with, quests to complete, it´s all here. the demon summoning allows for a fair bit of customization, depending on the situation at hand and a persons playstyle. Each character has strengths and weaknesses that can be offset to a degree, but never enough as to remove their individual identities. There is a bit of an issue of character dialogue getting quite repetitive, and that problem unfortunately persists throughout the entire game. I found myself playing the game more with the sound turned off during the more grindy sections, with the final boss suffering badly from this problem.

Main story line is relatively straightforward and easy to track. Most all of the plot twists that occurred are anything but subtle, although I will give the game props for one or two that did catch me by surprise. The side quests are your standard fair for these kinds of games, but I will give props for the NPC´s actually being given character development. A fair few will give multiple side quests of similar nature, but with an overarching story all of their own the progresses along with the main story.

I could speak of this game further, but as a whole this feels as though it is one is a hit-or-miss kind of situation. I can´t say I enjoyed it particularly, but that does no mean the game has no redeemable qualities. Far from it. I would say if you´re a fan of Atlus´ other work, I´d say you should think about giving this one a look. Definitely not one I would recommend paying full price for, but do pick it up when it goes on sale and give it a whirl. I can´t in good conscience recommend going out of your way to complete it, but if you just stick to the main story and a few side quests, I believe it should help to kill a few hours.
It by no means should be compared to it´s siblings, but taken as it´s own thing. An interesting venture into exciting waters, but ultimately it seems more interested in floating on stagnating waters, rather than raising the sails and catching it´s wind.
I would love to see what this series could become with some time and a fair bit of polish.

I'm glad I waited for the QoL update so I could sprint through dungeons, because oh my god is the dungeon design tedious. I hope you like long, blue-tinted corridors because that's essentially all you're getting. You'll also be revisiting most areas multiple times if you plan to do all the sidequests/get the "good" ending.

Battles are your standard Persona/SMT style turn-based combat, so unless you're very into those you won't get much else out of them.

I mostly play JRPGs for the characters and the story though, so I'd have been able to forgive the lackluster dungeon design if I really loved those. But I didn't. Saizo, Arrow, and Milady were all fine. Not particularly exciting, although it was nice that they were adults who had adult lives. Ringo... was not as great as I was led to believe from all the reviews. Not offensive in any way, but not particularly great either.

That's about all I can say for the characters. I loathed Figue, but that was almost a given. The story and worldbuilding made no sense. Everybody just blindly accepted the exposition dumps about an all-knowing AI, the conflict was basic and unnuanced, the final villain and their motivation made me roll my eyes (although the villain before that wasn't any better). It seems very clear to me that Arrow was meant to be the protagonist at one point, with how the story centered around him as much as it did, but he wasn't any more fleshed out than the others.

I also wish I'd gone with my gut for the "normal" ending. Doing all the dungeons and sidequests just for that cheesy "good" ending was not worth it. It was actively worse than the normal ending for me. But I guess by the time I got to that point, I just so done with the game I wanted everything to burn. 

Incidentally, you can't do everything on the first run. You have to do a NG+. Which I will never touch.

128236847.review:
I was on the fence for reviewing this game for so long because I wanted it to succeed. But after months dreading to return to it, I just gotta get it off my chest. Atlus rushes a RPG to further boost sales. It seemed too good to be true that two Atlus games came out in the same year.

Gameplay: Fun for the hardcore turn-based rpg players. For all others it will come off as a grueling dungeon crawl slug. I love a good grind but this game made me rethink that.
Levels/Worlds: Very nice designs, just wish they were a bit shorter. After a point everything looks the same and there isn't any events to liven up the rest of the crawl.
Characters: Ringo is obviously the strongest character, and it is nice to finally have a main character with their own personality. That being said at some points she's just too good? Too strong? It is clear they put all of their focus into the main character as the side characters are nothing but their tropes. Your side members exist just so you have the 4 party scheme of persona. Honestly you could go a more mainline SMT approach and that would take the bland characters out of the spotlight. Figue was my second favorite but the story reduces her to the sidelines for no reason other than a spoiler reason at the end of the game with very little pay off. Fuck the bird, easy to spot a cash grab mascot and this is the most bland attempt yet. It is just a drone for Figue and is tied to a shitty mechanic.
Voices: Being unable to turn off the notifications of enemy awareness is too taxing. I get the use, just let me turn it off. I played the game on mute after a point just to avoid it. YOU HAVE BEEN SPOTTED, YOU HAVE LOST SIGHT OF THE---, YOU HAVE BEEN SPOTTED. I played with the english dub voice acting and I'm sorry for them that they had to voice this game but at least they tried.
Graphics: I thought this was the area the game would struggle in but this is where the game performs. Everything is visually appealing and smooth, I think the cell shading helps but I could see where someone who hates anime style with a passion would get tired. 
Atmosphere: The game really hits the bright neon notes and a striking visual backdrop, but after a while things start to look the same. I wish there were areas that weren't as future or fantasy to show just how much things have advanced but every square inch screams "FUTURE FUTURE FUTURE"
Story: Interesting to a point. They really push the "technology has exceeded further than humans know what to do with and no new inventions will ever exist again" and then it just pretends we didn't discuss that for over half the game. For a society that has peaked, we don't see anything new from our world that could exist. It is a modern day world with a futuristic coat of pain and cyberpunk just ain't my thing.
Grind: Too much without DLC, Too easy with DLC. I like a good grind but other than the numbers going up the battle abilities are story progression locked and you only get a certain amount. Hope for 30 hours you were planning ahead! Which is another thing, imagine if this game was over 30 hours long and you still had to grind just as much. Makes me shutter. If only they spaced it out to a 100 hour RPG with better pacing.
DLC: Absolutely required. Can't beat the game without it. Shameless cash grab.

127726771.review:
Pretty good experience, especially post patch.

The biggest selling point I'd say is the main cast of characters that is pretty refreshing for an Atlus RPG, a bit reminiscent of P2 Eternal Punishment. Great interactions both in battle and in quieter moments, all sold by extremely high-quality voicework in both japanese and english. 

Speaking of good points, the game looks great on all fronts, but especially the characters and demons. The Kaneko designs have never looked better, it's like I'm rediscovering them after many years, and the addition of the Doi designs is also greatly appreciated. 

Combat starts out boring, but quickly gets more interesting, Your mileage may vary on whether or not that's acceptable, but by the midgame it was decently varied and enjoyable, and stayed that way until the end. It kinda does its own thing separate from all recent SMT titles (no turn shenanigans), and it does it okay.

Dungeon exploration is pretty bland, not helped by the lack of diversity in dungeon designs and soundtracks. The general direction of the game is a bit aimless in what it tries to convey about the state of the world. The plot fares much better as a personal story for the main cast than as a game with a broad message about society.

The game is solid overall, but more so because it has a lot of uneven parts that balance themselves out, with the positives edging out the negatives in the end. I hope Atlus takes it as a first step to diversify the SMT catalogue beyond the mainline and Persona games, because there are a lot of good elements in there that deserve to be explored further. Don't expect to have your mind blown, but you'll probably have a good time.

I just want a cool cast of characters like this one in all future Atlus games dammit.

127674437.review: This game received way too much hate, it's good it has some problems but it isn't even close to horrible like people seem to say

127654638.review:
This game feels like it was made by whoever was leftover from working on the persona ports at the atlus offices.

Soul Hackers 2 is probably the easiest megaten game out there from my experience, but if you're unfamiliar with megaten games as a whole, it might give you some challenge. That said, I don't recommend this as your first outing as it'll give you a bad first impression on what to expect going forwards.

The good:
The setting and presentation are nice, lots of style to be had if you're a sci-fi nerd and need a change of pace from your average cyberpunk dystopia. (Not that the dystopian aspect isn't explored at all)
Character design is stellar, especially for the important shop keepers you return to throughout the game.
The voice acting well done for the human characters and the jack frost monsters.
And the story is by far the games best strong suit.

The bad:
Simply put, this game overstays its welcome by a long shot.

If you're B lining it for the story you might not feel anything beyond the occasional grind wall for neglecting side content.
However, being a completionist, or 80%ist, the game is littered with busy work that can feel more time wasting than interesting.
by the 30 hour mark, you've already seen all there is aside from the stories conclusion.
Dungeons easily feel like stretches of land with nothing to do in them aside from fight, but you'll start to avoid combat after a while as the only time the game tests you is through the "target" series of side missions.
These missions start out fun, helping you come up with clever ways to beat the fight like a puzzle, but eventually feel like a gotcha for not investing in a monster who can use a particular skill. made worse by the fact, the hardest target missions, require abilities you don't "need" for anything in the base game.
its not hard because you can't use your head, its hard because you happen to not have the answer with you, and you'll have to then spend the time to go bad and rebuild a particular monster to have the move.
The sad thing is, these will be the things that get you killed in almost every circumstance. the fights run on a timer where if you take too long, they'll throw out a move that insta kills the party. I can still count on two hands the amount of times I died to fights normally.

On the target of dungeons, the thing that finally got me to write them off, almost every late game dungeon relies on putting long hallways with rooms that have multiple teleporters everywhere. one or two, ok. but when five dungeons do the same thing back to back, thats not challenging. thats mind numming. made worse by the fact they all look the same.

Demon negotiation is all but nonexistent in this. Now you just find you monsters throughout the dungeon, the demon will show up, ask for something slightly more demanding depending on how many of the said demon you've killed. they then join you no question.

the voices for the demons outside of the jack bros series aren't fitting either. recent game gave them good voices, but now suddenly ones who normally sound refined and calculated sound crazy and silly.



what version should you get?
either the deluxe or ultimate edition. get them on sale. don't pay full price for any version.
the inclusions either version provide make the overall game easier to swallow, especially with how low the price point has been getting on sales lately.

Final verdict: 6/10
TLDR: its OK. but thats it. don't bother trying to 100% it. Don't make this your first megaten game either.

127212418.review:
TLDR:
  Don't hate this game for its creative or gameplay decisions. Hate it for its technical failure. In other words: this is a fun game until it stops working. All I get upon starting the game now is eternal loading. Not recommended unless the issue gets fixed.

THE FULL REVIEW (spoiler-free)

  Most of you have probably already got your info on this game from Megaten youtubers, so here I will mainly touch on things they didn't, or on points I have a different view on.


THE GOOD

Story & Characters
  You play as Ringo and three other party members to prevent the apocalypse in a futuristic and apparently stagnant but comfortable society. The plot has three major twists which I found engaging enough to keep me wanting to play. Ringo has a positive and playful personality, and I would love to befriend her IRL. Opinions on the other three party members vary across the playerbase, so make your own mind up. However, they still come across more alive in general than P3's cast (SEES); you can feel both the camaraderie and animosity in SH2. As for Figue, she is wife material; that is a fact!

Art Style
 The game has a captivating art style and fresh character designs (within Megaten at least) and it pulls it off well.  The colours pop out very nicely in the whole game without being garish, whether it's on a bright environment like the hub worlds or sabbath attacks, or  the subtle specks of colour in the light signals and yellow lines in the dark subway tunnels. The menus are stylish but not overly so. I like the helpful skill type and weakness/resistance icons. Too bad the text is so small, and you cannot enlarge it in the config at all.

Music
  Most tracks are just fine, but there are a few bangers. They are: Mansei Realm, Safehouse, Battle, Boss, Soul Matrix Boss, and the opening theme Hopeless Call. See also Soul Matrix section. 

Combat
  The battles are easy in random encounters, but harder during the bosses from the mid-game onwards, and hardest during risky (mauve) enemies. The latter category is used to grind for high sums of XP and money. A good balance in difficulty overall. (I played on Normal all the way.)

The main principle in SH2 is the stack and sabbath system. Strike an enemy's weakness to add one of your demons to the stack. Once all your party members have their turn, all demons from the stack you made do a free, all-out attack on the enemy. The more demons in the stack, the more damage you do. This applies only to you; the enemy does not do stacks on you. 

Another important change is that aliments are now a big deal, while are buffs and debuffs less so, so you should take ailment skills, vulnerabilities and resistances seriously when making your demons and constructing your party. Learn to exploit this to your advantage and you'll have such fun!  Shield spells (as well as buffs ad debuffs) work on all allies/enemies (so, you know: properly!) which is a definite plus. 
Critical hits, unfortunately, do not result in extra turns, unit later in the game as an optional, unlockable, in-game upgrade to your comp weapons. 

Overall the stack and Sabbaths make for a fun combat system. I like the build-up to each sabbath with the demon silhouettes and increasingly thick mist and colours. The sabbath attack animations are thrilling and satisfying to watch. I've only ever skipped them twice out of over 100 times.

Soul Matrix
  This is a semi-optional dungeon you must complete if you want to unlock more character abilities (summoner skills). Many players have complained that the Soul Matrix is the same visually and musically throughout, and while I absolutely see their point, it's not all bad. The music and atmosphere are very serene outside of battle, and I love to admire the shimmering effect on the floor or background blocks. I advise you to stop and smell the roses. Admittedly, the blocks and BG could at least have been differently coloured for each character, and maybe the hue could have changed the further you progress. Nevertheless, I'll still gladly take the Soul Matrix over Persona 3's Tartarus any day for the positives I've mentioned.

Demon Personalities
  Atlus have always tried to flesh out the demons' personalities through their dialogue in the Megaten games I am aware of, and SH2 builds on this trend. The demons in SH2 have text archetypes and voice archetypes to give you an idea of their personalities. Some of the voice archetypes which stood out to me are: the Valley Girl (Mermaid, Apsaras), the cocky and mischievous male (Gremlin, Andras, Cu Chulain), gay male (Mokoi, Mothman), caring older sister or governess (Silky, Valkyrie) and scumbag male (Pazuzu). They did interesting things with Mothman and Pazuz. Info on them below in their own sections.

Unfortunately, these are for flavour only. The excellent demon loyalty mechanic from SH1 is gone. I'm not joking. Demon loyalty was fun in SH1 and half-arsed in the Raidou games.

Mothman (minor spoilers)
A certain mothman stalks you throughout the apartment block dungeon to drain your party's MP before absconding to leave you fighting his increasingly tougher possy (nothing you shouldn't be able to handle by then). Mothman may use the gay voice archetype, but you know that one gets bitches. He is a real player. God bless you, Mothman! 
When you finally catch up to him, he has three of his fellows with him. Throughout the dungeon I kept thinking you would take him/them out in a boss battle similar to, but even more satisfying than, the cat in Eternal Punishment's TV studio dungeon, but no. They are destroyed for you in a cutscene. [sigh] Never mind.

Pazuzu
Atlus has always been good at writing downright scummy characters when they intend to, and in SH2 this honour goes to Pazuzu. He is the objective in a semi-optional sidequest from Aion. His lines are voiced and let you know that although he is powerful and speaks in a refined manner, he is nothing more than a bully. If you have a shred of decency in you, you'll make it your obligation to take him out. Great job, writers. Another Pazuzu appears in the Ash boss fight and uses the poison mist mechanic which was fun.

THE BAD

Demon negotiation
  It is overly-simplified. It works, but it's better in Nocturne. Then again, did any Megaten veterans complain about buying demons in an auction in Devil Survivor?

Text Size
  The text is much too small, and there is no way to change it. We went from nice and clear in P4G, to OK in Nocturne, to unreadable unless you put your spine into shrimp mode for the unvoiced dialogue in SH2. Please rectify this ASAP,  Atlus. I'm sure it would be much easier than sending Mr. Tomigawa round to fix my back every time.

The technical problem
  All I get upon starting the game now is eternal loading. I can't even get the title screen anymore. And this was all of a sudden after playing the game some 135 hours. The solution someone suggested on the Steam forum did not work for me at all even after verifying all of my local files. I cannot even say to wait for a sale, because this may happen to you at any time. Whether you buy it cheap or dear, what good is a game you cannot keep playing?

CONCLUSION
What a shame. Apart form the one bug which makes the game unplayable, the good definitely outweighs the bad as long as you can play the game in the first place.

127157179.review: honestly pretty good game. story wasnt anything to crazy but i enjoyed it, characters i liked a lot and were very interesting, music was super good, gameplay was pretty much like every atlus game in a way and voice acting was really good

127139144.review:
It's decent. 
7.5/10

Its decent, but playing this right after Persona 5 hurts its score.
Persona 5 had fast combat animations, great soundtracks, good pacing, and interesting maps.
Soul Hackers 2 combat feels slower, soundtrack not memorable, a lot of side quests, and the 'soul' dungeons are all the same maze like style. 

Pros:
The world is a futuristic japan with demons summoning being the normal.
Main characters are fairly cool and their story unravels as you play.
The shops owners are like side characters with their own side quests and stories.
Side quests are quite interesting for lore, world builder, and store owner stories. There are defeat or collect x amount of item requests, but you can usually do them alongside the main story/more interesting side quests.
Japanese and English voice included. The japanese sounds more impactful to me, but you do miss out on battle dialogues not being shown as subtitles.
The sprites/artwork are nice and animated to talk and blink.
The camera work during cut scenes are quite nice and have more effort put into it. 

Con:
Combat is not snappy and feels slow. There is a speed up option that doesn't feel nice to watch, but it does help.
Initiating combat is odd. You need to swing at the enemies model and then walk up to it to start combat. I get its there so you can skip battles (swing but don't touch), but feels odd.
Map list is ehh. Its gets long, and theres not indents to help quickly locate city or store options.
Weird default settings. Like character purposely being off center, insanely zoom in camera, voice actors speaks before the text is able to appear. All can be fix in settings, but just weird choices to have as their default.
Dungeons gets boring quick. It just reused dungeons with long branches paths where you either hit a dead end or go the right path.

Overall:
Its a decent JRPG, don't recommend for full price. If you haven't played Persona 5 yet, choose that instead. Soul Hackers 2 is if you just want more SMT/Persona style game.

127129770.review: Many who need this might not see it, but the steam cloud saves are broken and will corrupt your game. In order to fix this, screw around in the main menu (start new game, exit before selecting difficulty, open config, mess around in it a little, go back to title, etc.) and eventually it will somehow uncorrupt your save. I saw that this worked for multiple people online and I can confirm that it worked for me too. I hope this helps someone who fell into the same "trap" as me. 127107139.review:
I dunno whether to recommend this game or not! I have a love/hate relationship with this game.

I personally really adore Ringo as a character (She's a fully written, full voiced character which is awesome and hopefully ATLUS does this with future protagonists) and I really like Saizo, Milady, and Arrow too. I like the soundtrack with the opening theme being my favorite song from this game and it's cool that Keiichi Okabe composed the soundtrack. I found the world itself to be interesting, but not as much as the original Soul Hackers' world. I like how this game has a full adult cast and I super enjoyed their many interactions between one another! These characters are not friends and it took until almost the end of the game for your group in-game to truly "be friends" or at least get along well, and I know throughout the game they'll sometimes have a nice chat but a lot of the times when they're together they will have arguments of some kind (Arrow and Milady are a big example of this) and this is because they these four characters have no choice but to stick together and stay as a team to get through this even though they don't want to! They basically aren't friends and are forced to be together and overtime these characters develop more, and I honestly love all this about these characters. They're nothing like the usual characters who join you on your adventure in jrpg's and rpg's where everyone in your group is just super nice and wants to help you on your quest without question, with everything being hunky-dory. 

However, as for the things I do NOT like about this game: Let's start with the Soul Matrix. It feels pretty bland and uninteresting, the music is always the exact same which is a real shame. I don't like how no matter how deep the places goes the Soul Matrix always looks the exact same and it doesn't have any sort of variety to it. I also feel it drags on for far too long as what also doesn't help is the fact there's import story stuff tied to it and the player is required to completely explore the entirety of each Soul Matrix to unlock everything the Soul Matrix has to offer, including the story stuff. When I mentioned "Each Soul Matrix" I mean that there's three Sectors in the Soul Matrix. There's the Arrow Sector, Milady Sector, and the Saizo Sector, and each look and play the exact same but the only differences between them is that each sector has it'd own story stuff like cutscenes etc (for example, Saizo's Sector is focused on Saizo) and while I do love these three characters (ESPECIALLY Saizo) I honestly feel the Soul Matrix drags on for far too long and according to some players, the Soul Matrix became too much for them overtime and they didn't want to do them anymore which is a shame because of the story stuff that's locked behind the Soul Matrix is actually good important stuff for these characters from what I remember experiencing but I fully understand these players decision. I personally did not mind the Soul Matrix too much but yeah I honestly understand other people's  criticism. Another thing I don't like about this game are the many dungeons (and not to be confused with the Soul Matrix. that too is a dungeon but it's a single overly large dungeon with randomly generated layouts). These dungeons are more bearable than the Soul Matrix, HOWEVER these dungeons are very uninspired, uninteresting, and boring but sure you could say the dungeons of the original Soul Hackers were "not good" however I truly believe those dungeons had much more thought put into them plus all those dungeons in the original Soul Hacker's had great interactions within them, and I feel Soul Hackers 2 is absolutely brought down not only by it's dungeons but also how all interactions within those dungeons work. Something I should also mention about Soul Hackers 2's dungeons that I didn't enjoy is that it's dungeons lack puzzles or at least any good puzzles.

Overall, I have a love/hate relationship for this game. There's things I wish had more thought put into (like the soul matrix, dungeons, and puzzles) and things that I believe are fine the way they are (like the main characters the player is with throughout this game, and the voice acting) and plus it's a good game in my opinion but there are things which hold it back from being great and the dungeons/soul matrix may turn away other people from playing this game, especially with how much talk there is about them online and to be honest the soul matrix is the worst part about this game for me.

For me this game is a 6-7/10 rating for me, at least! It has pros and it has cons, and because a lot of the time spent in this game is through the Soul Matrix and the many Dungeons explored in-game, It's a hard sell in my opinion. I feel this game is the perfect example as to why fun and overall great dungeon design in any game is super important and that bad uninspired dungeon design/dungeons is not good for any game.

Even though my review says "I recommended this game" it's a review that's both positive and negative.

It was lacking in story, yet it it did have interesting characters, Saizo being my favorite of course. It also had demons and gameplay that you'll easily get familiar with if you ever played any Shin Megami Tensei or Persona game. I definitely wished it was more developed regarding the dungeons, which are repetitive and aesthetically boring, and customization, which just boils down to using the highest stat item and paying for the DLC if you want your characters to look different.  All of that said, the game is addicting for someone like me who loves playing Shin Megami Tensei and Persona games. I love grinding, listening to the music, and seeing the visuals and the interesting characters. It maybe needed more time of development to make it feel more unique, but as it is, I still recommend the game if you never played any of the other Atlus games I mentioned. If you have played the other games, you're probably playing Persona 5 or even 4 as you should be.

125644998.review:
[h1] A boring game that is a Soul Hackers sequel in name only [/h1]
[b] Welcome to yet another ATLUS crash grab brought to you by the corpse of a long dead JRPG studio being puppeted by SEGA. [/b]

[u] STORY [/u]
Two cyborg waifus created by a super secret artificial intelligence attempt to stop a culturally stagnant humanity from killing itself via demons. The setup is more exciting than the actual plot itself. The twists and turns follow your typical JRPG playbook with every [b] EBIK REVEAL ZOMG [/b] coming from a mile away. One noteworthy inclusion is that the MC, Ringo, is fully voiced. While not the worst thing in the world it's hardly anything special and Ringo herself can be funny despite some of the cringe writing. 

[u] GAMEPLAY [/u]
You'd think a sequel to Soul Hackers would have demon summoning and recruitment, well you're wrong bucko! The series is now a persona spinoff complete with lack of demon party members and recruitment. Instead you equip one of your four human party members with a demon and they use the inherited spells and abilities. Recruitment is handled in the most brain dead way possible, you walk around and find them randomly. You simply give them what they ask for and if your level is high enough they're yours. You'll be hunting for demons randomly placed in dungeon maps so boring and empty you'll get persona 3/4 flashbacks and they aren't even randomly generated maps! Combat is one of the worst in the series thus far! Instead of the one more time system where a strike with an enemies weakness you get build your "Sabbath" charge. Some hits can add more than 1 per attack if you hit hard enough or use a commander skill to boost them. At the end of your turn your demons come out to smack the enemy. You or your enemies hitting weaknesses do not give/take away turns unless it's status related which makes the combat extremely easy and boring. In an attempt rectify this they added the commander skills from SMT strange journey REDUX [spoiler] it didn't help, combat is still boring [/spoiler]. There's also social links, but they're for the party members only and suck.

[u] PORT REPORT [/u]
Actually nearly fully featured other than lack of ultrawide because Japanese indie devu pwease understandu.

[u] In Closing [/u]

Soul Hackers 2 is a great spin-off. It isn’t as long or ambitious as other Shin Megami Tensei titles, but it’s clearly made with the same quality. While the reduced number of demons and the simpler mechanics can be a negative for veterans, this game proves to be a much friendlier starting point for newcomers. Fans of the franchise will likely enjoy this installment, even if it lacks the complexity of other titles in the series.

PROS:
✓ A distinctive art style
✓ Story and characters are enjoyable
✓ Two endings for players to unlock
✓ Excellent PC port full of modern options
✓ Fantastic voice acting 
✓ Enjoyable fighting mechanics
✓ Few new demons never seen in the series

CONS:
- Side quests don’t add much colour to the world and are quite shallow
- Dungeons are basic and repetitive
- Selling some demons through DLC
- No normal demon negotiations
- Devil Summoner game, that, just doesn't have it in the title

After playing this game, it's an excellent SMT universe title worthy of your time!!! 125349067.review:
is this the best megaten game out there?
no
is is truly worth $60?
probably not.
but do i love this game anyways? absolutely. 
The combat is the classic weakness system megaten is famous for, although it does deviate with the sabbath system rather than the press turn or one more combat system, but its still just as rewarding. By downing enemies using their weakness or getting a critical hit, it adds to the sabbath counter, in which more and more demons can participate and deal extra damage, as well as some having sabbath skills that allow for extra moves being able to be pulled off (extra damage, health/mp restore, etc).
The characters are also, well, full of character! They do fall a bit cliche at times, but Arrow and Milidy's constant bickering, with Saizo just in the backround trying to stay neutral was pretty amusing, and Ringo's initial snarkiness at how primative humanity is was always fun. In fact, Ringo in general is just a fun character who calls everyone out on their BS.
Honestly, the only thing i can really say the game was lacking in were the dungeons. I wasnt expecting Persona 5 levels of design, but the long corridors lead me to think that the dungeons were originally going to be randomly generated (ala persona 3/4), especially the SOUL Matrix, the "mementos" as it were of the game. Other than bland dungeon design though, the game might be a tad on the shorter side (no side content start to finish being about 6-7 hours, doing only the manditory 1st floor of the matrix and minimal demon fusion), but on a "normal" playthrough, its probably going to take around 9-10 hours, especially when counting in the DLC.
Overall, i give the game a 7.5/10
Its fun and enjoyable, but not for everyone. the game had a small budget and it shows, but it does everything it can with that budget.
$60 is totally worth it, but hey, it doesnt hurt your wallet to see if it goes on sale for ~$40.

125261111.review:
So first off, let me state that Soul Hackers 2 IS NOT PERSONA in any way shape, or form! If you need to have this game compared to something from Atlus, the closest match is Tokyo Mirage Sessions #FE Encore for the Nintendo Switch. They are very similar in design philosophy, battles, etc. 
So now that is out of the way. Let's get to the pros and cons!

Pros-
- Future Cyberpunk setting (think Cyberpunk Edgerunner aesthetic mixed with SAO anime character design)
- The cast of characters (the cast is small but has enough variety and personality differences. Character growth also happens as you do more side quests and activities with them, as well as advance the main story.)
- Combat is fun with a twist to the usual Atlus-style combat systems that we have come to expect from things like Persona. 
- No knowledge of the previous game is needed at all.
- Music and Voice acting are all good and fit the setting and themes.

Cons-

- Combat-heavy game (If you are more for story over gameplay this game may not be for you as there is a TON of dungeon crawling and combat with a little section of the main story thrown in at various points.)
- Difficulty Spikes (certain areas can see a sharp increase in difficulty.)
- Side quests (Kill X many things, Fetch this, there are some story bits that try to make them at least entertaining. However, the biggest problem is all the backtracking to previous areas to complete these quests.) 

     So is Soul Hackers 2 the next big Persona franchise Atlus is hoping it would be? Nah, it is more the Tokyo Mirage Sessions #FE Encore just available on every platform now. It is a decent game as long as you do not come in expecting Persona 5 Royal, or Persona 4 Golden. You will get a competent JRPG with some unique things going for it, I would give it a 37/50 (or a 7.5/3.5 for your more traditional game score people)

125227801.review: It was... "Ok". The story could have been better but otherwise an ok game.

125141375.review:
I used to be a big SMT fan, or the SMT blanket of games, but not as much recently. My favorite game of all time is the first Persona. I was really disappointed with the direction the series went with social links in 3 on. I mention this in case just knowing that helps you decide if you agree with me or not going forward.

As far as Soul Hackers go, and the first Devil Summoner...I dabbled with them, but didn't get far because of the language barrier (back when they were on Saturn). They both became more of collectors items. So I can't really compare this game to the first...but what this game came out to was pretty impressive.

The combat system feels pretty standard of the series, but I really like the benefit of stacks from hitting weaknesses. I am always targeting weaknesses and keeping a balance of spells, so this is just adding icing on the damage cake.

Also the way social links are handled in this is so much better than the other SMT games i have played. It doesn't feel like it is trying to take over like in the Persona series. Its subtle...leaving the game, exploration, and combat as the main focus.

I've seen others mention areas being boring and bland...and that there are a lot of cut scenes, making it more of a visual than a game. I haven't gotten super far into it (around level 22 currently), but I haven't felt like I have been spending more time watching than playing...and the areas do look the same, but it didn't seem like a distraction or disappointment to me. I grew up on areas looking the same. Thankfully there is an on screen map to help. I remember the days of NES exploration where that wasn't present.

I guess if I could sum this up is that this probably won't be the best game you have ever played....or even the best game in the "SMT blanket series". But it doesn't leave a bad taste. It is enjoyable...it might not be the most amazingly detailed game ever, but neither is my favorite game of all time. 

Persona is over 25 years old and I will still play it today. Would I still play this 25 years in the future? 

I think I would. And that by itself says a whole lot....

125092541.review:
Soul Hackers 2 is a very good follow-up to the first Soul Hackers. It carries forward similar themes relating to technology, as well as adding its own things to the mix. The characters are downright amazing, forming (in my opinion) the best SMT cast. The music is wonderful, composed by the same person as the Nier series, and the anime looking style is done really well in 3D, probably the best I've seen. The plot as well is wonderful and has ample emotion and suspense throughout.

The game isn't perfect however. While the combat is good, it is a tad simplistic compared to main-line SMT, though if you're coming over from Persona then it'll provide some good tactical challenge. The dungeons for the most part are not very good, especially the soul matrices. Despite these gripes, I would argue that combat gets very fun once you get in the swing of things, and as a time waster while watching something, the soul matrices are quite relaxing.

Despite the downfalls of the game, I would still rank it extremely highly, as the positives far outweigh the negatives. Definitely something you should check out if you're a fan of Megaten, or RPGs in general.

124806568.review:
A handful of flaws, but a solid game otherwise. 7/10.
If you go into this game with the lens of it's not gonna be as great as mainline SMT or Persona, it's actually quite fun. I loved the characters, thought the camera work and animation were wonderful (on top of the fact that, according to what I've seen, this is the first game where ATLUS ACTUALLY ANIMATED ENGLISH LIP SYNCING, HELL FREAKING YES), enjoyed the combat (though some of it needs work, namely enemy balance and the amount of grinding you need to to), and the story was nice and had plenty of good writing in it.
HOWEVER
It is far from glorious. Some of the dungeons (especially in the endgame) are horribly designed and made me legit look up a guide just to navigate through them, which for basic map design with zero puzzles should not happen. The game forces you to grind a lot, which is thankfully easier to do with the character Axes areas, but it's still a drag. And I played this game before they released the QoL update, which took over TWO MONTHS to come out and adds damn near necessities for a JRPG, like a freaking RUN BUTTON.
It's not perfect, no game is. It has its flaws, major and minor. But the people who say it's the worst thing ever are very much exaggerating it. I enjoyed the game as a fresh, new experience, using the demons I loved from SMT and the gameplay design of ATLUS I've known for years. I think it could've been great, but some of the decisions they made regarding endgame stuff and the flow not really having a hook to it (I lost motivation to play this game 4 times over the course of 2 months, most good games I finish I only lose motivation to do so one time, if at all) shot the game down in the end. Again, it's still good, but could be a whooooole lot better.

124133272.review:
Spoiler Free review.
Let's be honest no one here has played the original soul hackers game and no one cares. What people care about is a good JRPG with great dungeons and even greater story. Sadly this ain't it chief. Soul hackers 2 is plagued by a predictable story, boring lazy dungeons that frankly just waste your time, static characters, and Cash grab DLC. The only saving grace of this game is the amazing characters designs and well built world, But you don't really get to explore the world so it doesn't matter. This game is pure cash grab that felt like there was some sense of passion earlier but quickly muddled by the need for money. If you had high hopes for this game like me, or was hoping for another amazing JRPG by Atlus, boy are you ready to be absolutely disappointed. So lets break open this baby.

Dungeons and Gameplay
The dungeons in this game are literally walking simulators with enemy encounters. If you thought death stranding was a boring walking sim, this is worse. Dungeons all look the same, either some sort of subway or the matrix. There is only 1 dungeon that's even some what appealing to look at and its the final dungeon. To be honest these dungeons are worse than P4. Large areas with loops and turns that take forever to get through and ringo walks like a slow ass grandma, yeah i fell asleep while exploring the dungeons. Puzzle don't seem to exist in the world of soul hackers because every dungeon is the same walking sim bull shit. What's worse is there's a section of a dungeon that becomes random encounters while not being able to see shit because camera controls are limited. enough is enough and i've said enough about these horrible dungeons, Battles and encounters on the other hand aren't that bad. It's your typical smt/persona TB battle system. Target weaknesses apply debuffs and buffs. The sabbath system, while a bit simple is really fun. Finding demons with unique sabbath only abilities is always fun. Commander skills feel a bit overpowered at times but being OP is fun. Difficulty doesn't really exist in this game. It's overall a very easy game with some systems that let you feel OP. The one Negative about battles is probably ruin. instead of having abilities that do specific debuffs, ruin abilities do damage while applying debuffs. Ruin kinda breaks the balancing of all area's excluding bosses(Bosses are usually resistant to ruin all together). So gameplay is fun.

Story and Characters
since this is spoiler free i'm just gonna keep this section short. The story is predictable, BUT NOT BORING just predictable. Some aspects of the story don't make sense and character development is weak. some characters are ruined by events in the game and i don't like it. Saizo is the only saving grace of this game. The character I thought i'd absolutely hate is the most dynamic character. Most of the characters in this game are fairly static till the the last few hours of the game, and the ending feels rushed. Overall its a mediocre story about human emotion and the characters are fairly static till the last hour. Also the ending feels rushed and pacing is all over the place, like all JRPG's.

Conclusion
I don't have to tell you that the world of this game is amazing. I don't have to tell you that the character designs are amazing. That's probably why you're here. The overall game isn't that great. The dungeons are just walking sims with rpg battles, and the story is a weak one with static characters. Don't play this game.
