124005845.review:
Feel like putting this out right now while I'm still finishing up my playthrough, probably postponing it till the upcoming QoL patch but I feel like there's stuff that needs to be said before then:

[b]Good[/b]
[list]
[*] The cast is amazing, you get to learn about them naturally and they all get their own development that is independent from Ringo intervening and they feel very realistic like real people and are overall really fun. Doing their side content (hangouts and soul matrix) even gives extra information and background about the antagonists which makes them feel more like characters than typical big bads.

[*] Combat. Didn't know if I liked sabbaths over press turns or one more system at first but honestly it feels really nice and unique. The progression in strength is very apparent and satisfying though a bit slow

[*] Boss fights are great. They felt really weird at first but once they clicked they were pretty fun and creative

[*] OST, there aren't many as far as I've found but whatever OST the game does have is great. I remember almost every track in the game and they live in my head rent free. A real shame that there weren't more tracks though.

[*] Aesthetics. Honestly, Atlus has been killing it in the aesthetic game ever since Persona 5, and this games no exception.  Everything exudes charm and looks extremely nice and polished. 

[*] Story is nice, I honestly never felt bored of the story so far (I'm currently just after Ozaki Hope Tower). Lots of character moments and growth alongside twists that I personally didn't see coming. The game tries to be darker in tone while also being somewhat lighthearted. It knows when to joke and when to be serious, though it doesn't go too far into the darker tones. 
[/list]

[b]Meh[/b]
[list]
[*] Demon recon is alright, nothing bad but doesn't do well in trying to replace demon negotiations. They needed smth better to actually replace it and sadly recon falls kinda short.  Otherwise, the mechanic is honestly just glorified chests. I feel like a lot of people hate on it a bit too much considering what they actually are

[*] Dungeons are alright. I personally don't mind them, after so many gimmicks in tons of dungeons in other SMT/Persona games it's nice to just have straightforward dungeons. Dungeons still do have some gimmicks, usually enough to mix it up but not enough to get too annoying (except for the tp puzzles in fucking soul matrix 3F). Honestly didn't feel like it was as bad or even worse than smth like Tartarus from P3 but the lack of varied OST doesn't help the dungeons. They also feel way too large, especially with the lack of proper sprinting before the QoL update. The quality is passable till near the very end when you have to deal with Soul Matrix 4F and the Sea level, those specific dungeons are just badly designed
[/list]

[b]Bad[/b]
[list]
[*] Mechanics are introduced way too late, some of these will be nulled by the patch coming in Nov but since I mostly played in the launch version I feel the need to mention them

[list]
[*] Assassin's step (a speed boost that lasts a short distance) is only gotten like maybe 7 to 10 hours in if you're lucky and know where to get it. This makes a lot of dungeons drag on for way too long until you get this skill. Even after getting it some dungeons can drag on for way too long. Once dedicated free sprinting arrives in the upcoming patch, this will become a non-issue but since it'll be a few weeks to a month till then as of writing the review this is a huge issue.

[*] Active commander skills, mainly conversion. Without it the combat feels very annoying as you can't change demons mid combat without it yet won't get it till at least 3 or 4 hours into the game. It would feel much better if it was introduced earlier alongside the COMP smith or when the first soul matrix is introduced but not enough to make the game too annoying early on.
[/list]

[*] Soul matrix dungeons are WAY too long, especially early on. IMO the soul matrix dungeons should be quick in and out sections that allows you to power up without making u stray from the main game for too long, but sadly the soul matrix takes maybe 30 minutes to an hour AFTER you gain the ability to run but before that they can last for more than an hour which I feel is way too long

[*] The game seems to be a bit too obsessed with Almighty boss signature moves. Which isn't really bad... it just feels very annoying at times when you're fighting a boss and they pull out their almighty attack and you can't do nothing bout it but lose a character or take massive damage based on your luck and stats.

[*] For some reason if you show beginner tips in the load screens the game takes much longer to load even if you're on an NVMe so if you want faster load times turn those off and you load way faster!

[*] Game is really short for its price and considering the fact that this game has no regional pricing like most Atlus titles it hampers the enjoyment for people like me who could get maybe 3-4 decent games at the same price
[/list]

[b]Verdict[/b]
Overall, aside from the trash day 1 DLC that Atlus pushed out, the game itself isn't bad. The game is just... different. I was one of the people who pretty much knew as soon as the trailer dropped that this ain't gonna be Soul Hackers part 2, or SMT or even Persona. It really felt like they were trying to be different but chose an existing name to use for some reason when it barely connects. If you ignore the fact this game is called "Soul Hackers 2" there's a lot that can be enjoyed here, but... 

[h1]While I'm giving a recommend on this game I highly suggest waiting for the upcoming patch before getting this game and wait for a sale[/h1]

Overall the game is a solid 8/10. It's not lifechanging but is much better than all the doomsayers that gave the game a 55% mixed rating on Steam. The game feels very persona 2-esque with characters developing with or without the interference of the main character and everyone's ability to use any demons with some caveats so if you enjoyed Persona 2 specifically then this game may be right up your alley.

I wouldn't say that the game feels rushed, it just has some weird design flaws that are thankfully going to be fixed with the upcoming patch. Overall, while I agree that the game has flaws in many aspects: dungeon design, QoL and the shitty day one DLC, the game still does tons of good despite all this. Hopefully a lot of the negativity dies down once they release the QoL patch (expecting them to make the DLC be free/cheaper is pretty unrealistic but will also help a lot).

123898870.review:
Way overpriced. The story is clichéd. Dungeons rely on multiple back and forth travelling to get "keys" or events to unlock inorder to proceed to the next floor. Characters' backstories feel lacklustre even though there are lot of "hangout events". True ending requires a specific condition to be met, for which players need to plan way ahead, or try again in subsequent playthroughs. Combat system is a little different compared to Persona series - you do not get additional turns if when you hit the enemy's weakness. Instead there is a "stack mechanism" which adds on for a cumulative attack at the end of the party's turn. This can be further upgraded or modified with different perks that you can unlock.
There is a system called "soul matrix" which acts like a dungeon to train and upgarde your characters, but the high number of puzzles takes the fun out of it and makes it only a mind numbing grind-fest.

In short, there are different mechanisms compared to Persona series (obviously) but they feel designed to deliver quantity rather than quality. I would recommen buying this at 50-60% discount.

123706267.review:
It's a shame this game's catching so much venom!

From my perspective, as a willing supporter of those who create and publish works like this, Soul Hackers 2 is a slick, fresh, modern take on the long running Shin Megami Tensei / Persona Universe. The characters are compelling, the Japanese voice acting is superb, the localization has done a fine job with the challenges faced by translators. The art work and style are excellent, consistent, and well-used in conveying the tricky bits involved in AI personalities interacting with Human Beings.

Any experience you've had with all those previous games in the SMT/P series carries over well into finding your way around this piece of world building. And yet, remarkably, it feels fresh. Well done, authors, artists, and Atlus! My own time with SMT goes back to the PS Vita and Nintendo products of that era. I'm thoroughly enjoying this game! 

One thing I've noticed with this particular battle system; in many turn-based team battle settings it often feels optimal for your team members to gang up on opposing targets, eliminating them one by one - for each one quickly eliminated, that's one less source of incoming fire.

Not so here! Instead, it seems to be preferable to spread the damage across as many in the enemy group as possible, to bring their HP count down across the board, so that when Ringo lets go with a Stack Attack you can wipe out multiple targets in one swipe. Very interesting. Battles in Soul Hackers 2 take on a completely different dynamic from a lot of other turn-based battle system games. It feels fresh and interesting.

Now, there are technical aspects to the Denuvo Digital Rights Management (DRM) solution that some folks object to as a matter, to them, of principle. Perhaps they feel they should have the right to copy and redistribute software freely, despite that specifically being prohibited by the Terms of Use they've agreed to by installing and starting the software. What we purchase is not the software, but the limited and specific rights to use it, under license. Copyright laws vary by nation but are established with consistent intent to protect the rights of authors and publishers of creative works. Those rights are not cancelled simply because someone doesn't agree with them, any more than your right to speak would be cancelled if I didn't agree with you.

Like the game? Want to try the game? Buy the game. if you're offended by the DRM implementation, then return the game under Valve's Terms of Use and get your refund. But please don't tear down or trash-talk a game or a game publisher simply because they've taken steps to protect their rights to a creative work.

Does this trash-talking happen to every game that employs Denuvo DRM? If so, that's an injustice against the authors and artists. And while we're at it, the level of piracy in the present world is a plague upon any creative house trying to produce and publish copyrighted work in a sustainable way. Want less noxious DRM? Stop downloading copyrighted works from piracy sites.

And none of this has any bearing on the merits of this work as a game. I've been enjoying it very much, and feel anyone who's enjoyed previous excursions into this universe will probably enjoy this one as well!

So thanks again, authors, artists, composers, musicians, and publishers! My life is enriched by your creative efforts, and I'm glad to support them!

Addin, now at  65 game-hours,,,
Still a strong recommend for this one! I'm actually playing it in parallel with Persona 4, 5, and Soul Hackers 1 on the 3DS. It's turning into quite the late Autumn/early Winter binge here, and I'm thoroughly enjoying it!

Some folks say the Soul Matrix levels are tedious, or overly plain: Bah! Look at them on a decent monitor, they're a nice rendering of the idea of a synthetic reality - and their design from a game architecture standpoint is just fine. The stairs come along when they need to, the gates are well-placed, the story-reveals are meaningful and significant, if you just let the story do its thing on you; there's really no problem here.

So in sum, at this stage, this is a game that belongs in the SMT Universe. 

There's room in the world for Golf, Croquet, and Frisbee Golf, too!

123618952.review:
If you haven't played an SMT or Persona game, this is not the place to start.

That said, it's actually a pretty good RPG in my opinion. It's a surprisingly good sequel to Soul Hackers 1 too, which is one of my favorite RPGs. I wasn't sure what to expect at first, as the preview trailers didn't remind me much of the first game and the game wasn't a first person DRPG like the original. They actually nailed the tone and atmosphere pretty well somehow though, and there are a lot of similarities to the first game that really solidify it as a proper sequel.

I enjoyed the game, but depending on your expectations you might not enjoy it as much.
[list]
[*] Ringo is an amazing protagonist. She provides the same sassy attitude that Nemissa did in the first game. I hope future Megaten games have voiced protagonists because it worked really well here.
[*] Unlike a lot of recent SMT games, the combat doesn't use the press turn system. I found the change refreshing, but I can understand why some players were disappointed. The systems here are pretty fun but notably less punishing than press turn combat.
[*] Hard difficulty felt like it should've been called normal difficulty for most of the game. Towards the end it felt perfectly balanced, though. I'd recommend playing on Hard if you've completed any other game in this franchise.
[*] The pace of the story is fairly slow. I enjoyed this, actually.
[*] The pace of the gameplay can feel tedious by modern standards. Battle animations, movement speed etc. start to feel too slow after a while. It's on par with what you'd find in some PS2 games. I wasn't bothered by this much until Soul Matrix 4F took me way too long. Atlus has announced an upcoming patch to address these issues.
[*] The soundtrack is really nice, subdued but catchy and very reminiscent of the first game.
[*] Performance is very good with very high framerates. Unfortunately you'll want to cap at 60 FPS because Ringo's movement goes too wonky at anything higher.
[*] Visually, the game is a mixed bag. Some areas feel unnaturally vacant and clearly didn't get enough attention. One of the mid-game dungeons looks straight out of a PS Vita game. The 2D assets all look great.
[*] The dungeon the DLC questline concludes in is a bit of a joke (not sure if the dungeon itself is DLC). Despite using unique assets, the entire dungeon is the same room repeated about 20 times.
[*] Linux/Steam Deck support isn't there currently. The game runs well on my Linux desktop but missing some visual effects. Steam Deck has more severe issues with audio playback.
[/list]

The current mixed rating is pretty harsh, but not entirely undeserved. The DLC situation is pretty inexcusable and I hope Atlus isn't quite so brazen next time. 

The game itself is pretty solid, despite the lack of polish in some areas. I think it's a great sequel, all things considered. Most of the issues/shortcomings can be chalked up to the development team working with an unfamiliar engine, and maybe some unrealistic player expectations. I would cautiously recommend this game, but not as an introduction to this amazing series.

123608843.review: Honestly, if you like Shin Megami Tensei games you will love Soul Hackers 2. Puts a fun spin onto the persona formula that most people know and love at this point. The characters are fun along side a cool twist of bringing the dead back to life. Can't wait to see what demons in this game makes it into Persona 6!

123603540.review:
[b] TL;DR [/b] I think this is a great game and is very much worth buying. Not for kids unless they are older and pretty jaded. Gameplay is Persona and SMT style and very enjoyable. Some of the DLC is good, but it is not must buy and with the exception of the cosmetics, can be attained in game. 

[b][u]Rating[/u][/b]
The game is rated Mature for violence, partial nudity, strong language, and blood and gore. The violence is characters laying in pools of blood, a character getting impaled through the chest, and a dismembered body part. There are scenes with on of the main characters with no clothing covered with a sheet, and scantily clad female demons. One of the demons is a phallic H.R. Geiger-esque monster. They drop the F-bomb and other words in the game as well. Lastly you do summon and contract demons in the game. They are based on all of the current and past mythologies of the world. 

[b][u]Controls: [/u][/b]
In towns and dungeons you have the freedom to run around and interact like most modern JRPGs, and inn dungeons you have a diablo-esque overlay map. Random encounters pop up on the map, and you can "slice" them to avoid the encounter, which is a feature that is very nice. There are also checkpoints, or gates, in the dungeon that allow fast travel to various points in the dungeon. The battle menu has the Persona feel, meaning every action is linked to a button rather than choosing from a menu. The enemies (and you) have resistances and weaknesses that you can exploit to do massive damage, and add stacks for an end of round attack called a "Sabbath" that attacks with the demons the character that exploited the weakness summoned and does pretty good damage to all enemies. 

[b][u]DLC:[/u][/b]
Let's begin with saying that the DLC is absolutely not necessary. In fact, I daresay play the game through without it and then get the DLC. I willl break down the DLCs and what they add to the game: 

[b]Boost Item Pack:[/b] This gives you the ability to turn on items that boost your stats and abilities in the game. After you turn them on in the gameplay menu, you get items that sell at a high price to the vendors, Items that allow you to buy stat raising items from a vendor, and items that each one boosts you a level and ove that boosts your demons a level. You get one of each of these items after you defeat an enemy in combat. 

[b]Bonus Story Arc[/b] This gives you access to a new [b]non-playable[/b] summoner, and an extra dungeon and an extremely difficult boss fight. The Story is pretty good, and the dungeon is enjoyable, and the boss fight will rock your world. Definitely wait until you have mastered the game for this one. 

[b]Demon Pack[/b] This will add 8 [i]powerful[/i] demons to the compendium, once you unlock it. You will be able to summon them for free the first time, and they are stupidly powerful. This and the boost item pack has the potential to make the game too easy on normal difficulty, unless you fight a risky enemy. 

[b]Costume and BGM pack[/b] adds costumes from Persona 4 and 5, SMT4, Soul Hackers 1, Devil Summoner, and swimsuits. It also adds a BGM that you can change in the menu. Get it if you are into that kind of thing, but this one is definitely skippable. 

[b]Useful Item Set & Extra Difficulty:[/b] This one give you 2 of a few items that will help out in the beginning of the game, most notably original flames  which will prevent a wipe on normal difficulty. This is assuredly not a must have, and the extra difficulty is only if you want a challenge beyond hard. The bonus is that as of the time of this review, it is free. 

[b]Final thoughts:[/b] I have thoroughly enjoyed this game and will wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone. I love the controls and the battle system, though the dungeons can be a little grindy. the ability to avoid battles and the gate system mitigates that a bit. I think this is a great addition to the SMT universe.

123470828.review:
I was very excited and hopeful for Soul Hackers 2 since it was the first time in a long time we got a brand new Shin Megami Tensei series spinoff, and could be the title that would bring forth new / revive some old SMT subseries. While the game is good in some aspects, it's tainted by some very glaring cons that make it a drag to play at points. It's hard to give it a positive rating, so I'm going to say I'm very mixed. Here's why: 

The game itself visually looks well with the vibrant color palette and character designs, especially Ringo and Figue who serve as the main character and sidekick, who look very well done with the cyberpunk-ish look and style.

This game's cast, which is an adult cast this time around instead of younger teenagers like the Persona series, is a good bunch with their own distinct backgrounds, personalities, motives, etc. Each character is perfectly fine, and I had no complaints on how they handled them. It's not one I would vaguely remember many years from now, but they were an interesting bunch. The main character Ringo, she is easily the best part of this game. They actually went with a protagonist who isn't silent this time around, and I hope it's not the last time due to this games' mixed reception. She was very like-able from the beginning, and is easily the best character by a landslide.

The story itself was alright as well, with the different side characters this game offers and events. The antagonists were very bland though IMO and weren't nothing to write home about. I will throw in a big con about the story however here. The biggest gut punch about party's backstories (Arrow, Milady & Saizo) if you want to learn them, you have to go through the 'Soul Matrix', which is the most bland and uninspired dungeon I have probably ever witnessed in an JRPG. More on this later on exploration. 

Now time for the points I am either mixed on, or very much despise about the game: 

The combat itself at first is okay, the sabbath system is essentially the "All-Out Attacks" from the Persona series, except some demons can acquire skills called "sabbath skills", that usually tack on extra damage or ailments to the enemy. The skill variety is what you can expect from an SMT game, but certain demons have their own unique skills that are just not in the game at all. The biggest one being Yoshitsune, who's unique skill is 'Hassou Tobi' which is a big part of why he is a sought after demon to recruit/fuse, is just not there. This was a slap in the face when I realized this, and is very jarring since we just got SMT V less than a year ago and these skills including that one are all there in that game? The combat after a while becomes a cake walk, especially since it isn't the press turn system and you can hit enemies that resist/null certain affinities and not get penalized for it. The COMP skills however, I can say I thought was a good addition and made it a bit more interesting and made you want to go after since they can increase damage and affinities which are huge to have for later. 

The OST is nothing too special, certainly not even close to touching Shoji Meguro or Ryota Kozuka works by any means, but it was fine. They let MONACA, who have made the music for the Nier series, handle the soundtrack instead and while there are some tracks that are good, they aren't any that would stand out that I would listen to over time after playing. The best piece I would say is the game's main theme "Hopeless Call". I wouldn't say there are any BAD battle themes, they are all decent but not too memorable like mentioned. 

Now finally for the exploration / dungeon layout - which is BY FAR the WORST part of this game. The dungeons are very linear and get to be a drag to get through, especially since there isn't a dedicated DASH BUTTON. A bit later on, you start to acquire these skills called "Map Skills", which can make these more bearable but still a chore since you spend a bit of MP to activate them and have to constantly refresh them. One of these skills is "Assassin's Footsteps" I believe it's called which served as this game's run button for dungeons / open areas, which runs out after a short while and costs 10 MP each time to use. Why would this be locked behind a skill for crying out loud? Persona 5 had a dash button for dungeons and that game came out years before this. At the time of me typing this, they announced on October 3rd 2022 they are releasing a patch for the game that adds a dash button and other fixes that will be released sometime in November I believe. I can respect them for at least going back to correct it, but it's too late for many who have already played it and moved on, myself included. 

The demon negotiating, which is a big staple of the franchise, has been completely watered down here. Within dungeons you send out the demons in your current stock to "recon" the area, which they usually turn up with an item either for restorative purposes or for a quest, or just straight up restore your HP/MP. It's completely randomized, and these recon demons are also how you recruit new demons to your party. Again, it's COMPLETELY randomized which demon it selects, but it usually is according to the current dungeon difficulty/level. The thing is, instead of the demon asking you questions unique to itself, as well as asking for either Macca or items, it only asks for either ONE item or Macca and it joins you simple as that. Recruiting this way that's completely randomized as well as brain dead frankly was very uninteresting. 

Continuing from my last point about dungeon layouts... The 'Soul Matrix' I mentioned earlier, which is required to go through for the main story to an extent, but further if you want to learn more about the party members, is the main culprit with awfully linear and repetitive these dungeons can be. Each floor for each character looks the EXACT SAME, but are laid out differently and end up getting more complex with random warps and such as you progress further up. These are so bad that I started to believe they were auto generated with how straight forward and boring these got. This itself is the biggest con of the game for myself and many others I can see. 

And to wrap it up, this game brings back more "Day 1 DLC", similar to the sort SMT V had, but it is infinitely worse here. The biggest part of being an ENTIRE SEPARATE STORY ARC locked behind it. The game itself it pretty short for an SMT title, so why would they cut this out and not leave it in to add some more depth and side quests, when the side quests in this game for the most part are just fetching something and skipping dialogue just to get to the reward? The DLC also includes bonus demons as well, including Satan and Mara. The other two are costume packs and booster items, which are okay and should've been the only two. The costume packs are different outfits for the party you will recognize from older Megaten titles, and include some unique music tracks depending on which you wear. You cannot see these costumes outside of battle however. I own the DLC, which I regret greatly after playing. I went and spent my time getting all the achievements the game has to offer to get my moneys worth at least. 

If you are interested in buying the game as a Megaten series fan, or even just a fan of JRPGs, please wait until this game is discounted to AT LEAST half off. Looks like it's currently at $45 USD at the time of my review, and the highest tier, the "Digital Premium" edition listed at $58.49 instead of $90 USD retail. At least the highest tier which includes everything is under $60, but it's still not worth it even for that price.

123426562.review:
Soul Hackers 2 is a pretty good entry into the ever expanding library of the SMT series. It'd definitely following the trend of becoming more "Persona" than previous SMT games, but still manages to deliver a worthwhile experience.

First off, and the biggest draw of the game to me, the characters. Most of the time, SMT doesn't really focus on its cast, they serve their purpose, and have their quirks to them, but generally, SMT is about the gameplay. Soul Hackers 2 is not like that. While the non-essential story characters are incredibly flat and forgettable, the core party and those close to them are incredibly memorable and fun to watch. The chemistry between Ringo, Arrow, Milady, and Saizo works really well, and every scene they're in is a joy to watch. The story is more interesting than your standard apocalypse scenario because of how well the characters are all written, and it makes you feel for everyone on all sides. It's hard to make all of your characters likeable like this, and you can tell a lot of effort went into making the cast a lot more three dimensional than your standard SMT cast. 

However, the writing only gets you so far in an RPG like this, hows the gameplay? Well, its definitely a lot more simple than most other Atlus RPGs, this isn't too terrible, and allows the game to be a lot more accessible to new players, but if you're a hardcore SMT gatekeeper, you'll likely be disappointed. The move pool is drastically smaller than even Persona's, and demon move slots are limited to 6. Fusion is super streamlined, similarly to SMT V, with compendium fusions being carried over, reducing the tedium of filling out the compendium again. Dungeon exploration is standard enough, with one major problem. At the time of writing my original review, RINGO WAS SLOW AS FUCK. They mercifully added a run button a few months after the game released, and while I'm sure its a nice quality of life booster, it doesn't save the frankly boring and generic levels. With the exception of the FINAL AREA, the levels are the same 3 recycled subways, office buildings, and blank voids repeated over and over and over again, making it a huge drag to get from one story beat to the next. I really like the story here, but I'm not going to lie, some of the mid points made it really hard to continue. Luckily, these dungeons tend to be short, but with them composing most of the game, and feeling twice as long with the lack of anything interesting, they are definitely the games biggest weakness.

Now, lets say you've read my little textwall, and the game sounds interesting to you. As you scroll back up to the buy button, you might notice this game has a lot of DLC. Now you're thinking "Hmm... should I buy the deluxe edition???"

No.

The DLC is a total waste of money. At best, you get a couple side missions that are a nice distraction from the main game for a little bit, and at worst you're spending an addition 50% of the main game's cost to completely ruin the game by instantly being able to hit level 99 with infinite money, and getting a couple neat (but totally useless) costumes. If this is like your favorite game ever and you just really wanna show your love for it, go for it I guess? But really, these are nothing more than a scummy attempt to scrape more money away from you by ripping content from the game day one that really has no business being DLC to begin with.

Overall? I had a good time with Soul Hackers 2. The gameplay is pretty lacking for an SMT game, and the DLC is pretty lame, but the characters and story are such a great time, and the general aesthetic being so appealing and easy to get sucked into, that it almost carries the rest of the games weakpoints. I think this makes a great first SMT game, especially if you're looking something closer to Persona. If you're a bit more of an SMT veteran, this may be a bit harder of a sell. If the story looks cool, or you just wanna see everything this series has to offer, it's far from a terrible game, but other games in this series significantly outshine it. 6/10.

123393794.review:
As far as I’m concerned, it always feels like a special occasion when an Atlus JRPG comes out on PC as I really like their [i]Megami Tensei[/i] franchise. With that said, I’ve never had the chance to play any of the titles in the [i]Devil Summoner[/i] line, so basically [i]Soul Hackers 2[/i] was kind of an entry point for me.

In general, I wasn’t disappointed, although it would feel more appropriate to give this one a so-so hand sign instead of a thumbs up if it was available. The whole time it felt like I was somewhere halfway between the [i]Persona[/i] and [i]Shin Megami Tensei[/i] games I’ve had the chance to play so far, in a sense that the story, the characters and the art style was closer to the former, whereas the dungeons and actual gameplay reminded me of the latter. The turn-based battle system is more or less as you would expect if you’re familiar with any of the aforementioned series, focusing on using demons and exploiting element weaknesses. It’s fun, but still, I would have loved a bit more innovation here to shake things up sometimes, at least during boss fights. Also, be prepared for a loooot of running around in similar-looking, monotonous corridors and subway tunnels… Unfortunately, there’s not much variety when it comes to level designs, which is a shame.

What I genuinely loved, however, were the characters, especially the protagonist, who is not a mute, blank slate that requires others to communicate for her, which is quite often the case in these games. Between battles and cutscenes you also have a chance to get to know your party members better, but don’t expect as much social interaction between them as in [i]Persona[/i]. And, of course, we also have the Demon Compendium, the absolute essential part of any title in the franchise, so catch and fuse ‘em all, if you can, I guess.

All in all, I didn’t regret the time I spent with [i]Soul Hackers 2[/i], even if its content feels much lighter than what I expected. There’s just not enough of anything, but what we have is OK. Nothing to write home about, though.

123379990.review:
[h1]TL;DR I personally recommend Soul Hackers 2 if you see it on sale.[/h1]
If you can get this game at a decent price then I can comfortably say you're in for an experience that, while somewhat flawed, is still very much worth your time.

There are a few things that I must address before going in-depth:
While I didn't encounter any bugs or glitches, myself, [b]the default settings create some odd optimization issues with this game. The odd part is that they can be fixed through some configuring.[/b] Atlus announced there is a patch to add some general fixes and QoL updates coming in the near future, so these issues may be fixed by then. I did the following for the best personal experience:
-Under "Loading Screen Tips" set it to either "Hide" or "Button Advance". For whatever reason this shortens load screen times drastically.
-Lock the frame rate to 60fps, as apparently higher/uncapped rates can break some animations.
-Adjust the camera settings so Ringo is focused in the center and the camera zoom is further away.
-Lower analogue stick sensitivity, as Ringo can be a little slippery to control.

[h1]Now for the main review[/h1]
Soul Hackers 2 is a game I can say I personally enjoyed, but I can completely understand why others may be underwhelmed or disappointed by the final product. The fact that the first Soul Hackers is such a cult classic among RPG fans may also play a role in this game's mixed reception. As far as Shin Megami Tensei games go, it is a very mellow experience that has a lot of the pieces the series is known for but doesn't necessarily go very far with them, and as a result the game lacks the sense of scope that players familiar with the series may come to expect.

If there's one thing I'm certain Soul Hackers 2 does very well, it's the presentation. The game is incredibly stylish and beautiful with its futuristic city environments, character designs, UI and VFX, as one would expect from a modern SMT/Atlus title. The music is also great with the Opening Theme, Weapons Shop, and the multiple Battle Themes being the highlights for me. The voice cast is also full of very solid performances. Outside of looking and sounding great, it's the rest of the game, itself where one's mileage may vary.

[b]Writing[/b]
As far as writing goes, I found the interactions among the main cast to be very enjoyable. Each party member is well fleshed out and they play off of each other very well, with Ringo and Saizo being my personal favourites. The other major characters also have some good interactions with them as well when it's their turn in the spotlight. The actual story, though, is rather lacking as far as JRPGs go. It has the pieces there to be something great, and there are a lot of compelling elements, themes, and interesting ideas that SMT is known for, however it feels like for most of the game that the story progresses just for the sake of moving the plot along.
For most of the game I was more compelled to see the interactions between party members and piecing together each of their backstories and how they weave together, rather than being attached to the main plot. It was only really after the major twist regarding the main antagonist that I began to feel like things were really picking up and felt engaged to continue the story, and that's roughly three quarters into the game. Fortunately I do believe the game had a satisfying enough finale and a great final boss to go with it.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
The other thing that I feel a lot of people will be hit or miss on is the gameplay. Soul Hackers 2 is, in all intents and purposes, a Megami Tensei game, but it's a relatively simple Megami Tensei game. The core gameplay loop that makes SMT so addictive is all there: you explore dungeons to recruit demons, and eventually fuse those demons together to create stronger demons, allowing you to explore more dangerous dungeons. The battle system also features the series' trademark affinity system, with each demon/enemy having their own strengths and weaknesses against the different damage types in the game. It's one of personal favourite systems as far as turn-based RPGs go.
On top of these staple features, battles in Soul Hackers 2 features the addition of the "Stack" system. On top of dealing bonus damage, attacking an enemy with their weakness grants a Stack. At the end of the player's turn Ringo performs an AoE attack and deals damage based on the amount of stacks gained during their turn. It's a very simple system, though in comparison to other battle mechanics present in other SMT games, it can feel rather shallow by comparison. Even as you progress through the game and gradually unlock more perks and abilities, the Stack system doesn't provide as much strategy to battles as the "Press Turn" system in mainline SMT or the "One More" system in Persona.

[b]Dungeons[/b]
While the battle system can feel hit-or-miss based on your preferences, the layout and dungeon design is probably the game's lowest point in nearly every aspect. While not necessarily bad (for the most part) they are considerably boring. Dungeons in Soul Hackers 2 go back to the maze-like hallway design of older RPGs and don't really bring anything interesting to the table. Compared to other recent entries in the series like SMT V's sprawling environments and Persona 5's unique palaces, it leaves a lot to be desired
It also doesn't help that the environments are rather bland. The Soul Matrix, the area where you will likely spend most of your time leveling up and grinding, features 15 different floors, each one with the exact same music and background visuals (not even a change in colour scheme) and it gets very samey, very quick. The main story dungeons don't fare much better either, as they all boil down to the same idea of "abandoned urban environment" (two of which are abandoned subway lines) and all share the same music track, which detracts from giving each one their own sense of identity. The only exception is the final dungeon, which feels very distinct and interesting and features a unique music track that adds a lot to the atmosphere.

[b]Summary[/b]
All in all, the best way I can describe Soul Hackers 2 is that it's a very good game to introduce newcomers to Megami Tensei as a series. It features all the core elements and gameplay loop in a way that's easy to get the gist of. It isn't brutally difficult like Mainline SMT, and it isn't a massive time sink like Persona. It's just enough to give players a taste of everything this truly unique franchise of RPGs has to offer. That being said, do I recommend getting this game at full price? No, not really. I would still say wait until it goes on sale for like half off. If you can get this game at a decent price then I can comfortably say you're in for an experience that, while somewhat flawed, is still very much worth your time.

123192238.review:
I did a blind buy of this on release day. You win some, you lose some. And this time I lost some. I wouldn't recommend this. I got almost every achievement so here's my two cents.

The long and the short of it: The best part of this game is basically the art style, characters, voice work, and the weapon shop and Mansei Realm music slaps! ...otherwise the music is a mixed bag. The story is unremarkable, but has a few twists to be enjoyable. Boss fights on hard mode are challenging and satisfying to beat. Speaking of boss fights the primary mechanic in this game, the sabbath attack, is actually still relevant during boss fights instead of completely thrown out like in the Persona games. While the worst of it was the extremely boring dungeon settings and design.

The main protagonist Ringo is surprising charming and silly. The artwork had me thinking she'd be a cold leader type and since she's some kind of robot/AI/android, so I figured they might've leaned into that kind of trope. Then Saizo I thought seemed too tropey from the artwork, but I ended up liking him the most, besides Ringo, with how he developed. Because the voice work is done by proven talents, the characters come to life and their banter is enough to keep me going through these long dark endless hallways.

The game's basic story premise you can read in this game's description page never really develops beyond that. Despite that there are some twists and turns towards the second half of the story. Even Saizo acknowledges the amount of twists at this point in the game. With that said, the story is nothing to write home about, but it has its moments and I enjoyed it enough.

The gameplay loop essentially boils down to crawling these massive boring dungeons, getting to a checkpoint and leaving to rest, upgrade or do a hangout. Which to me is immersion  breaking because the game sets things in the main story thread to be urgent, but it feels weird to leave the dungeon to have a beer with your party mates. You just have to suspend disbelief here. Maybe I'm too used to the Persona dungeon and daily life cycle. Speaking of Persona, I fee like the party member hangouts here seem tacked on because of Persona's popularity.

As far as gameplay systems go, the sabbath attack is basically a weaker all-out attack from Persona and hitting weaknesses doesn't stun enemies, but you can stack up the damage and it's actually relevant in boss fights unlike in Persona which is a plus. When you progress in a party member's soul matrix dungeon you learn abilities for them that can affect how these characters can add to the stack. However, it's pretty much on rails. You play the party members as they're designed to be. It's a beginners trap in thinking you can make Ringo a good ice user because her ice bonuses from mistique unlocks never go up that high and she doesn't get stack bonuses from them anyway.

I played the game on hard right from the start and I will praise the game for its tight balancing. Boss fights are challenging and satisfying to beat. The soul matrix quest bosses can be very tricky especially because you often aren't allowed any items or commander skills and have a time limit. I always took these bosses at the recommended level and always eventually found some kind of combo to win. However, since you can, eventually, leave a dungeon and come back at any time and can skip random encounters as you please normal enemies don't pose the threat of attrition on your resources like in other JRPGs. They are just piñatas to beat for loot and XP. This further adds to the monotony of dungeons.

I've been beating up the dungeons in this whole review so let's get to it. By now, many reviews pan this game's bland dungeons and that word really doesn't describe how bad they really are. They are all long dreary corridors with usually nothing of interest to see or do and they all have the same ambient piano track playing for all of them except for the soul matrix dungeons which has its own track that's shared between them.  if you don't mind spoilers all the dungeons are basically: [spoiler]an abandoned subway[/spoiler], [spoiler]an abandoned office tower[/spoiler], and [spoiler]some shipping ports[/spoiler]. This is in stark contrast to the rest of the environments which all share the neon future aesthetic so it really confuses me why they went this direction for the dungeons. Only the final dungeon has any interesting design to it. Now if you played Persona 4, you might be familiar with the long corridor dungeon design, but at least there at each stage of the game it had a different theme and music. Of course if you played and liked Persona 3 then you'll be right at home with the never ending dark corridors!

Now the dungeons do sometimes have a puzzle to solve which helps break up the monotony. One dungeon has doors closing behind you and it was interesting enough to solve. Then a few soul matrix dungeons have a "pick a door" teleporter puzzle where if you pick the wrong one you're punished with being sent backwards and having to walk back to it. Game design nowadays have a lot of padding to prevent people from complaining a game is too short, but this is particularly egregious.

Finally, this game's default camera is awful. I had to adjust the settings multiple times so I can see where I'm going.

Overall, this game is a missed opportunity. It could've used some more time in the oven, but I feel like a resurrected 20+ year old franchise isn't going to get the funds to develop a more fleshed out game. However, if you think you might like the characters in a very anime-ish end-of-the-world story, then I'd recommend playing this on easy/normal and just getting to the story bits ASAP.

It comes across as sterile at points. That being said I do really love this game and feel like you should give it a shot if you are interested in a Cyberpunk JRPG by Atlus. 122950777.review:
You're probably going to regret buying this at full price. I enjoyed the game, quite a bit, and I still regret buying it at full price. It starts off somewhat rocky, but after it lets you off the leash, the game becomes really fun. And then after a while, it just becomes disappointing. Although I have to admit, I was disappointed right at the get-go.

If you were expecting a sequel to Soul Hackers 1, from the words 'Soul Hackers' and the number 2 in the title, then you'll be disappointed. This game owes more to persona 5 than any game in the devil summoner series. Whats the difference you might ask? Devil summoner games are usually first person dungeon crawlers where the player starts out weak and then evolve into a gun toting, sword swinging, demon summoning badass. Soul Hackers 2, meanwhile, is a 3rd person dungeon crawler where you fight demons as a party of 4 unique characters who deepen their friendship over the course of the story. Sound familiar? But that was only the start of my disappointments.

The artstyle of the game is really good. Very pretty, good character designs, the works. The thing about it, though, and it might take you a while to realise this, when it comes to graphics, the game is pretty shit. The environment looks pretty dated, character models don't emote very much, and they recycle almost all of the attack effects. Animation is pretty weak in general in this game, the most notable example being Ringo's walk cycle. It's rather stiff and somewhat awkward, and since she's the main character, this is probably going to end up bothering you a lot.

Voice acting is pretty alright overall. The 4 leads have pretty decent voice acting, but Ringo's voice acting is just a bit off. Most of the time it'll be fine, but there's certain times where the quality dips. And again, since she's the main character, this is going to end up bothering you a lot. Music is alright too, not really any notable tracks.

The gameplay is normal SMT fare, with the notable absence of light and dark instant kill spells. That means that random mobs won't randomly one-shot you, which is nice, I guess, and that's about it as far as gameplay differences go. Dark spells are debuffs, and they also do damage and exploit weaknesses so it's not bad. Building up the 4 characters is also pretty engaging, because the materials you need to upgrade them aren't always found in the same dungeon, so you'll upgrade different affinities at different times. 

You'll never really need to farm if you keep up with axis unlocks. The axis is the main side dungeon, basically, and you clear it out for some pretty nice character buffs. The issue with the axis, though, is that you'll be going there a lot, the scenery never changes, and it's used to pad out the rest of the game. The main issue with Soul Hackers 2 is that it's really not a long game, but it makes itself feel like it's much longer. I have just finished the game with 60 hours, 50% of which was spent in the axis, 25% I spent on loading screens, and probably 25% I spent in the actual story and story dungeons. There's just not a lot of content, and around the halfway mark, you'll notice things repeating themselves. As for the story itself, it's alright. There's a really actually quite solid (if somewhat cliche) twist in the lategame, sandwiched between 1 ok twist and another twist that's pretty poorly built up. The characters are alright and they get more fleshed out over the course of the plot, though they start off pretty one-dimensional. I'd give the story a passing grade, for whatever it's worth, considering you won't interact with it much. Though I should note that I almost didn't bother finishing the game because it was just so samey by the end dungeon, but I figured I might as well have just bitten the bullet.

Overall, this is kind of a disappointing game for something that has the balls to say that it's full price. If you really want to play something like this you might as well just play Persona 4 Golden, which has more content AND a better story, and it's only about a 3rd of what Soul Hackers 2 is selling for. If you really, really, really want to play this, I'd wait for a sale. This isn't really a must-play game, especially considering P5R is coming out on PC in october.

122893169.review:
Balan Wonderworld literally has a higher user rating than this now. 

Is this game really worse than that? Sure the dungeons visually are a mess but the character development, the combat, the story, I think are pretty good, a lot of the themes are very mature and reflect things people go through in real life. There's a few glaring flaws with the dungeons as I mentioned, the walk speed and fusions feeling limited in potential. Combat is also fun with how customization for each of the characters work. It's not a terrible game. If anything I think people had there expectations set on a successor to Persona 5 Royal, if you go into any game, comparing it to another. your almost always going to have a bad time. Soul Hackers 2 is a fun experimental game made as a revival of a 25 year old franchise. It's not trying to surpass Persona 5, or Shin Megami Tensei V, just being it's own thing and try something different, while appealing to older fans of the series. feel free to keep hating it if you want, I enjoyed my time with the game, and I hope whoever reads this found something they liked too.  If you do genuinely hate the game, your opinion is yours to have, and I'm sorry you feel like you wasted your time and money on it.

Personally I liked the complexity of the dungeons, visually they failed i agree, but i liked actually having to "solve" the later dungeons. there's that 'ah-ha!' moment when finally progressing that made them really satisfying to work through. the 1 way door mechanic in the subways felt like a more fleshed out version of what they tried at the end of Shin Megami Tensei V, as well as dungeons from the PersonaQ games, all i ever hear is people hating how complicated the dungeons are. but that's strictly a personal thing, and not a 'flaw' of the game. If the layouts were the same but each of the soul matrix's had unique and striking visuals with there own music and themes would you still hate it? The demons could have also been replaced with chests, but instead they chose to show us demon's from our party, a lot of people tend to overlook this but it was kind of cool getting to see Ringo standing next to your demons and interacting with them.
 
Also I personally enjoyed the DLC story, it's not connected to the main plot at all aside from just a hint of extra context for the ending, even then it just feels like a filler episode, extra fluff. it doesn't takes anything away from the game not having it, but for those who like the game it's a nice side story that's fully voiced and fun to play through while adding an extra dungeon to explore, and adding some of the hardest fights in the game for those who really want to push the limit.

I just find it strange that this game is literally getting a worse overall rating than Balan Wonderworld. At least this game works well, even if it's flawed. feel free to leave a comment if you agree or disagree or want to bring up something I missed.

the dungeons are copy and paste to the extreme. i think maybe only one dungeon, the last one, didn't have a variant copy reused later. the final dungeon felt like a glimpse into what the game could've been with a better budget since it had unique bosses and the like and didnt just reuse the same dungeon palettes. i get the feeling the game was rushed and some stuff was cut from production at some point. i think we needed a lot more involvement from the game's factions and you only actually feel the weight of their presences at the end. the VERY end.
it's not a LOW budget game--I played Caligula Effect and its sequel, THOSE are low budget, and I love those games--but this is not SMT 5 or Persona 5 budget, or even half of it. It's a polished, modestly budgeted jrpg. If you like SMT games you'll probably enjoy this, provided you're not one of those people who complain about the cyberpunk aesthetic.
it feels like figue is a cut playable character which is a wasted opportunity.
but it's a charming game in its own way. 8/10 for ringo if i can be biased. ringo is the best.

122718528.review:
(This review was made before any updates were released, this is probably outdated.)

(I'm not checking)

(dont read this anyways it sucks)

Nothing great, nothing terrible. Just a mostly bland experience.

The worst issue with this game is that it takes what already works in other SMT games, and changes them for the worst. For example, exploiting weaknesses isn't rewarded by an extra press turn, or being able to act again. Instead, you do slightly more damage at the end of a turn. And instead of having your turn taken away for using something the enemy blocks, there's now no punishment besides the usual things. (Doing no damage, Healing the enemy, Attack being reflected) You're still rewarded for using the right skills in the right situation, but thanks to these changes, you can pretty much just spam the most powerful move you have without very many consequences, making the entire combat system uninteresting.

Combat's not the only thing that's been made worse. Demon negotiation has pretty much been removed. Now you just find demons while exploring, and they'll always join you if you give them a worthless item or two. 

Skill affinities have also been removed. Demons are no longer good with different types of skills from a scale of -8 to 8, there's just skills they can and can't have. This makes fusing a chain of demons to make a specific demon with a specific set of skills extremely frustrating. Not only do you have to find a demon with the skill you want, you now have to find a set of demons that can all inherit that skill, and be fused in a chain of fusions to make a single demon with a single skill that you want. This takes forever, even with a fusion calculator. 

Another thing that has been changed is no longer having demon allies. Instead, you have the same party members that can use the skills of a demon, kind of like the first 3 persona games. This isn't a huge change or anything, but because the demon is nothing more than something you equip, making a new powerful demon doesn't feel nearly as rewarding, knowing all it does is give your party member some slightly different skills than before.

There's a lot of other smaller changes that do nothing but make things worse, but those aren't really worth noting.

Even if you don't compare this to previous games, this still does a lot wrong. Exploring is what you'll be doing for half of the game, and the places you explore are boring both visually, and layout-wise. Dungeons are just barely decorated long hallways and mazes. Even the gimmicks are bland, the later soul matrix levels overuse the hell out of teleporters, and still somehow does nothing interesting with them.

Another thing that I absolutely hate that this does is locking features that do nothing but make the game less frustrating. Ringo is painfully slow, it can take over 30 seconds just to go from one end of a hallway to another. You can get a speed upgrade around 10 hours into the game, but even then, you have to re-apply it every minute, and it cost MP.
 
The DLC is some of the worst I've ever seen, but that's been talked about enough.

It's not all bad though. Outside of the dungeons, the game is very good visually, if a little generic. Even if things like combat and fusion are worse than usual, I still occasionally had fun with it. The story is okay, which is surprising considering how some of the recent games in this series have turned out. 

Besides having all my save data corrupted (Which was an easy fix, just delete everything except your autosave folder.), I didn't have any technical issues with it. The default settings are terrible though, please change them if you haven't, especially the loading screen option which adds 10 seconds of artificial loading.

Overall, I don't recommend this, but I can't say I regret playing it. This game has a lot of good things in it that I didn't mention here, but unfortunately the negatives outweigh the positives. At it's worst, it's boring. At it's best it's just alright.

122607402.review:
It’s alright. There is a part of the game where, once you complete a dungeon that takes place in a subway system, you have to go right back into another full length subway dungeon. This is just bad game design, plain and simple. Revisiting dungeons is fine when these visits are spaced out enough as to not make the player bored, but there was no effort made to space these dungeons out at all. Additionally, the Soul Matrix is bland and uninteresting. It’s just a sea of blue cubes meant to be all hacker themed, which is fine, but the Soul Matrix is meant to be done over the course of the game. Nothing about this dungeon changes at all between floors, or depending on whose Soul Matrix it is. This is only two dungeons I really had a problem with, sure the others weren’t super interesting but they were at least fine. I liked the dungeon where you kept getting into forced encounters that drained your MP, as it forced you to defeat the group of enemies with limited resources. 
In terms of combat, the combat system was fine. It was fun enough, but not as fun as mainline SMT or Persona. The main thing is Sabbath attacks that occur at the end of every player turn if you strike a weakness. Each attack that strikes a weakness adds a stack to this attack, and you can unlock ways to get more stacks depending on the element used or by certain commander skills. There is some satisfaction in getting very high stacks and dealing some massive damage, though the damage never seemed really significant to me, even when using every demon in my stock. Though maybe that’s just me, either way it’s still fun, but that’s all there really is to the combat. Other than that it’s SMT. 
The story was alright, definitely a step up from SMT V. I haven’t finished the story because frankly I got bored once I had to mandatorily revisit the Soul Matrix, so I can’t comment much on it. There are some twists and turns, the characters are enjoyable (except Mimi), and the English voice acting is aight. Again, haven’t finished the story because again, boring dungeon made me bored. 
Grinding in this game isn’t bad at all, as the meal system provides meals that can give you even more EXP from fighting higher level enemies. Meals can increase stats or buff your party in some way, and wear off when you leave whatever dungeon you enter. These meals aren’t hard to get, and you’ll likely end up with more than you need just from your allies giving them to you. The meal system is pretty neat and adds some level of strategization when preparing for a boss. 
There’s a hangout system where, after certain events or sidequests, you unlock a hangout event where you get to talk to one or some characters at the bar. These are kind of neat, but if you don’t care about them you don’t have to do them. 

Overall this game is just alright. Buy it on sale if you’re interested as this game isn’t really worth the $60. I haven’t covered every element of this game, mostly just the things that stood out to me as good or bad. It’s an alright game but it could have been better.

I really wanted to like this game, but I just couldn't in the end.

The premise and start of the game was interesting. I enjoyed Ringo immensely and how she interacted with Milady, Arrow and Saizo. I loved the cute little lines the demons tell you when they're out on recon in the dungeons. All of the dumb filler lines were great. The soundtrack for the last dungeon slaps hard. There were many different types of hee-hos. I really loved Milady. The EN and JP voice acting was amazing. That's all I really have to say that's positive.

Now the negatives is just a long laundry list of stuff that really disappointed me as a longtime SMT fan. For one, the story was just so lacklustre and short. It only felt like the game was long because there was just so much filler. Everything related to the narrative picked up at the last dungeon and I got myself worked up only to find that it was the end. They could've done so much more with some of the characters and their backstories, especially Arrow. Throughout my playthrough of the game, all I could think about the entire time was "wow, Ishikawa Kaito really was typecasted for Arrow" because he was just so bland even with all of those later-game background revelations. The last dungeon could've easily been the midpoint of the game, but it just wasn't and I felt like my hype was for nothing. I hated the Soul Matrix designs and found myself immensely frustrated trying to figure out the 4F/5F of everyone's matrices. I felt that the game was really grindy and annoying, even though I was playing on not Hard Mode. I'm not a huge fan of whatever Persona-esque battle system is used (I'm a press turn stan). 

Overall, the game just felt rushed. I felt like I got half of a game and that they could've done a lot more with it. I'm not sure if it's even worth playing. If you played the original Soul Hackers, I think you'd be disappointed with this.

122526980.review:
This is my favorite Atlus game I think. The combat finds a way to incorporate the idea of having a party of characters fighting together without being as repetitive as Persona thanks to the ability to actually change the demon associated with each party member. It mostly feels like an in-between of SMT and Persona, being both an ensemble narrative cast of protagonists and a game about making nice with demons so they'll help you in a fight. It's the same combat as most every Atlus game, once again being a little simpler than SMT V's additional turn system but more in-depth than Persona's All Out attacks.

Mostly though this is the first Atlus game where I care about the characters and want to see them interact and develop as friends, including the protagonist, who has a distinct character as opposed to the blank slate types that you often see in Atlus rpgs. Oh also they're all adults and there's no weird adult/child romance stuff, so you know, that's a positive.

Anyway I just think it's the best JRPG this company's ever made so it's a bummer that this might be the last one since it doesn't seem to have done well.

122409851.review:
Soul Hackers 2 is a really solid cyberpunk JRPG. Its greatest strength are its characters, all of whom are very likable and have had their own traumas that made them grow into who they are, and they very frequently have an air of moral ambiguity to them, even when you wouldn't initially expect it. The dialogue is hip and modern, and yet, unlike Persona, which is hard not to compare this against, more adult to fit in line with its characters all of which are adults.
Combat is your standard turn-based fair, but instead of the typical bonus turn from older Megaten press turn titles, you get a bonus attack of varying power depending upon how many times you exploit the enemies weaknesses. I appreciate its long winding dungeons; in some ways they're reminiscient of the dungeon crawlers in the series early titles, which could be very mazelike. This game is no different, though admittedly it takes a while for the dungeons to become more complicated and interesting. Eventually you get teleport puzzles and other environmental puzzles, but early on a lot of the maps will be very samey. Once you get past that though it really gets going.
The game is very pretty and its music is pretty solid too. Animations during cutscenes can sometimes be very good, a step up from older Megaten titles.

122406737.review:
It's... an Atlus game. I'd recommend it, but understand what you're getting into.

The most popular genre example I can make is Persona 3 FES, The Answer. In The Answer, which was an expansion to the original Persona 3, the entire "game" was dungeons and minor story sections. That was it. No social links, no slice of life, no sidequests, nothing else. You went from dungeon to dungeon, midboss to midboss. The combat of SMT and its spinoffs has always been strong, but it gets to the point of staleness.

I would compare Soul Hackers 2 to The Answer with slightly more story content.

There are two types of dungeons - story dungeons, which exist as real-world locations, and the Soul Matrix, which is an isolated Tartarus- or Mementos-like series of dungeons that all share the same aesthetic. The dungeons are not procedurally-generated, so once you've cleared an entire map, you're good. However, each type of dungeon only gets one audio track, so you will be hearing the same two tracks for hours on end. And there are also no changes to battle themes apart from what you get in boss and midboss encounters.

You get your full party early on and then don't get any more members for the rest of the story. The five lead characters (four party members plus the navi) are somewhat one-note, but still interesting enough. The party members engage in playful banter during battles that also serve as audio cues in case you're not paying attention to weaknesses or resistances. Because you're dealing with five characters, instead of eight or nine like in Persona, there's a stronger, more consistent sense of comradeship among the team.

The plot takes a lot of time to seriously get going and has the potential to turn people off early on out of boredom. Once it does, late in the game, it's just as exciting as other good Atlus games. However, it relies very heavily on MacGuffins, and changing the rules of said MacGuffins on the fly, which is super-tropey and may also turn people off. There are also instances where no-name characters show up like they're insanely important figures in the story only to never be seen again after one or few appearances.

The combat is the highlight and is very strong... Some of the challenge bosses are like puzzles that will take you several tries to figure out. Hitting an enemy weakness builds a counter which results in a large AOE attack every turn. As you progress through the game and gain party member skills, you can rack up insanely large counters, resulting in a crazy-satisfying attack.

The game is obviously lower-budget compared to something like Persona 5 or SMT 5, but thankfully it is still polished with minimal noticeable bugs or performance issues. I did not purchase the DLCs, and my review of this game does not take any of them into consideration.

Again, I recommend it, though understand that it's a very, very, very combat-focused game going in.

[b]Technical Stuff:[/b]

[list]Game uses an older version of the Unity engine, pre-dating [url=https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/direct3ddxgi/for-best-performance--use-dxgi-flip-model]Flip Model[/url] support. For proper performance you need to either force Fullscreen Exclusive (yuck) through command line switches or just inject Special K and it will automatically convert Borderless Fullscreen to correct Flip Model, handle gamma, etc.[/list]

[list]Game is not compatible with Auto HDR on Windows 11 due to the previously mentioned lack of Flip Model support.[/list]

[list]Special K's own HDR features work beautifully and are where the game starts to shine, provided:

[olist][*]You set 'Bypass sRGB Gamma' in SK's HDR control panel
[*]You enable 8-bit and 11-bit render pass remastering[/olist][/list]


[b]Be Warned:[/b]
[list]Game uses the [b][i]native[/i][/b] Steam Input API and XInput simultaneously and you will get double button presses, drifting analog stick input, input icons changing incorrectly and other wonderful bugs. You should disable Steam Input in the game settings; you should do this as a general rule in all games :)[/list]

[list][list]The only reason I am not giving the game a negative review for its use of Steam Input is because if you disable Steam Input, the game correctly uses platform APIs as a fallback unlike most recent titles using the Steam Input API (*cough* [i]Tales of Arise[/i] *cough*)[/list][/list]

122305945.review:
After plaything almost 2 whole playthroughs and getting all but 5 achievments, I feel like I can finally take the time to review this game

I'll give a summarized version, and an extended version of this review

Summarized: It has good visual presentation and voicework, but falls short in every other category

MAJOR MAJOR SPOILERS BELOW






Extended review:
Oh man where do I start...? I'll start with the positives I guess.
Pros:
-Soul Hackers 2 has some really nice visual designs and presentation, I really liked the aesthetic overall, the whole cybery futuristic dystopia is nice, as well as the character designs themselves, be it the main cast or the extra shop owner characters like Victor or the quest giver Madam Ginko, the designs are top notch
-Demon Fusion is still fun to do, although it feels pretty much unchanged from other games, so nothing too interesting, but at least it still works as intended
-Game doesn't have any massive bugs (that I'm aware of) and runs fairly smoothly
-Music is alright, nothing too spectacular given ATLUS's track record, but passable
-Voice work was really good in this game, in both English and Japanese
-Saizo is kinda based sometimes


Now onto the bad...we're gonna be here for a while

Cons:
-Small nitpick to start, the default game options are godawful, the default camera angle and FOV make exploring dungeons a nightmare but thankfully you can change that. Same goes for loading screen tips artificially inflating load times, they can be disabled thankfully

-Characters are really boring in this game, genuinely some of the most forgettable characters in any game I've played recently except Saizo, and he's just alright at best, the only memorable part about Arrow, Milady, Figue, Ringo, Raven, and so on, are their visual designs, otherwise they have nothing that makes them stand out, Arrow being generic anime good guy, and Milady being the "tough girl who refuses to open up, but has a soft spot for children" as her entire character, Raven ends up being a "morally grey" villain who wants to save these orphans by...destroying the world?!?! It doesn't make sense and is hardly morally grey, it's just bland

-Story is very very VERY generic anime, and very very forgettable, starts with standard megaten "apocalypse" plot, but it tells you everything important within the first 2 hours, like Yatagarasu, Phantom Society, the Covenants, summoning the Great One, yadayada, it shows its hand right away and then barely builds on it at all, the numerous plot twists are all predictable and fail to make me care about what happens next. Like, the whole Soul Hacking thing barely even comes into play throughout the entire game, only like 6 times in the ENTIRE story is Soul Hacking even used, 3 times for your party members, 1 time for Arrow to give the purple covenant, 1 time failed with Figue and Raven, and 1 time to rescue Figue on one of the endings.
All the story exposition happens in one of two locations, the safehouse, or the orphanage, and very rarely in the Axis itself.
The whole story revolves around gathering the covenants to stop the end of the world...that's it. The individual character stories are pretty bland as well or just handled poorly, and speaking of being handled poorly, character stories happen in the Soul Matrix or during the hangout scenes at the bar. The Soul Matrix sucks major ass, and the hangout scenes aren't engaging enough to be memorable, which only further hurts the memorability of the characters. The game has 2 endings, both are similar and neither of them are very interesting, effectively leaving things off virtually unchanged from the start of the game. 

-Gameplay: I'm gonna split this one into two parts, Dungeon Crawling and Combat.

    -Dungeon crawling: Oh man this is by FAR the worst aspect of this game, having to explore and return to the various "dungeons" as they barely qualify as.
This game has multiple boring dungeons, between the shipping areas, the subway lines, the towers, and the Soul Matrix, the only one that felt even slightly different was the final dungeon, and it still sucked hard.
The shipping districts are just small containted areas, nothing special about either of them, West or East shipping districts.

The Subway lines are just that, abandoned subway lines with almost nothing of interest except for this one door puzzle that goes away after you beat it, and there are 2 of these identical subway dungeons for you to mindlessly roam around in.

The Ozaki Hope towers are a smidge more interesting, with the elevator puzzle, but that's about it, otherwise it's the same mindless roaming around, aside from this one segment where you go through the vents as Mimi, the little owl navigator bot, which is extremely slow and still have to deal with enemies while doing so.....it sucks, plain and simple

The Municipal tower is this weirdish dungeon with doors and "teleporters" that transport you either up or down depending on the flow of the water...and that's it.

Soul Matrix, the dungeon you revisit the most because there's 1 for each character except ringo, so you have 3 identical dungeons, that boil down to doors, telporters, and a second version of teleporters....yay....

I just listed eveything unique between all of the dungeons, now here's the flaws they all share.
All of them are enormous, long, spiraling empty halls with nothing to do except fight or run past enemies....which makes exploring them not only very tedious over the course of the roughly 60 hours of main story progression, but very boring as well.
On top of having boring empty halls for every dungeon, enemies spawn every two seconds, forcing you to stop and swat them away, wasting time.
Actually progressing through these dungeons really sucks when you realize that Ringo moves slower than a paralytic grandma who just got shot in the knees, and the only way to speed her up is by using a skill that costs 10 MP to speed you up for like 20ft worth of distance, which you can only unlock by progressing Milady's Soul Matrix....
Also the navigator is insanely annoying, someone invented a mod just to shut the navigator up...that much should be self explanatory.


Combat: BUCKLE UP FUCKOS BECAUSE THIS RANT IS GONNA BE MORE INTERESTING THAN THE BATTLE SYSTEM

-Battling: You and your party members can each equip some gear, augment mistiques, and a demon each
combat is turn based and lacks the fun aspects of other smt games, like the press turn system, or even the baton pass from Persona 5, and 1more function from Persona 3 onwards. Instead you are rewarded with a Sabbath for hitting weaknesses....which is just damage at the end of your turn to all enemies....for doing the normal thing...so the gimmick with combat is a non interactive reward for playing the game normally....lame...and you can only upgrade it through having certain demon skills or stack bonuses applied, but it fundamentally remains the same.
      There's no sabbaths for enemies either, so the enemies are always at a disadvantage to you, which is an oddity for SMT and Persona, as enemies could take advantage of both Press turns, and 1more in those games.
      Light and Dark skills are gone entirely, replaced with Ruin, which is basically just ailment moves that also deal damage...
      Without any sort of interactive gimmick, battles become really boring, especially with the removal of Demon Negotiation putting the final nail in the coffin, it just devolves to hitting the weakness and moving on, no strategy or tactics in any capacity.
With a lack of strats, progression just becomes a boring grind.

I have more I could say, but I can't fit much more into this steam review, so here's my final verdict

Game has good visuals and presentation, everything else is shit, and I can't recommend it, even if you're a longtime fan of the series. 2/10, don't buy it, even on a sale.
