122257514.review:
Overall: I'd rank this about a 4/10. Good characters, reasonable combat, barely adequate soundtrack, bad plot, terrible dungeons, infuriating navigator.

"Uninspired" would be the word I would use to summarize this game. The core concept was fine, but almost everything surrounding that concept ranged from bland to terrible to downright rage-inducing.

I liked the individual characters. Ringo had just the right amount of sass, Saizo was cool without being a complete smarmodon, Milady wanted to set everything on fire, and Arrow had kind of a stick up his butt in a way that gave him a good contrast to the others. (Arrow's voice kind of reminded me of Yosuke from Persona 4, if Yosuke were a lot calmer and a bit older, which I liked.)

Combat was fine. It was a pretty standard variation on the basic SMT/Persona/etc. system. The Sabbaths were an interesting halfway point between SMT V's press turn system and Persona's all-out attacks.

Controls and menus were a little clunky. Ringo moves like she's on ice skates, with a large delay before she starts moving at her full speed and a large delay between no longer pressing forward on the controller and when she actually comes to a stop. It's funny when you run up to a demon or NPC and press the button to talk to them, then watch Ringo slide to a stop ten feet past them while the dialogue is going.

Music was unmemorable. Coming from the entire Persona series before this, I was very disappointed in this.

The dungeons were TERRIBLE. There were two dungeons in dark and visually unappealing shipping yards. Two in dark and visually unappealing subways. A DLC dungeon in a dark indoor treehouse that looked like it could have been built in vanilla Minecraft. Three dungeons where everything was just different shades of blue and the floors floated in blue nothingness. And one dungeon in a tower that was inexplicably half an undersea theme and half pathways made of bones with gestating fetuses in the sky.

Those three blue dungeons were infuriating. Starting on floor 3 of each of them, they became mazes of one-way teleporters between short little bits of platforms. The teleporters largely had no discernible logic to them. One place, as far as I was able to tell from the single guide that exists in the entire Internet for this floor that was all in Japanese, had a set of teleporters that had to be entered in a specific order, with absolutely zero hint or guidance in-game to indicate that.

The undersea dungeon was somehow more rage-inducing, possibly because I'd already spent hours with those stupid teleporters. Again, one-way teleporters, this time with a metric ton of backtracking in between each one. This isn't fun. This isn't interesting. This is just artificially inflating the play time.

And while I'm on about the dungeons...Mimi. Oh my god, Mimi. Imagine Navi from Ocarina of Time, but turned up to 11. For every single enemy, she tells you there's an enemy, she tells you the enemy has spotted you, and she tells you when you've neutralized the enemy. EVERY. SINGLE. TIME. And her lines never vary! And the enemies make sound themselves when they spawn anyway! She never tells you anything you can't see for yourself literally right in front of you! Fortunately there's a mod to shut her up otherwise I would have given up on the game about ten hours in.

The plot is paper-thin. Characters react to things in strange ways. There are multiple instances where one minute they're like "we've gotta hurry and do this thing!" and the next minute they're all "welp, we're tired, time to call it a day". At the start of the game, Ringo says "I can't just Soul Hack whenever I feel like it" and then proceeds to Soul Hack three times in short succession, so, so much for that, I guess?

122212178.review:
I rate this game a 7.5/10. If you expect something of persona or mainline SMT quality, this game is not it.

Overall I enjoyed my time with this game but it has some major flaws keeping it from being a 8/10 for me.

This game is supposed to be a budget title and you can see it ingame, which is why I don't recommend buying this game at 60 dollars if you're not a huge Shin Megami Tensei fans (Go grab P5R instead if you haven't played it).

What I like:
- The characters. Ringo is a great main character with actual personalities
- Progression system is fun with a lot of customization opportunities
- Sabbath and commander skills are neat ideas
- Stress-free combat for casual players like me (but it can be too way easy at times)
- The game respects your time by allowing you to save and quit anywhere
- A few great tracks with huge Nier vibes, as expected from Monaca
- Good story, not great but it's a breath of fresh air from Persona and SMT games
- 40 hours main story, a good length for this game

What I don't like
- The dungeons. Even though I'm used to navigating bad dungeon designs (looking at you Tales of Berseria) it doesn't mean that I give them a pass, especially for a 60 dollars game. By the end of the game I just spam Assassin Steps to rush through dungeons.
- The lack of variety. This one is the biggest flaw for me. In Persona games, the randomly generated dungeons change overtime in terms of soundtrack and overall theme. In Soul Hackers 2, there's only 1 track for Story dungeons, 1 other track for Soul Matrix, 1 track for every single story boss, etc.
- Combat is too easy with every single enemy advantages removed from hitting your weak points
- Demons and some materials require a lot of running around and pray that RNGesus will give you what you actually want
- Skill inheritance isn't explained very clearly. I still don't know how they pick which skills to inherit by the end of the game.
- Shitty DLC practices. Atlus keeps trying to hammer in the worst DLCs possible in their games and I don't support this one bit.

122193840.review:
***SOFT RECOMMENDATION // WAIT FOR A SALE***

Pros:
-Fun combat. While I miss Press Turn & One More from other sub-franchises, Sabbaths are fun. I just wish critical adds weren't locked behind upgrades and were in the system by default. Demon inheritance is a thing, but not every demon can learn every element. It's a shame, because the attribute system in SMTV seemed like the most fun way to balance demon builds. Beyond that, if you like MegaTen combat, you'll like it here too.
-Great characters. With how goofy most of the cast looked, I wasn't expecting much; perhaps that's why was blown away by the quality of the character writing. Each character has a unique perspective and character traits while still feeling reasonable why they'd help Ringo and without feeling one-note.

Cons:
-Ringo moves very slowly through dungeons. There is a speed boost skill you can get early on, but it doesn't last very long and is tedious to repeatedly activate.
-The dungeons are boring and repetitive. There aren't many dungeons in this game, and the ones that are feel very short and bland. There are two in particular that I consistently had to check against quest and demon locations because I could not tell them apart visually. MegaTen games typically have some interesting dungeon puzzles; there are only two of such in this game, and calling them puzzles feels like an overreach. They can be bruteforced very easily, and don't feel satisfying. I'm not asking for Nocturne-level warp dungeons, but a little more content would have gone a long way.
-The story is apparent within the first half-hour of gameplay. The character writing carries the entire game on its back.
-This game only feels loosely connected to Soul Hackers. There are a couple of character references and Soul Hacking happens. That's it.
-The music is serviceable. Disappointing when compared to Persona 5 and SMTV, the latest entries in the other two major Megaten franchises under Atlus' belt.

All in all, if Atlus was attempting to make Devil Summoner the third pillar in their roster, they failed. This game was underfunded, lacking in distinct content, and generally feels like it could have used more time in the oven.

DLC Rating:
-I have no opinion on costumes. It's pricey, but honestly changing the battle theme to the original Soul Hackers one was worth it to me.
-Demons being such expensive DLC-- ON LAUNCH-- is criminal. This game already wasn't given enough budget or time to come out well, and bad launch-day DLC practices only hurt this game even more.
--Lost Numbers is okay. Nana is a fun character, but all other associated content is either very short or insanely repetitive. The only highlight is the [spoiler]Superboss included in this DLC[/spoiler].
--Ring-ho should not have been DLC, much less locked to the DIGITAL DELUXE EDITION.

Recommendation: The game is fun, but not worth the $90 Atlus is asking for what feels like the "full" game. I still recommend buying it, but only with a good discount during a steam sale. Do not touch the DLC unless its discounted, and even then only buy The Lost Numbers.

122170501.review:
Initial impressions: The trailer art style is semi deceiving. Initial impressions set my expectations to something close to Tokyo Mirage Session however the lighting and shading work lends it somewhere closer to a noir comic book like style. If you enjoyed PS2 Megaten games (like I do) the game navigates kinda similar, in a close up 3rd person view. The controls are a bit difficult and throw you off but they aren't intolerable. The combat system is highly controversial, and I can't say for late game, but initial impressions are interesting to say the least.
People are disappointed that Press Turn isn't the system that Atlus went with, and while I also enjoy press turn this was to be expected even before the games release. Devil Summoner games (which this game should fall under) tends to be Atlus's test bed for different combat systems. Devil Summoner 1 and Soul Hacker has its loyalty system, Raidou Kuzunoha has its real-time battle system, and Soul Hacker 2 has the Sabbath system. Its sort of like 5's essence system and 3's magatama system. The player character gains the affinity of the demons they have selected and use demon skills during their turn. The player doesn't summon the demon to the field, rather they use the demons skill directly, and if the skill is especially effective against a foe the demon will stick around till the end of the round. At the end of a combat round the demons engage in a Sabbath and inflict extra damage against the enemy party. The side effect of this system is characters can only summon 1 demon each, a maximum of 4 per party. Its a far cry from the 4+ party characters and I can see it leading to less complex party set ups compared to Soul Hacker 1, but once again this isn't the first time Devil Summoner has limited the active demons in a player party. It's not the worst combat system but I can see why many don't like it compared to the other games. I enjoy it (as of writing this) but it's worth knowing this is the main gameplay for this game. The combat animations are exceptional, all characters have a stylish aura and demeanor (yes even the guy in the hoody, he looks cooler in person than in the trailer).
People often ask why Soul Hacker 2, rather than Devil Summoner: Aion or whatever. Besides Soul Hacking being a main story mechanic it probably has to do with its themes being directly connected to Soul Hacker's. Where Soul Hacker's main themes and setting was all about the exponential growth of technological capability and how the explosion of tech in the 90s was rapidly changing the living standards of all people, Soul Hackers 2 directly follows it up with modern days continued technological growth and yet somehow the stagnation of human living standards. Even if tech is still getting better as the years have gone on we as people haven't been greatly changed. Not in any utopian way that the 90s had envisioned it atleast. Only time will tell if this theme is fully realized but I can at least understand the Soul Hacker 2 monicure.

TLDR/Conclusion;
I'm not saying this is the best game or even one of the best. Its probably not going to break new ground in the SMT fandom in terms of story or gameplay, as many have pointed out in there own Reviews. However I see very little reason as of now to not recommend it to people who enjoy SMT and Atlus games in general. If you set your expectations to that of a decent, if simpler take on Devil Summoner I doubt you will be disappointed. I see very little reason to by the game full priced and with DLC. I only did it because I like to support Atlus's game developers. I honestly have never played a bad Atlus game. Many tedious and some that were kinda boring, but never bad. Play on Hard if you are familiar with Atlus games (its closer to other Atlus games Normal, and remember there is a Very Hard that should be closer to the expected Hard mode).

122119958.review:
There's a lot I can say about this but I'll try to keep it brief:

Soul Hackers 2 is a more simplistic SMT entry in gameplay. It doesn't quite have the depth of games like Persona 5, SMT 5, or Strange Journey, but it has a much more focused story. 

The mainline SMT games are overly edgy alongside trying out new mechanics that generally don't always work (Smirk + Companion in SMT4), making it a good JRPG gameplay experience but not a strong character-driven experience. Side games like Strange Journey have excellent dungeon designs, but the story is often driven by assholes who won't ever compromise, always going to a "the law/chaos ally goes to overwhelming extremes." 

Persona has been the series that often doesn't fall into those pitfalls by focusing on Social Links instead of Law/Chaos, but the gameplay is designed to often be unfocused, with a lot of your limited days going towards raising friendship points to attempt to get to the next breakpoint in a social link, and you often end up only experiencing a portion of the social links, which are the highlight of the character development. You effectively get familiar with the characters you already liked, and don't see the full story of ones you didn't, which can heavily impact your opinion of said characters.

Soul hackers 2 stays focused on its relatively small cast of 5: Ringo, Figue, Arrow, Milady, and Saizo, plus a few characters that are close to that cast, about one or two characters per. They also have a few side characters with a short quest line that does help flesh out the problems with a technology driven world. You get a pretty good development on the group as a team, rather than just dating sim between mc and one other character. That's a big advantage of a focused story.

Now the dungeons do suck. They're pretty barebones, and the game is low budget and that's noticable. The animations aren't super amazing either: Ringo's hair clips on her jacket from very early on and the soul hack dive animation is pretty clearly reused in a super noticable way. The demon roster isn't big and the Macca system is pretty fucked. Comp upgrades are a bit boring where there's much less tradeoffs than in other games (i.e. status weapon with 1 damage), and there's not as much flexiblity with each character as certain ones are locked to doing certain actions better than others. It streamlines it for newer players, but it also limits the depth of gameplay for older players. Sabbaths are boring and you can't have the animation on skip by default for some reason (?). They still haven't figured out that modern turn based combat should have a fast forward button like Bravely Default did, without tying it to auto-attack. They don't tell you what you need to do the True End. These are all valid complaints that don't necessarily need comparisons to just other SMT games. 

The story also isn't the newest thing ever, but I think what a lot of people miss is that it's not about what the story is about, but what route the story takes to get to its plot points. I think you don't need to write a new story every game, just a relatable and meaningful experience on the path of the story. It's about how much you like the characters. After all, if we were rating SMT games by just the plot, most of them would be the same general story in the "big picture."

122113284.review: This is a fun RPG with a nice battle system. I don't think any of the mechanics are as deep as some of the other Atlus games, but that is isn't a bad thing. The game is streamlined but not hand-holding or infantilizing. The story is very character focused but the characters are actually quite charming. It's also nice that each dungeon gives you something to pay attention to story wise-- that keeps the pacing tight.  The combat is generally fairly smooth and while the dungeons themselves are surprisingly plain, these are probably (overall) also the least annoying dungeons in SMT (or offshoot) game in a while. The game does a good job at keeping you focused on the story and advancing while also allowing you to grind if you'd like. It is an easy time if you are looking for a traditional (character) story focused JRPG.

That being said, this game just doesn't feel complete. Not in the way of playability (bugs, glicthes, etc.), but more in a sense where it doesn't really have enough polish.

I've played plenty of the other SMT games, so honestly I just bought this game because I'm waiting for P5R to release on Steam and I had already beaten P4G this year. With comparisons in mind, I really like the difference in combat in this game, the main difference being that attacking weaknesses won't stun enemies, but instead adds up to extra damage at the end of your turn, which itself can be modified in a bunch of different ways. As a result, getting hit is guaranteed, and it forces you to choose between offense and defense more than before. Other than that, its essentially the same, but for me, that was really just what I was looking for anyway. Upgrading weapons is a tad too grind-reliant, as it requires materials on top of the currency. All the options do allow for making more specialized builds with each character, but unfortunately they don't amount to much more than more damage for particular types, just first of the reasons why it doesn't feel like it had gotten the full polish treatment. 

As far as plot and characters go, the game does a fine job. I actually really like the characters, as they really aren't as morally cut and dry as the other games, so seeing them interact with not only each other but with your dialogue options is a pretty fresh feeling. Ringo is genuinely really funny, and even if the other characters are kind of tropey, I thought it was not really distractedly so. The story is just okay, its main problem being far too predictable (and at the time of this review, I'm a little more than halfway through it). It feels more like a plot you would get when your in your second draft; you've got the basic premise, maybe some things to spice it up, but you haven't reached the point where anything truly engaging has been added. 

The absolute BIGGEST problem with the game are the levels (or dungeons, whatever you might call them). Straight up, they are bad. Compared to other SMT games, they are incredibly uninspired, with them being simple mazes at best to infuriatingly gimmicky at its worst. They aren't even interesting on a aesthetic level either (other than the Soul Matrix, which acts as each companions side-quest dungeons). TWO of them are just subway systems with literally nothing going on. This was definitely the biggest problem with the game, and it is actually disruptive at time considering its not only the way to actually progress, but as mentioned before, they want you to actively grind for upgrades, too, so coming back to them is bound to happen. Even worse, for some reason you can't see the missions you accept in the Soul Matrix, so you either have to remember, look up what they were, or get lucky. The levels were CLEARLY not thought out enough, and its kind of baffling at times. 

All in all, its a fine game, but its unfortunately marred by potential not seen through completely. The fact that the main story on average takes somewhere near 30 hours to finish compared to the near 100 the others have says a lot. In a weird yet disappointing way, Soul Hackers 2 feels like the side game to the side game, and while I would love for them to come back to this, they have to put in more effort. Overall, like a 7/10.

121906614.review:
Buy it on sale

Soul Hackers 2 is overall subpar for an SMT entry: plot and worldbuilding details are glazed over without serious consideration or development, dialogue is repetitive and shallow, and the characters feel hollow and unlikable. Serious themes such as death, sexuality, and divinity are handled callously and the cutscenes depicting them are often slow and lifeless. 

The environments are repetitive and boring, npcs and quests feel uninspired, and the dungeons don't feel worth exploring. Characters and demons themselves LOOK good, I just can't understand the gap between their looking straight out of Persona 5 while running around environments that look ripped from SMT 3 Nocturne.

The combat is worthwhile, but the Sabbath system feels gimmicky and the dialogue between characters makes me cringe. I would rather have a team of just demons over these gloomy losers. The leveling feels really off: unless you're stopping to fight every mob, you're going to be super under-leveled while progressing at an organic pace. 

The Soul Matrix is straight-up a bad time. The side-quests feel like content for the sake of content, which I would expect from a lesser JRPG. It's like a checklist to clean out these horrible teammates' souls by witnessing their trauma and having a conversation like "that was messed up but I see why you wanna get the bad guy" over and over. It makes me more claustrophobic than Mementos from P5 or Tartarus from P3, and might stop me from ever finishing this game. 

Lastly, a matter of personal preference: I usually play SMT games in Japanese, but the subtitles are really lacking in this one so I'm playing with the English dub so I understand what my loser teammates are whining about in battle. If you're a Subs > Dubs guy like me, you understand it's a bad time.

Sometimes changing an established formal can be good, other times it's annoying. Soul Hackers 2 is a strange mix of both. For new-new comers to the series, many of the changes may seem weird, but nothing annoying. For anyone else whose coming off the heels of SMTV/any other SMT game, they can put a real damper on your enjoyment.

For starters, you can't recruit demons via talking anymore, only through demon recon and it's random too. This means that 8/10 any time you recruit a demon it's one that you already have. With how rare demon recruit nords are, it's a MASSIVE waste of time. Even more so when you're trying to farm.

Fusion skills have also changed, now skills can only be passed down if the new demon has an affinity for it.  Which, the game does a poor job of telling. 

But the biggest change is the (lack of) press turn, this changes battles on a fundamental level. In other games, you would avoid hitting a demon's resistance because it would mean losing you're extra turns. Now? It doesn't matter! Not only does hitting a demon's resistance not affect turns, it still does a good bit of damage. 

Thankfully, the characters, music, and setting more than make up for all this. This is not a game you buy at full price, this a game you get on sale. 

Oh, and the DLC is terrible, all of it full stop. Don't pay for demons that are main stays of the series and the exp items break the game. The costumes don't even show up in the overworld.

121865590.review:
First off, I'm using the version of the game including all DLCs. Like I usually would have done, I cheesed it and level grinded my party to 99 early on, so I've been able to auto-battle most stuff. This was made easier by the fact that one of the DLCs lets you toggle the dropping of level-boosting items from each encounter, but I would have done the same thing even if it took me longer, so it was really just a timesaver. A friend who's also playing it has taken about the same amount of playtime to reach where I am now while barely using the DLC content, so I imagine it must not be that difficult of a game compared to mainline SMT.

Story, and especially characters, are top-notch. I never want to play a silent SMT protag again after this. In contrast to Persona (except P2:EP), all the main cast are adults and have adult problems and deal with them in a mostly-adult manner. I played with the English dub, which was excellent, although I'm planning to do NG+ with Japenese audio to compare. The graphics are also excellent, in my personal, amateurish evaluation. The music - done by MONACA, the people who did the music for the Nier series and Drakengard 3 - is also great, aside from one or two tracks that I felt were repetitive. The weakest point is probably the mostly-optional side-dungeon design, which is very same-y. The layouts of the dungeons are fixed, and early dungeons are pretty straightforward, but later dungeons have gimmicks. All in all, although I haven't beaten it to 100% completion yet, I like the game a lot and would definitely recommend it!

If you're starting out, however, you'll want to adjust certain options in the config menu from the title screen before you start, since you won't be able to actually access the in-game menu until partway through the tutorial level. Namely:

-Set Ringo to center instead of left screen
-Make the camera distance further from her
-Set Loading Screen Tips to display (button advance), which will remove 90% of load screen time

121852957.review:
as of 20 hours into the game
Story/Character: 5/5
Aesthetic/Graphics: 4/5
Combat/Gameplay: 3.5/5

I personally love this game. It fits nicely into what I was looking for and my experience with the SMT series but I can see the caveats a lot of players have with it. so I think it's best served to just say who I think will enjoy this game. 

Who I think would enjoy this game: Soul Hackers 2 seems to be ATLAS targeting new adult fans of Persona. The story is less shy about treating you like an adult and all of the characters are adults themselves. So I think the person that is going to get the most out of this title are people looking for something a bit more mature than Persona 5 but are relatively new fans of the franchise. 

Explanation of scores:
ATLAS at this point has a reputation for love-able and memorable characters, and Soul Hackers 2 is no exception. The characters all have endearing chemistry and great well written banter that makes it easy to get attached. The most standout example of the characters and writing is our protagonist Ringo who is just as active and well, if not better, written a character as any other in the game, a notable and welcome departure from the silent and self-insert protagonists we see so often in RPGs in general. 

Aesthetics wise Soul Hackers 2 delivers on what it offers. A bright and colorful cyberpunk world with a high quality soundtrack. The set pieces and aesthetics of the game are clean, well constructed, and have a memorable identity and flare. Meanwhile the soundtrack delivers on the style we're used to in the Persona franchise, albeit without the catchy vocal tracks. The only draw back for the looks and aesthetics of this game is the volume of aesthetics. Soul Hackers 2 shows its more limited budget in stretching the assets it has, however those same Assets are not wanting for quality.

Soul Hackers 2 is a distinct flavor of the SMT franchise while also borrowing elements of the persona series specifically with it's social gameplay elements exploring side character stories. As far as SMT games go the combat is familiar and different enough that newcomers to the SMT style of games will find a distinct different flavor of combat vs recent entries such as Persona 5 but veterans of the SMT franchise may feel it doesn't stand out compared to other games from the series.

121804941.review:
TLDR: I would not recommend this for someone getting into the SMT genre because it is a bad representation. If you've played other SMT games and are expecting something similar to those I would also not recommend it (DO MORE RESEARCH). For the truly brave that want something different (perhaps worse imo) then I think you could consider this game it just feels very unfinished to me. I have not played Soul Hackers 1, I played a bit of the remaster and it didn't really interest me so I do not know if it's a good successor to that game.

Just for some background, I've played a bit of SMTIII Nocturne, finished SMTIVA, SMTV, Devil Survivor 1, Devil Survivor 2, the upgraded versions of those games as well, Persona 4 Golden, Persona 5, Persona 5R, Persona 5S and I am near the end of this game and I don't know if I can finish it. I consider myself in between a casual and hardcore for this genre at least the modern version.

For a modern game it feels really bad, more specifically unfinished. I'll try to not go into the specifics of the story, but most of the game play is mapping around the dungeon, fetch quest via talking to demons, and talking to your teammates. I struggled coming up with a third point cause it's mostly the first two. 

The dungeon experience is straight out of Persona 4 or SMT4A but worse because they make you do more with the same movement and those games came out in 2008 and 2016 respectively. The puzzles in Soul Hackers 2 are just infuriating and inconvenient, the maps are plain, and walking around just feels like a chore. The movement and attacks also feel clunky, while it's not important in a game like this I thought I should point it. All this just screams to me that it was rushed because there is practically 0 depth to the dungeons.

Another issue I have with this game is the overworld. It feels so empty. It's pretty much the shops to get items, interact with teammates, demon fusion, quest shop, and restaurants for food. A lot of things are tied to character interactions which honestly they are all pretty bland.

Moving on to the combat... it feels unrewarding. The press turn battle system has evolved into sabbath attacks which replace bonus turns for more damage at the end of your turn, which can be modified with different abilities but most of them suck imo. I feel like this is move is bad because it restricts a player's choice. It only allows you to get more damage down as opposed to healing or buffing yourself again which feels worse to me. It's not like this helps with resource management either because your MP pool is so big plus you can always just leave, heal, and come back.

Another issue for me personally is demon fusion. You are restricted to 6 skill slots with I think 0 amps for specific elements, although these come in the forms of augments for your comp which can be debated on whether this is good or bad. I think this discourages you from swapping demons too often as you only have so many augment slots and they are also linked to farmable materials + money. There are also far fewer elements in this game than say Persona or even SMT which means easier element coverage but also demon variety seems lower. Also money is painful to farm, I have the DLC and it's still rough fusing demons, so I couldn't imagine what it's like for people without.
Side Note: RIP Hassou Tobi you will be missed

As someone else said in their review it's like a mix between a Persona game and SMT except it does both poorly.

121795218.review:
There is a somewhat decent core of a game here, however I feel like the negatives outweigh the positives so I can't really recommend it.

Starting with the battle system, I have to say that it's merely alright. It's the standard "hit weakness, do more damage" fare that you'd see in most other modern MegaTen games, but the press turn system is replaced by the pretty boring Sabbath mechanic that lets you do damage at the end of your turn depending on how many weakness you hit during it. Seems decent on paper, until you realize that it doesn't really do that much, and it's actually pretty useless against boss fights.

The COMP upgrade system is rather unimpressive, and all it does is encourage grinding enemies for the necessary materials to buy your upgrades. The upgrades themselves are also pretty boring, and the most exciting thing you can unlock is Commander Skills which are special abilities you can use every few turns in battle that do useful things for ya, like increase your Sabbath stacks, swap demons etc. Every other upgrade is generic "do more damage" or "you can now equip higher tier upgrades". Overall very underwhelming.

The story is very average and predictable. The characters are very barebones, and the ending is so basic you can see it coming 10 hours into the game. The first Soul Hackers game at least had great characters to carry the story, while this one doesn't even have that. There's really nothing special to write about here, the story is kinda just... there. 

The side quests are on par with the main story, and kinda just exist. In a way they're worse than the main story, because you will often find yourself getting asked to go back to the same dungeon you were asked to go to 5 times already to fetch yet another item from yet another random demon. There's 2 particular dungeons, both of which are almost identical looking subway lines, that you are constantly asked to go back to over and over again because the game just doesn't have anywhere else to send you.

Finally, what I think is the worst part of the game: the dungeon crawling. 80% of the action takes place in what's called the Soul Matrix, which is a set of 3 dungeons of 5 floors each, which are [i]extremely tedious[/i]. It's literally a series of almost untextured corridors floating in a void of nothing where you constantly get spammed by enemies every 2 steps of your way, and your reward for beating each floor is a tiny bit of story dialogue that they could've easily fit anywhere else. I think a good comparison to the Soul Matrix would be the final dungeon of SMT4 Apocalypse, for folks who have played that one. Just a large section of literal nothing that takes needlessly long to complete.

I kinda focused on the bad here, but there [i]are[/i] things to enjoy here. The combat, despite being simple, is still fun. The boss encounters are mostly enjoyable. The fusion system is as fun as ever.
Unfortunately, for every little good thing the game does it does 5 other things poorly, so it's just not worth the time.

Play Soul Hackers 1 instead, as this game has nothing to do with it anyways other than share a title.

121790975.review:
"A modern take on a classic series" 

In this review: I'll try to answer some overall questions and point out some key features/issues In this game that I think people should be aware of. 

As a fellow Megaten Enjoyer, I'll pretty much play any game in the series as I have done for all the previous Devil summoner installments and pretty much other Megaten titles. 

To answer your question right off the bat: No this game does not require you to have any knowledge on the previous titles, although bits and pieces are referenced, this is a completely stand alone title which is a great way to introduce new people to the series. 

Before I get into major components of the game: allow me to say that I give this game a solid 8/10. It has some flaws that just can't be overlooked, but overall it's a solid game. 

Gameplay: This game does not feature the classic press turn system of the previous smt games, nor does it has a row system like the first soul hackers, instead you have a new system called: "stack" which allows you do basically an "all out attack" from persona 5 with the demons in your party. This damage is increased based on the amount of times you exploit a weakness. To be quite honest: this system is not that amazing at lower levels, but becomes a staple of combat when you're mid game. The format of dungeons that are in this game include some  classic smt warp puzzles, your Persona style  exploration, and unique demons on the field which I loved completely. Your DEMONS ACTUALLY HELP YOU EXPLORE! A sick mechanic that I hope they bring back in later installments. 

Story: I'm not going to break down the core synopsis of the story, what I will say is that this game does take things in such an interesting way. Taking all the previously niche and relatively simple concepts of the previous games and fleshing them out is a genius way of telling a new story in an old IP. So all in all, if you played the first game, or you like smt/persona in general, this story really ties together something for everyone to enjoy. The unique thing about this one is your choices do affect the outcome of each person's “soul level”. Which is a mechanic that ties into a place called the “soul matrix”. Think if Mementos from Persona 5 was individualized for your party members. The higher your soul matrix is with said party member, the more you can explore inside the soul matrix of that party member.  

My personal experience: Overall there were a couple things that really just make the experience and 8 rather than a 10 for a reason. You'll notice I have 89 hours on this game, the average playtime is 30-60. I typically like to grind, and I was playing on the hardest setting, this game is basically a cake walk on normal if you know what you're doing. The difficulty spike was fun and challenging at times, but here's where the problem comes in: Demons. Yes the core mech of this game is to summon and fuse demons right? Well there's a lack of a proper demon negation system, meaning if you see a demon in combat, you cannot recruit it like in normal megaten games. This was beyond disappointing to me at first, but the workaround is that your demons can recruit others for you. You just need to find them in the field.

 Let's talk about fusion: Idk if this was just me, but there was a huge lack of proper scaling when it comes to summoning demons at certain levels. For context: I was level 91 when I beat the game. From like 78-81 There are no demons you can fuse, meaning you better have built a proper party comp otherwise you will get clapped. This is a big problem that I think the developers might have oversighted when it came to properly balancing the game out as they have locked some demons behind Paid DLC that would have normally been behind in between some of the levels where there are gaps. I have to talk about this because this might very well make or break your playthroughs as I was at level 65 just stuck on a boss because I just did not have the right dps output with the demons I had currently in my party. Meaning I had to grind of course, but grinding to get semi-mediocre demons with a higher level wouldn't make much of a difference. The overall lack of new series demons is also Disappointing too when you realize the new jack frost Ai-Ho is a paid DLC, like seriously? 

Let's talk about DLC while on that subject: is it worth it? ABSOLUTELY NOT. To play devil advocate: I bought the lost numbers and the costume pack DLC (Because I like to hear the other games' music) The lost number dlc is a standalone story, meaning that it takes place between the game and is not something you're missing out on (Honestly it wasn't that great either of a story). It is also very disappointing and bad game design to include some of the best demons behind a paywall making this game virtually a pay to win situation for people who aren't as well versed in megaten titles trying to beat difficult bosses and such. This again is the problem I had with balancing issues when it came to demons and summoning them. 

Small issue that is totally just my opinion: The lack of music. This is something I live for in megaten games. The composers just always do their things when it comes to new titles, I guess my expectations of this game come from SMTV just having such a banging soundtrack, when I realized it's the same dungeon crawling song for the entire game.. I was really disappointed, yea the boss music is cool, but the lack of ambience that this game has comes from a lack of a proper soundtrack. The first soul hackers had a different ost for each dungeon, I guess I was sorta expecting the same with this game. Although this may not sound like a huge deal for other players, it just dampens the overall feeling of the game. 

If you made it this far, thank you for reading, if your planning on picking up the game after reading this, here are some basic tips I can recommend for you:

Fuse alot of demons, I mean fuse like crazy. 
Have each party member have a utility to perform (like saizo for ex, could be you wind guy)
Upgrade you comp whenever you get a chance
Balance the soul points between in each person (First playthrough and I maxed out the soul matrix)
Use buffs and debuffs 
Always keep at least 6-8 demons in your party at all times (good for stacks)
If you want to grind, get the udon ramen that allows you to encounter risky enemies and gives you a shield 
Phys/Gun Pierce is your best friend

Lastly: There are two possible endings


TLDR: This game is a modern classic that does a good job of telling a compelling story, offers good gameplay, and brings in both modern and classic fans of the series. 

Should you play this game if you're new to the series? Yes, I believe this is a good starting point into the world of SMT. 

Should you play this game if you're a series vet? Absolutely, You'll notice right off the bat that there's tons of references and hints to other games loaded in this one that you'll come to appreciate. 

Thank you for taking the time to read this! 8/10 Solid

Best way I can describe this game is SMT on training wheels. This is the easiest title in the franchise from what I've played. As much as I love the game, please buy this game when it goes on sale. For what it contains, it is not worth full price. A shorter than usual JRPG, with lackluster dungeon design, a rushed story, and some lacking side content.

Is it bad? Not in the slightest! If you can muster through dungeons similar to Persona 3 and Persona 4, then by all means try this game! Soul Hackers 2 is a visually stimulating game with an incredible cast (Great dub by the way), and flashy combat that took inspiration from Nocturne, Persona 5, and SMT5. Even though the story felt a bit rushed, I was still longing to see what would happen after each major event. Albeit, a bit predictable, but engaging nonetheless. Oh, and not to mention that Keiichi Okabe's studio Monaca (Nier, Drakengard, Tekken) worked on the OST, which by the way, is full of bangers!

121755211.review:
Atlus resurrected the cult classic 90s MegaTen game, Soul Hackers, for a sequel which is perhaps the most by-the-numbers, and predictable RPG they've released in fifteen years.

At its core Soul Hackers 2 revolves around traversing some of the most thematically bland and uninspired dungeons, defeating enemies in a so-so variation of Press Turn combat and making your way over to the next round of story dialogue, much of which tends to be filled with unnecessary exposition. Throw in some half-hearted MMO sidequests too - the game has to rely on this as a crutch to make the dull dungeon crawling more palatable. 

The above would be digestible if the narrative was actually interesting, but it isn't. Soul Hackers presented the writers' bold 90s vision for what a connected future might mean for society. While I don't mind the loss of the hard boiled detective atmosphere that permeated its predecessor, Soul Hackers 2 is meant to be set in an era where data-driven AI has become sentient, but it does almost nothing interesting with it, at least in the 13 hours I've played so far. The world itself might as well be set in the present day. 

If you're going to spend your precious time on an RPG, or even an Atlus game, you can do much better than this. There are simply more interesting, more memorable games by the esteemed RPG developer which are worth your time over this uninspired sequel.

121717655.review: The game experience focuses on the characters, story and game play and less on the exploration of game locations and questing; all of which is typical of Atlus games.  The elements the game focuses on it do so well, delivering an engaging experience.  Refreshingly the game is technically sound, which in these days is a seemingly difficult accomplishment to get a quality working game launched.  Our main protagonist is not the typical blank insert, she has personality which is brought to life with a competent script and good voice acting.  This holds true for all of the main cast of characters. I found the combat system akin to Toyko Sessions, but instead of your team landing combo attacks when weakness are hit on your enemy, Soul Hackers 2 uses Sabbaths which initially are stacked by hitting weaknesses (later there are alternative ways to add "stacks" to this feature), which will unleash demons in the stack in an all out attack at the end of the player's attack phase.  All in all a good game experience.

121717084.review:
I love Megaten games and have played nearly everything that's been released since Devil Survivor 1 on the original DS + most of the PS2 games. This review is my first impression after getting through the first 3 story dungeons.

Playing the game on Very Hard for my first playthrough and I'll say I'm enjoying the challenge it offers that restricts you from using items (although it is very trial and error not knowing any of the bosses the first time around) with just enough customization to help you prepare and enough side-content in between if you find yourself struggling/underleveled. Battle system is not press turn, but there's enough customization to compensate and make things a bit more interesting (equipment/comp upgrades/demon fusion/Mistiques that boost parameters of a certain type of move/etc). The characters are interesting and consist of adults that act like adults (elevated by the voice acting, the English VA's did a great job). The banter between the party members and the battles are probably the most enjoyable aspect of the game for me. Music is good overall.

Onto the bad stuff, the dungeon crawling is incredibly bland and sluggish. I don't get why they had to tie many mechanics of dungeon crawling like finding item chests/heal spots/and especially demon negotiation to demon recon (where monsters in your stock just stand in random spots of the map to offer you one of the 3) it makes discovery/finding things a whole lot less interesting. Figue as a navigator seems really unnecessary with how simple encounters in this game work (the monster is 3 feet in front of me I don't need a navigator to tell me what's right in front of me) The Soul Matrix dungeon (of which there are 3 of the same dungeon for each of your party members aside from Ringo) is tedious/boring, it's like Shin Megami Tensei IV Apocalypses final dungeon times 3 with a lot of nothing and is a major missed opportunity. These things alone dampen the experience a pretty good amount and makes it kind of difficult to recommend to everyone kind of player.

Despite being pretty mixed on this game and a little hard on it, I'm still finding enjoyment from the game. The cyberpunk setting and the battle system/characters are what help's this game stand out. I can only recommend it if you're craving something that isn't Persona or Shin Megami Tensei (though borrows things from both games), are looking for a JRPG with an adult cast, and are piqued by the cyberpunk setting/theme while not too peeved by the underwhelming dungeon crawling.

121700053.review:
I just wanna say before really starting that i've never really got a chance to play any of their other games like P5R on PS or SMT and im basically a newcomer to trying out Atlus games.

(EDIT at the bottom of review)

The game is just fine. The characters are fine, I personally enjoyed their stories and their hangouts learning about them. The combat is fine, my problem with the combat is the "Sabbaths" the game does after every, single, time, you end your turn. After about 100+ battles I wish I could just turn it off. Its just annoying after a point, I don't care how flashy they look, they just extend how long my turn goes on for, when I just wanna grind some mobs and be done with it. you can skip them but you cannot actually just disable the cutscene for them because of abilities some demons can get. Having to mash the skip button just to skip the cutscene for it is really driving my gears.

Dungeons, my problem is the soul matrix. It is boring, I don't like exploring it. after doing the second instances of everyones Soul matrix for the first time and finding out there were 5 for each character not including Ringo (15) total with a shitty teleport system they introduce HEAVILY after the second one was so mind numbing. Unless you have a certain skill that you obtain from Milady which makes Ringo run faster while exploring dungeons your going to be looking at the soul matrix alot if you wanna get specific character skills. Other dungeons are fine, something else to look at.

DLC, Please don't buy them unless your a crazed Atlus lover, I won't tell you how to spend your money but please just don't because I already blew mine on it just because I bought the pricier version of the game. 

The booster item pack is bullshit, cheats locked behind a 7$ CAD price tag and it gives you guaranteed level up items for both your demons and your characters along with items that sell for a really good chunk of coin. The plus side of this is you can disable them dropping in the settings. Don't use them unless you wanna ruin the first playthrough of your game being overpowered.

The bonus story pack should have just been apart of the base game, I don't know why it isn't and its locked behind a garbage 13.49$ CAD for how little it adds to the actual game. the content itself is fine. The character it adds is a joy. It also gives you access to a dungeon locked behind the dlc, which consists of a 11F tower that is just a copy and past for all 11F's basically. Just run circles, get to the next stairs, repeat.

The bonus demons, same thing as the booster pack. essentially cheat codes locked behind a shit paywall of 17$ CAD.
Demons with crazy good resistances and stats, along with really good moves. and they allow you to summon them regardless of your level so you could essentially start the game with a lvl 90 Demon if you wanted.

Costumes & BGM pack, I enjoyed the music more then the actual costumes. The game only has one soundtrack for fighting basic fights not including bosses, the extra BGM at least spices up normal monotonous fighting if your grinding. The costumes are just ok. Definitely not worth 17$ CAD tho. Also can only see outfits in combat.

Useful item set is free.  just adds a difficulty that limits your use of items in battle, and some early free stuff.

If you can get past the boring parts of the game its a alright game. the world is great. The dungeons are fine to explore, (other than matrix but to each their own) I recommend at least the base game. The DLC however I do not recommend buying. Ever.

Bonus - Loading screens take a long bit and there is a lot of them. If you go into your settings and look for "Loading screen tips", change it to either "Display (Button advance)" or "Hide" to change your loading screen times from 10-12 seconds to about 1-2 seconds.

Edit - I have long since beat the game and I can say that I just felt meh, I ended up reaching a point where I thought "Can the game just end already?" because I was bored out of my mind. My original review still stands, but I don't like the game, it was fun for the time until I got bored of the dungeons, and the ending made me go "Thats it?", I would recommend trying their other successful games rather than this one. You would probably get more satisfaction playing any one of their other games, I felt like I just wasted my money.

121694061.review:
This is not my ideal SMT game, but it is better than most of the series' historical titles.

The music is great.  

Normally I don't like voiced protagonists in RPGs, because my enjoyment of the game as a whole is marred by what the protagonist says.  I actively want Geralt, Eloi and Tiny Tina to die horribly in a hurricane with sharks,tigers and a nuclear bomb thrown in for good measure.  Ringo is enjoyable -- but I would still prefer silence. But I prefer gameplay over story, so take my opinion for what it's worth.

As SMT titles go, the battle system here is "meh".  Not the best, but not overly tedious.  I miss the press turn system and feel like this system is a downgrade.  But it generally avoids the kinds of problems that could make Nocturne "the opposite of fun", where you have to spend 30 minutes incrementally grinding away at the health of a boss only to find out you lost the race and have to start over.

What is an improvement over many of the titles is that you can swap out any of the main characters' demons both out of battle and during.  That opens up a lot of options for dealing with difficult situations.

Overall, I'd give it a 7.5.

121681647.review:
So this was the game SEGA teased in their last survey earlier this year. 
TLDR: Overall, the game is amazing, a perfect intro to Atlus. a story that is well put together and about mid length compared to most JRPGs. Turn based, and has elements from SMT and Persona. You do not need to play the first game to understand this one. It is a stand alone title. Worthy intro to Atlus games and will set new players up to how Atlus creates their games. Basic enough to understand and then moving into SMT and Persona, getting a much more refined experience from those titles.
------------------------------------
This game is actually really good and a nice side project from Atlus. Newcomers to Atlus games should definitely give this game a try as it is about 1/3 in length compared to their mainline series of Persona and SMT and the mechanics are basic and unrefined in SH2 compared to the other titles. SH2 will take roughly 30-40hrs to complete vs their bigger titles which are upwards to 100hrs+. Vets of Atlus games should not be comparing this title to the bigger ones because it isn't a mainline series for them. Obviously it is going to be much more basic and comparing it to P5 is just being disingenuous and unfair to Atlus. The first ever turn based JRPG I played was (yes) P5 back in 2016 on PS4. It got me into this genre as turn based in not an easy mechanic that many players like due to how it slows down game play, atleast for me. But Atlus does it right somehow. So I know where some of the vet players are coming from when feeling the need to compare this title to it. Then went and played P4G and even FF10, but I haven't played an SMT game yet though.

Starting off, the game runs very well and you can actually play it on release compared to other devs >_>
The story line is fully voiced and is fairly deep, though with sometimes feeling a bit rushed and cliche in JRPG tropes. But doesn't detract from the game all too much. The characters are unique and likeable, and you can build rapport with them to increase their personal story lines and get more background info. The game features various things from other Atlus titles, such as summons/compendium and upgrades/items for your team. The worlds are not the most detailed, but it gives off such a nice cyberpunk vibe and is detailed in an anime aspect. The music...Atlus scores another success in my personal opinion. My favorite, the over world exploration BGM, is calm and relaxing and I can see myself listening to it on a YT 10hr track lol. The dialogue is humour at times and brings a smile, especially that first boss, which had me face palming in both cringe and laughter. The bosses and enemies in early game are super easy. The game practically hand holds you until you get to where you get your 2nd team member. Then teh difficulty pushes you off the bridge and you will find yourself getting more challenged. Not so much in teh trash mob aspect, but teh bosses. They tend to exploit your weakness more by design and also pack a punch as well as can take a hit. I spent an hour trying to brute force my way through [redacted] in Subway Line 14 as I was too stubborn to go back and level up more before getting some nice RNG and beating the boss. After that, I made sure to prepare more. The game will crush you if you are under leveled, even by 1 or 2. So grinding may need to be required at times, which isn't too bad as the game is generous in handing out exp.

Now for some of the negative things I've noticed which are actually not a whole lot, and that proves that devs can for the most part, release a polished game to the public and not play damage control. 
-The game has a weird brief auto walk after you stop moving for Ringo to come to a complete stop. It is annoying at times and should just be taken out of the game.
-There are some minor rough edges on mainly the characters themselves when viewed up close in cutscenes. Nothing too drastic and for the most part, unnoticeable.
-VERY minor stutters when moving around in the over world. lasts about 2-3 seconds. Infrequent enough to not warrant a negative feedback.

Lastly:
The default settings may need to be changed for some players, as they are super clunky and make the game feel much slower. 
Consider changing these settings when you get the chance:
-Chat Speed to Instant (voice lines tend to finish before the text)
-Camera Speed (turning the camera is super slow)
-Camera Distance (Ringo defaults to taking up a good portion of the screen)
-Camera Tracking to OFF (Allows you to actually control the camera more fluidly)
-Using a controller (unfortunately, yes - M&K is perfectly fine, but feels clunky at times)
As well as any other settings to suit your needs.

121660037.review:
Just finished it a few minutes ago.

I loved the cast. Ringo is way more likeable than I initially expected from the trailers. The rest of the main cast is incredibly likeable, too. I've always found myself not fond of some main cast characters in other SMT games, but Soul Hackers 2 made everybody very likeable. Probably helps that the skits through the hangouts and meals give them so much more life.

I think the story is better than most Atlus games, too. Persona got too formulaic with the school life thing and mainline SMT is too extremist morality-based. True Ending for Soul Hackers 2 also felt fulfilling even though the requirements are easy to meet.

Dungeons though... could have used a bit more aesthetic creativity. Especially the Soul Matrix. It could have used some touching up. I'm not a big fan of the dungeon layouts either. I was just spamming skills that make weak enemies disappear and increase movement speed on the map the whole time because of how tediously long some of the dungeons are.

Battle system could have been better by having Press Turns or Once More implemented, but all the same, I enjoy the more simplistic nature of the Sabbath System since Press Turns and Once More can get very grindy by the end. My only real complaint with battles would be for more enemy variety in certain dungeons due to how frequent enemies appear. Also would have been nicer for more variety across Risky Enemies, maybe 3 possible teams of enemies to fight per level batch instead of 1.

I don't see myself replaying on New Game+ soon since I have other games in my backlog, but I know Soul Hackers 2 will be a treat to return to.

121657808.review:
(Have not finished the game yet at time of writing)

Soul Hackers 2 is a decent in-between of Persona 5 and Shin Megami Tensei 5. While the game tries to has social sim aspects similar to Persona 5 they are quite watered down and not as varied. And while the game is more strategic than Person 5 it doesn't quite hit the same customization and tough combat as Shin Megami Tensei 5.

While it doesn't quite hit the sweet spot you might want straddling between the other latest Shin Megami line of games it gets about 80% of the way there. The combat is good, though not as many tough battles as I'd like. The story so far isn't anything amazing, but the characters are all fleshed out enough that they can carry it. The biggest issue is probably that the dungeons are uninspired and traversing them is a bit of a bore. 

If you enjoy the other Shin Megami series games then you'll probably find something to enjoy about this one.

121626295.review:
I played Persona 4 Golden for 50 hours and loved it. I uninstalled Soul Hackers 2 after 5.6 hours. Many people will like this game, others will be disappointed.

I think that $60 is too much for this game. Then add on the FOMO that comes with day 1 DLC. Unless you spend $90, you buy a new game and it immediately feels incomplete. I would pay $30 for this game.

The game is not bad, but it is not good either. 
- I like the bright coloring and the art style is vibrant
- The characters themselves are well-defined and unique
- The character models are attractive and interesting
- The voice acting is emotive which is usually nice, but sometimes overdone
- The cutscenes are informative to the story and interesting
- The default camera movement was jumpy in open-world roaming (which you can customize) and even worse in combat (which I did not see how to customize)
- The major premise of the story is interesting but skips out on details (don't buy this game just because of the "cyberpunk" label)
- Roaming the open-world feels constricted, you can't even roam around your safehouse
- The dungeons are less interesting than those from Persona 4 Golden
- Interactions with other characters in the open-world is shallow

121546445.review:
the famous Atlus-DLC-policy
long story short: it's horrific, one of the worst examples in the industry
offering "skins" for nearly as much as some great/fantastic full on indie games
offering core demons (imagine collectible pokemons) for an horrendous price

same goes for some of their games:
core mechanics are often so similiar that there's little argument about how much dev-time they can cut down on, just looking at how much art, mechanics and often even soundeffects carry over from game to game with little adjustment, but then you are still ment to shill out tripple A price tags for their games

in short corporate Atlus is a menace on the level of Ubisoft and EA, there's no other way to look at it

now that out of the way:
still love many of their games
and i can understand why people love the Persona series, it's just not for me, mainly because of the forced time-calendar nearly always tickin away...i just don't like time-limits in my rpgs, and Persona is pretty much build around time-limits

this is where SMT and also Soul Hackers as a sort of mainline games comes in
it's many of the best mechanics of the franchise just not forced into a calendar frame and focused around the dungeon-crawling, looting and grinding (as much and as often as you like)

mechanicaly there isn't much to be said. all SMT games are very, very good when it comes to combat and progression mechanics, probably some of the best stuff in the jrpg genre

where Soul Hackers 2 stands out for me is a) the characters b) the mature (very) story and dialogue c) the incredible vibe (music, art, overall design)
unlike Persona's coming of age stories (again not trying to hate on Persona..just to old for that s***t) Souls Hackers 2 start of with dead bodies everywhere. like the best games of the franchise the story is pretty dark, touching on betrayal, murder and violence all over the place...and it's great. the same goes for the cast and supporting characters (yes, the usual jrpg cringe exists aswell); starting from your protagonist to your team-mates it's just a joy. a***holes and misfits as much as you can expect from a jrpg. very solid writing, amazing voice-work (and a lot of it).
the icying on top is the scenario: devil summoners, demons, magic and co. hitting cyberpunk supercomputers, guns and neon-lit streets: it's almost Shadowrun material. 

mechanicaly combat is not press-turn, but more like Persona 5, the change comes in how weakness hits now work: you don't get extra turns and stuff, but instead build up "sabbath" stacks (not just through weakness hits, but later on many other means) which get unleashed at the end of your turn and before the start of the enemy turn as a pretty impactfull aoe-attack, which can be further modified later on. sounds strange, but while doing the usual grind i fell in love with it. 
the rest is the usual material: collect demons, fuse em, gear up, exploit all sorts of mechanics, upgrade this and that. 

dungeon runs come in 2 sets. one set is playing out in a cyberspaceish world, the other in the real world. each having their quirks, layouts and a quadrillion busy quest attached. before entering an area you send out your demons, which you can then encounter randomly to offer the usual services: new demon introductions to collect, items or heal-points. 
mixed with the very snappy U.I. the tiny loading times (disable loadingscreen tipps and loading times are pretty much instant, even on an HDD), the flashy optics, your parties very well voiced combat commentary and the amazing neon-synth-wave-techno-cyberpunk-japano-jazz-OST...it's great.

bottom line:
Atlus-corporate is a horrible company
Soul Hackers 2 is an amazingly fun dungeon crawler and a great entry into the franchise
funny how that goes

121536365.review:
Update:  Having played to the end, I will say that it gets *better*, but I wouldn't say it ever truly becomes more than "adequate."  The plot does eventually pick up, and the dungeons get a bit more interesting towards the end...  but it's still a bland and watered-down MegaTen experience which is hurt by having a budget that was clearly too small for the scope of the title.  And it's still very hard to forgive just how interminably boring the first 20-30 hours are.  

Die-hard MegaTen fans will undoubtedly want to play this sooner or later, but if that's not you, go play one of the better games in the franchise instead.

******************************************************

My disappointment is immeasurable and my day is ruined.

I know some of the Atlus fans out there are trying to put a good face on this, but the reality is that this is a mediocre MegaTen game *at best.*  I can even accept that the gameplay has been simplified to the point of being welcoming to newcomers, because I don't blame Atlus for wanting to bring in new players.  What I can't accept is how ungodly crushingly BORING this game has been so far.

I'm 22 hours in, and - I'm not exaggerating - at least half of that time has been spent wandering around an endless, endless set of subway tunnels and utility corridors.  And every time I beat a boss and I think I'm finally done with this section, ANOTHER set of subway tunnels opens up.  It's like Mementos in P5, except so much worse because I don't even have the catbus to speed up exploration.  This is one of the most miserable grinds I've been put through since the PS2 days.  Just the same tunnels repeated over and over and over.

And for funsies, occasionally I'm given a side quest which forces me to go back to other sections of this endless set of tunnels, for even more of the same. 

It's like Atlus outsourced an SMT game to Idea Factory.

Likewise, the plot has been dull as dishwater too.  It's been pretty much nothing except the characters sitting around talking about  the plot.  Apparently there's some big war going on between multiple factions of Demon Summoners, and an apocalypse is on the horizon, but I've been shown almost none of it.  Just endless cutscenes of the crew expositing at each other at the home base.  Nor are the characters particularly interesting either.  Main character Ringo has some sparks of personality, but otherwise, even the supposedly flamboyant outgoing character seems like he's on too much prozac.  

And, of course, the combat being easy and streamlined just adds to the underwhelming.

I really can't recommend it to anyone, not unless it magically gets so much better later on.   If you're already a MegaTen fan, you'll probably play it anyway - but don't get your hopes up.  If you aren't a MegaTen fan, just wait for Persona 5 Royale to hit Steam in a couple months.  It's so much better.  Or play Shin Megami Tensei V on Switch if you'd prefer a *good* dungeon crawl.  

But don't start with this.

121519270.review: Lovable and stylist characters, interesting story. Combat is too easy even on hard and monster x2 your lvl

121518175.review:
I will give this game a thumbs up, as the game is not "bad" and I did have fun, just taking a step back and looking at things objectively.

Really disliked how rushed the story was.  It was dungeon after dungeon without any breaks for proper character developments or subplots (excluding soul matrix and requests).  Character moments, while I did find them really enjoyable and heartwarming, were too short and too few.

As the main story is extremely rushed, there is no time or incentive to fully utilize items such as the augment/arcana mystiques because by the time you grinded enough to get them, you would already be reaching the end. 

Combat is okay.  I preferred the old press turn systems from older SMT games.  Delivers more of a challenge and a reason to fuse properly.  Without enemies being able to gain extra turns from exploiting ally weaknesses, there really is no point in stressing trying to get coverage because you can just heal the next turn.

On a technical level, the game runs smooth on my laptop, but I noticed that Ringo's hair tended to spaz out when she runs.  I've checked with many other users and they also said the same thing.  This isn't a major problem as some players did not have it happen to them.

Dungeon design is really disappointing.  For a "cyberpunk" world, the dungeons revolved around dark, gloomy, old installations.  Dungeons also have the same old puzzles most of you guys know such as, collecting keys to unlock doors, defeating mid-bosses to get items and teleporting through portals. Speaking about cyberpunk theme, despite the main city being designed nicely, you are unable to really explore the city.  When you're in the city, the game becomes a "side scroller" where you just run back and fourth to the store you want to visit, and that's all.  No exploration within the stores or whatever, it just shows up an item screen.


The soul matrix is really a slow burn, it does look good however.  If you aren't a fan of backtracking or running a long distance, you would probably find yourself skipping alot.

DLC review:
-Lost numbers is alright.  It's really just a few more quests.

-DLC demons are alright.  They have unique skills, but you can't pass them on via fusion. 

-Costumes are beautiful, just that you can't wear them outside of battles.  Not even while traversing dungeons.

-Stat boost items are sort of a waste because you can grind for highest stats, but once again if the main story is so short, what's the point?

To end the "review", I would just encourage future players to wait for sale to get this game, because it is not worth the SGD$120 I paid for.  The game has good moments, but the moments are quickly taken away due to how rushed everything is.  There were many promising character developments wasted.  

Mini spoiler:
The man you see in the trailers, only really appears for a few quick battles and that is all.

121512130.review:
I'd somewhat recommend Soul Hackers 2, but with many caveats. I've played every single Persona game and almost every SMT game ever released. I've played games made by Atlus for a long time, and after the resoundingly high note that was SMT V, I had really, really high expectations for Soul Hackers 2. What I got was a very middling JRPG that's stuck between being an SMT game and a Persona game but is good at being neither. This game is a prime example of style over substance. It looks really, really nice. It has one of the best presentation out of any megaten game. However, the gameplay, dungeons, and quality of life aspects just aren't there. 

Pros:
-Great artstyle. Everything just looks very aesthetically pleasing, from the characters to the environments, the demons, the visual effects, etc... The colors really pop and look vibrant no matter what is happening on screen. The character models are not only very sharp and expressive, but they also move really well. From a presentation perspective, I can't fault Soul Hackers 2 at all. It just looks really good.

-Interesting story with solid characters. Midway through the game, the only thing that pushed me forward was the story. It shared some loose connections with the original Devil Summoner and Soul Hackers that I appreciated, and it was nostalgic to see the world of these games again after so long.

-Great atmosphere and setting. The writers really kept the atmosphere of the original Devil Summoner games alive in this game, portraying this gritty, dangerous world full of demons and intrigue. Again, this may be because I've played the original Devil Summoner and Soul Hacker games, but I instantly liked the world of Soul Hackers 2. 

-I like Ringo a lot. 

Cons:
-The gameplay is noticeably worse than the most recent Atlus entires. It's like we've regressed 10 years since Persona 5 and Shin Megami Tensei 5 came out. This game feels like a PS2-era game that was released in 2022. Gone are press turns or anything that makes megaten combat remotely enjoyable post-nocturne. The combat in this game trying to be more like Persona's combat but it's somehow much slower paced, less complex, and less satisfying. It plays like a very generic JRPG combat system, which is already a dealbreaker for me when it comes to JRPGs, but even more so when it's a megaten game. In addition, demon negotiation has been completely gutted. You can no longer even talk to demons in battles. The only way to recruit them now is through an RNG mechanic that occurs when roaming the dungeon, and when you do get to talk to them they ask you for only one thing and will always join you if you give it to them. It's like they only included demon negotiation for the sake of having it, and only put in only the minimum amount of effort to make it functional. It's a very gimped version of a very long-standing megaten mechanic, and I have no idea why they made it this way when even games released 10 years ago had it down pat. 

-The dungeon crawling is really, really tedious. Ringo moves really, really fucking slowly and the dungeons mostly consist of very barebones corridors that you run straight down to get to the next boss or story moment. There are barely any gimmicks or variations in scenery. These are some of the laziest, most tedious """"""dungeons""""" I've seen Atlus put out. Hell, even Megami Tensei I and II on the goddamn NES had some dungeons with more variety than Soul Hackers 2. The game also only has 2 tracks that it reuses for every dungeon in the game. 2 tracks. You remember how each dungeon from any Persona game, or even each dungeon from the first Soul Hackers game had a unique theme? None of that is here. In fact, the dungeon music in this game became so mind-numbing after 20 hours in that I just turned the music off and played my own music. I almost dropped this game a few times because of how unbelievably ass the dungeons were. All my above complaints wouldn't even be so bad if only Ringo had a sprint button that I could use to speed through it all, but they decided to make her jog like my grandma after she just had a stroke. After having played through the sprawling maps of SMT V or the complex, multi-layered dungeons of Persona 5, it's really, really hard to slog through this game's sorry excuses for dungeons.

-The loading screens are atrocious. You get a 5 second loading screen every time you change locations. It may not sound much but keep in mind that this happens every. single. time. you. change. locations. If you need to go shopping at 3 different stores, go grab some quests from the quest lady, then go fuse some demons, then go back to base to rest up, then go back to the dungeon to keep exploring, that's 7 loading screens in the span of 5 minutes. How is this even a thing? SMT V had massive open levels that were like 30 times the size of any one map in Soul Hackers 2, and there were barely any loading screens at all in that game. 

Conclusion: 
I'll give Soul Hackers 2 a 6/10, and I'm being generous. I wanted to like this game. I liked its presentation, its world and story, but if you strip away all those things, it's a very clumsy and mediocre JRPG sitting on the shoulders of giants. It's not even sitting properly up there; it's just half-heartedly dangling one leg off the side like it doesn't fully know what it's doing. My main problem with this game isn't that it's not Persona 6 or SMT 6, but rather, it executes some of the most basic aspects of being an Atlus game quite poorly. I'd only recommend you get it when it's on sale or if you're a big fan of Atlus and their games. Even then, set your expectations somewhere around the middle of the pack. Then you'll enjoy this game much more than I did.

EDIT: After I've finished the game and sat on it for a while, I'll knock the score down to a 5. The story was actually quite good right up until the very end, where it went straight to shit. The final dungeon was also like a final fuck you to the player. The enemies suddenly got a massive level spike, forcing you to go back and grind, and the """""gimmicks""""" that they threw in were, as with any other gimmicks in this game, thrown in for the sake of having gimmicks and padding the dungeon out rather than being a fun or interesting challenge. The DLC mission is also a joke. It's one of the most barebones Atlus DLC I've ever played. SMTIV Apocalypse and SMTV had some of the coolest DLC the franchise has ever seen, so Soul Hackers 2 once again is the lame child in Atlus' family of games.
