121450789.review:
Remember back in the 90's when Square was trying something different with every new Final Fantasy? Set classes in IV with rigid party structure, back to the freeform classes of the Onion Knights in V, magic decoupled from characters first in magicite, then materia in VI and VII? That was, for me, an exciting time. Who knows what Square will do next? (Oh, Junctions. Oh well, IX will do something different!)

This feels like that for Atlus, who have a habit of most of their games, really since the 90's, feeling kinda samey. Shin Megami Tensei will be apocalytpic explorathons (since V nixed dungeons mostly), Persona will be social sim with decent dungeon and a fun, dumbed down version of SMT's press turn. Catherine will be...  weird. Etrian Odyssey will be boring (sorry, guys), Trauma Center will be impossible to play in docked mode, and 13 Sentinels will be... developed by Vanillaware and just distributed by Atlus. (but seriously, play 13 Sentinels, guys)

Since the one-two punch of Persona 3 and SMT Nocturne brought us One-More! and Press Turn, Atlus combat has mostly looked like variations on those. Which is fine. They're great. And every time they deviate from that in ostensibly a game in those series (Strange Journey's Demon Co-Op, TMS's Encores, and now Soul Hackers' Sabbaths), there's an outcry.

So I'm going to be that weirdo who says I like Sabbaths. I don't think they're better than Press Turn (SMTV still has my favorite moment-to-moment combat from an Atlus game), but it's nice to see something different in an interesting way. It's less braindead than Encore and feels more satisfying along the lines of Demon Co-Op, especially as things get more complex later in the game (once you get 10+stack Sabbaths things are typically more interesting). And the way systems are spread out, between Mystiques, weapon upgrades, Soul Matrices, and demons, there's enough fun interlocking stuff to keep things interesting, and I can definitely see new game + being worth doing.

The story is simple, straightforward, almost basic at times, but I haven't yet been absolutely insulted by it. What it mostly allows is for character interactions, which is the real bread-and-butter of the storytelling here, and which keeps me interested in what's happening. Grabbing a drink at the bar, sharing a meal at the safehouse, or digging into their secret, repressed traumatic memories are all opportunities to get to know these cast members and really feel like a part of the group. Even your navigator, Figue, and incidental side characters like Raven have piqued my interest enough that I pay attention to new info about them. Having onging questlines involving the shopkeepers is also a great idea, as it gives these potentially throwaway NPC's some staying power as characters (think the collector manikin from Nocturne). The world has stuff going on. It's a cyberpunk world, so a lot of what goes on really sucks. And it's glorious.

The real let-down for me is dungeon design. If you count the three soul matrices as a single dungeon, since they all share a tileset, and the two subway lines as two different dungeons... which also share a tileset, there hasn't been much variety in dungeon designs. I'm not done yet, but I feel about 2/3 of the way through, and repetitive dungeons have taken up much of that time. Once I'm IN combat, or out of the dungeon, things are great, but wandering the hallways is a drab, repetitive, boring experience made somewhat worse by the semi-random placement of scouting demons (which replace item chests, healing points, and also allow you to recruit demons).

Overall, the game is very fun, and despite its flaws, I definitely recommend it. Unless you're a real diehard fan of the sort of bright cyberpunk that feels like it's trying way too hard to bury its dystopia (but trust me, it's there), it may be worth waiting for a sale, especially given the absolutely predatory practices regarding DLC, but I am glad I preordered the game proper, if nothing else to let Atlus know that yes, some of us are interested in PC releases of their products.

121444892.review:
Played just about every SMT Mainline and spinoff there is, such as DDS, Devil Summoner, including the first Soul Hackers, at least the 3DS port if not the Sega Saturn original. Knowing the first, I was pleasantly suprised. I was hoping they'd bring this sequel more up to speed with the other current titles, and so they did.

The story is surprisingly compelling, though there will be a lot of dungeon crawling pretty soon into the game. More than some people might be used to. If I'd compare this title to any other in the SMT Universe it would actually be Persona Q probably.

In a nutshell, I'm really having fun with this one, even though it is a little on the easy side. I like the traditional press turn system, which has unfortunately been replaced with the sabbath system. In a nutshell, for people familiar with Persona and SMT: Instead of getting extra (half) turns for exploiting weaknesses, the party collects "stacks", one per exploited weakness, later more possibly with some passive skills. If there is at least one stack at turn end, it will trigger sabbath, which is essentially an "All-out" attack, and it gets stronger the more stacks there are. This actually makes the game easier in a way, but it just feels a little less satisfying to me. It's not horrible though, and I think it's quite alright that they experiment with their combat system a little.

For anyone who likes the SMT Franchise and doesn't mind doing a lot of dungeon crawling, they'll probably appreciate the title as I do.

121406265.review:
TLDR: I don't think the game deserve its price tag and day one DLC which is quite minimal content, dungeons are uninteresting after some time, in game currency could've been managed better especially the devil summoning prices which are ridiculously expensive, bosses fight are not as fun because they give you one shot mechanic which pretty much force you to learn 'Sabbath' but then again after fusing demons, you pretty much want to avoid summoning them due to its price making it significantly difficult to have optimal devil lineups

I wish I can stay neutral in my review, I want to recommend this game but there are a lot of flaws that will keep people away, including myself. The gameplay itself was enjoyable at first, I was playing at hard mode for 20 hours or so but then I decided to go back to normal because how they treat some boss fight, especially some optional boss challenges. Some optional boss challenges have mechanics where they will one shot you after X turns, which is extremely frustrating if you face them under levelled. Pretty much every boss, you will need at least 1 heal bots and sometimes they get rid of 1 character on optional bosses, I find it almost impossible to beat boss on first try (unless you are over levelled) which is usually what I've always aim to do when playing Persona.

Another incredibly frustrating things are economy in this game, I've been going through dungeons facing almost every single one enemy that I encountered and I only have barely enough for one or two accessories and upgrades leaving none to summon devils. On top of that, the price for summoning devils are ridiculous reaching up to 300k at level 20-ish, the more you levelled them up, the more severe the price hike gets. You can either choose to get a couple of weapon upgrades or one devil summon, I would always choose to upgrade my weapon because devil always ends up getting fused anyway.

Dungeons are also very uninspiring, it's closer to what we had in Persona 3 and Persona 4 where dungeons are pretty much almost the same and I think we can also compare it to Mementors in Persona 5. I would imagine this as playing Persona 5 without the main dungeon, only going through mementos and the area is significantly larger without much challenges. I liked that they replaced treasure chests with Demon Recons but they essentially are the same thing.

I will update it as I go my playthrough.

121405799.review:
Soul Hackers 2 is probably the most derivative megaten game that I've played. There's not much to set it apart from any other title in the franchise, and while it does do everything somewhat competently, it doesn't do anything particularly outstanding. 

The sabbath mechanic is similar to demon co-op from strange journey, map navigation is similar to Tokyo Mirage Sessions, you control humans with demons attached like in Persona, it has a set of dungeons similar to Mementos in Persona 5 that I literally thought were randomly generated because of how boring and samey their aesthetic was. The most unique thing about Soul Hackers 2 is the story which is fine? I do really like the characters but for whatever reason the overarching narrative just wasn't that gripping to me. At around 40 hours long this game is one of the shorter games in the megaten franchise that I've played.

My three main gripes with the game are the Soul Matrix, the character voice lines and the DLC.

As I said before the Soul Matrix dungeons are literally identical to one another and they are astoundingly boring. There's a billion side missions to do in here so that you keep trudging around the same endless gray platforms for hours. The game's skill unlocks are also partially tied to it. If you want to be more effective in combat and get cool skills, you MUST do this dungeon regularly. 

I can't exaggerate how ludicrous the character voice line play rate is. The navigator will tell you every single time that an enemy has appeared "An enemy!," that they're running at you "Be careful!." and that you're safe after you hit them "Now we can relax." It happens EVERY SINGLE TIME. Once you get into a battle the fun doesn't end, because nearly every action you take or button you press in the battle screen will trigger a voice line. Sometimes multiple characters saying lines on top of each other! For me, using the menu in a quick and efficient way is one of the most satisfying parts of a JRPG, and it really gets on your nerves constantly hearing voice lines play. It was so egregious that I actually just muted voices altogether a couple hours into the game. If you can have fun without voice acting and let the music carry battles and scenes, then I highly reccommend playing this way as well unless you can somehow withstand the barrage of voices telling you what to do.

The last thing I want to touch on is the day 1 dlc for this game. Fuck you Atlus. The dlc issues that plague this company are downright insulting. SMT V had a superboss and iconic demons locked behind dlc, and Soul Hackers 2 has extra story and dungeon content PLUS demons, seemingly picked at random, also locked behind a paywall. If you decide to buy this game, don't buy the DLC. Please don't support this anti-consumer bullshit.

Putting that aside, overall Soul Hackers 2 is a very okay game. It could have literally any other name and still be a good Atlus JRPG, but for some reason they went with the soul hackers branding. If you have played basically every other megaten game then pick this up and you'll probably enjoy it, but the rest of Atlus's catalogue far exceeds Soul Hackers 2.

I have a lot of other issues with this game which I won't go into. I do NOT recommend playing/spending money on this game currently, and recommend waiting for a sale assuming they ever release updates for this game to fix some of the issues.

-first impressions-

First of all I got the $89 version because I know I will pour enough time into it personally to justify the price. I am recommending this as a game on its own and not the major issues surrounding its release trust me I will tell you how stupid it is. Here is the quick version of what I want to say. Maybe I'll add more to this later but I got shit to do and so do you.   

-Soul Hackers 2 is an absolute must play if and only if you are a fan of Megaten games there is subtle and not so subtle fan service to the og Soul hackers and devil summoners 

-If you aren't super involved and interested in the franchise some mechanics will take you a minute to fully grasp (as a Megaten game it is easy, as a normal turn based JRPG it's probably around average to a little above average in terms of difficulty)

-if you have only ever played a persona game please please PLEASE temper your expectations. This is not persona the scope of this game isn't and wasn't ever meant to be on the same level of persona. (hence why its dumb to price it as such from a PR perspective)  

-it’s a 7.5/10

-story is good, combat is great, OST character design and art style is orgasmic

-dungeons don’t have a whole lot of window dressing much in the same vein of a classic Megaten game. The star of the show is what you're doing, not where you are doing it. there isn't a whole lot going on in the dungeons themselves. enemies are frequent and will always be riding you

Now unrelated to the game but the issues surrounding its release.

-ATLUS fumbled the bag with the collectors edition of this release through Shop ATLUS. fact of the matter is a lot of us never got a chance but it honestly is a blessing in disguise 

-Day one DLC for a triple A priced game that isn’t supposed to be on the same scope of one of their major titles such as SMT V or P5R is total bullshit and is on par for ATLUS as many of us should know by now. 

-this game should not be priced at $60 in any universe if you want my opinion on what this should be priced at. $40 for a standard edition $50 maybe $60 if you really have to have the Day one DLC

The day one DLC itself is nothing special. The items are helpful for busting out grinding but should honestly be free. The demons are very nice. Overpriced at $12.99 but nice, the models  for them are wonderful and they are all packaged as one. I would have no complaints (especially because ATLUS tends to package extra demons like this) except for the fact Namissa is locked behind the paywall. Someone who should already be a character we interact with in the story anyways and could've been someone we battle to recruit I.E Demi fiend and Ruido/Dante style, that's when they bust out the OG soul hackers battle music could've been fuckin sick. Speaking of music we have the worst offender. The music and costume pack, $12.99 holy shit batman! The music is enjoyable and the costumes look nice but $12.99? I was born at night, not last night. The lost numbers is supposedly Inconsequential to the story which is probably more of a good thing I mean, you'd be pissed if important plot related details were locked behind a $10 paywall  

Overall the Day one DLC sucks but ATLUS is a business and the winning faction inside the company right now is on the side of “make the most amount of money” and they know they can get away with it 

-edit #1- 

ATLUS has further fumbled the bag even more with breaking the DLC if you happened to get it through a 3rd party key seller in some cases. I don’t have this issue because I bought the $90 version but the issue needs to be addressed and also reflected upon in this section of my review until such a time passes where ATLUS resolves the issue. 

-end of edit #1-

If you are gonna refund and wait for it to get cheaper I wouldn't count on it getting super low %15 off max knowing how reluctant ATLUS is to push it super low.

121389875.review:
There's a reason why all the negative reviews are complaining about Day 1 DLC and Denuvo:

It's because the game is actually really good and these meta-concerns are all there is to complain about. 

Tons of side content, combat is just complicated enough to keep you thinking strategically, Hard mode is actually hard and requires effort.   With the side dungeons, quests, food, collectibles and etc. it almost seems like there's too MUCH distracting from the story at times. Definitely not a lack of things to do. 

The story seems decent so far, though I'm just getting started on that. 

Dungeons are of the simplistic style that Atlus is known for, but they are pretty and not oversized. 

The game runs well on my moderately-good PC. 

Put as simply as possible, if you're a fan of Atlus JRPGs in general, there's no reason you wouldn't like this one in particular.

121386249.review:
I'm not going to lie to you, this review will have some innate bias as I absolutely love MegaTen. Out of the nine hours I've played so far, it's been solid. The combat is like a blend between mainline and Persona, which is just dope and i love it. Though it does favor the player more than having a fair even ground like SMT. The dungeons are the weak part of this game. They are not bad, but if you need a comparison on what some (not all) of the dungeons are like, think Mementos (Vanilla P5) and you got the gist of it. The Story is engaging, and for the first time that I am aware of, you have a protag who is actually voiced and based at the same time. Ringo, the protag, is such a dope character, along with your team mates and its just a well balanced great time of its cast. Like I said though, there is still a bias for me, but I would recommend it in a heartbeat for those that love turn based JRPG's, or just MegaTen in general. 10/10, you won't regret it.

PS, Ringo is best girl.

121383920.review:
I am rewriting my review as I've beaten it and am no longer in my honeymoon period for this game, alongside me just feeling the original was not that good in the first place. A quick and short answer for me is "Buy if it's on sale and you're interested".

In personal opinion the story and characters are very solid and well-built. They don't ever feel like an annoyance nor make me want to roll my eyes, which was something i was terrified was going to happen pre-launch. 
The combat in this game is an altered form of SMT's typical combat: Instead of the staple "Press Turn" fighting, it's instead normal turn-based with the added element of "Sabbaths", which is a large attack based on the accumulated Stacks you got from exploiting weaknesses. The system itself feels very one-sided and unfair, which made this game typically easy even in hard mode. It would be slightly better if the opponents could do the same, at the very least the summoner bosses, but none do that as it's a plot element that Ringo is the only one who can. It can be exploited even more as you delve farther into the Soul Matrix's of each character as you get Stack bonuses too. 
Recruitment is also something different, as there isn't talking options during battles; instead, you recruit them in the field from your other demons finding them. I think this system is ok in all honesty: it's incredibly easy to recruit them in this game, as almost all of them only need a singular item to be completely fine with joining. 
The music was honestly very good throughout the game, however there isn't many tracks in it(which is probably why they have a music dlc in the first place). For the most part you should be expecting to hear the same few songs alot.
Dungeons in this game are very straightforward and sometimes incredibly annoying once you reach the third floors and beyond for Soul Matrix's. Something to note as well is that there's no treasure boxes in this game, you only find items from your demons.
Quests can be very binary in which it's basically either just a slaying mission or a collecting one.
A complaint i can also quickly think of is how animations can look very stiff and unnatural.

Despite a lot of the flaws this game is presented with, i still thoroughly enjoyed it throughout the duration i played. It definitely feels like they needed to at least delay it a bit more to sharpen the edges it has, but it is what it is. The game gave me alot of similar charm to the original SH which made me really happy too. I can recommend this game if it ever gets a sale, but you should probably avoid the DLC as nothing is really needed and it's all very overpriced for what it is.

Not only has ATLUS and SEGA not communicated openly on this issue, but it only continues to get worse and effect more and more people. This is a great game, but DO NOT BUY IT until this problem is confirmed resolved. I'm extremely disappointed in ATLUS for giving this first impression of Soul Hackers to PC players at $60.00.

121379489.review: This game does so many things right that it's a shame that the final product is weighed down by bad decisions and poor performance. Story and characters are interesting, voice-acting is great, art direction is cool, but the gameplay is too thin and a step back from more recent SMT games. Taking away the extra turns from hitting weaknesses and replacing it with the Sabbath system has dumbed down the strategy greatly. It's just hit weaknesses, get free damage at end of turn, repeat. Add to that the limited move list for every demon, little variation in enemy encounters, and it just feels like a mobile game; a far cry from the strategy and careful balancing in the core SMT or Persona games. Beyond that there are the side quests, which are MMO-style fetch or kill affairs. Boring, uninteresting slogs, every single one. Under-cooked is the term that came to mind. Occasionally a dungeon will spawn an elite or treasure enemy, which are basically pointless because the elite enemies are just regular demons that are 5+ levels higher than the party and the treasure monsters were regular demons that you can't fucking hit no matter how much you buff your aim. To top this off there are strange quality of life issues. When moving around town protagonist Ringo will take a few slow-down steps after the player releases the stick like she just sprinted the hundred meters. Navigating to the world map can not be cancelled, a selection must be made, and from there a load screen. And the load times for a game that has smaller maps and poorer graphics than SMT5 on the Switch are longer than they really should be. Overall this is not a horrible game, but a decent one done poorly, something I don't expect from the series or publisher and will probably be my most disappointing game of the year.

121378206.review:
As a fan of SMT, I felt obligated to pick up this game, and it really does have its merits, but I feel like there are so many glaring flaws that I can not, in good faith, recommend this game, at least not at full price. I'll post another review once I've beaten the game, but since I'm a good while in I wanna get my thoughts out.

First off, Atlus' DLC practices are absolutely abysmal. Day 1 DLC is nothing new for them, and it is (mostly) cosmetics, but an entire story expansion behind a paywall right out the gate is just insulting. I bought the Deluxe Edition, and I felt incredibly guilty for doing so, as it felt like validating and supporting these practices. This isn't part of the game itself, but I felt I should mention it.

Unlike many other people, I'm not a big fan of the combat system. I mean, it's fine, it's functional, but it doesn't have the same rhythm that SMT usually has, due to lacking any real form of a Press Turn system (Sabbaths hardly count, they don't actually add turns and it's just "do more damage unga bunga"). It feels more like a standard JRPG, which may be fine to some but I believe it's very lackluster for SMT. I feel like the difficulty options also need work; I've been playing on Very Hard, which doesn't really add anything to the combat, it just locks off an option and calls that difficulty. 

The dungeon crawling is also kind of a drag. All the dungeons (so far) have just been hallways with no real interesting features or gimmicks. There's not even any awful gimmicks to gripe about in any of the dungeons yet (the Karma Temple from DDS1 might've been one of the worst things I've ever had to experience but at least it's memorable!). 

This game's saving grace is its characters. All of the characters have incredibly unique designs that stand out, and they're all incredibly memorable. The story they're used in could use some work, but they're honestly the only reason I have stuck with this game for as long as I have.

TL;DR, this game is a decent JRPG but a bad SMT. It's a decent entry point for newcomers, but I cannot recommend it at full price. Also, fuck Atlus' DLC practices.

121378088.review:

121374540.review:
Gameplay: 4.5 Stars
The game has a 5-8 hours tutorial depending on skill level, however towards the end of it combat and the Soul Matrix/Level system is an amazing upgrade to the Confidant system from persona, Soul Hackers 2 uses the Sabbath system which is an interesting evolution to the Press and One More system of previous games, your team can equip demon's similar to personas in Persona 2 and at the start of the game you earn "Stack" by hitting weakness similar to Press or One More however at the end of your entire turn the Stacks turn into an All-Out Attack called "Sabbath" where you summon demons for each stack earned (Pendulum Summon style from yugioh), as you progress the Soul Matrix and leveling your teams Soul Levels you earn more ways to gain stacks eventually gaining the benefits of the previous Press and One More systems, this makes it so you have to earn the overpowered exploits of the systems prior to top it off on Hard and in mid game, Elite and Boss fights start to use these systems against you as well.

Story: 4 Stars
Taking a classic of AI predicted the end of man and putting a really good twist on it, SH2 takes place about a decade after Soul Hackers and the events caused by Spookies story. Though unrelated to the previous game the world very much is the same world though we don't really address alot of the politica in SH1 that was setup in the World, Basically an Almighty AI calculated the world would end if 2 specific people are killed, your mission is to prevent their deaths and save the world. You end up being too late and have to Soul Hack Arrow to bring him back to life and from their you go on a Steel Ball Run chase to collect the corpse parts.....I mean to collect the Covenants to prevent the Antagonist from collecting all 5 and using them to summon the Great One and end the world.

Graphics: 3.5
Very basic Anime JRPG graphics of the 2020s the game offers very little customization and the antialiasing is kind of poor. (I run a 3060 GeForce RTX, with a Ryzen 7 5800x and 64GB of Ram) while i get a real stable 144+ FPS without needing vsync the lack of additional options makes me feel less in control of how the game looks.

Audio: 4
OST is pretty good, if you got the DLC though the new soundtracks added are alright (kinda sad I can't blast Mass Destruction during battle) also if you get the DLC unless Persona 5 or P5R you get to select the BGM during battle in gameplay settings and don't have to rely on what outfit Ringo has equipped.

DLC: 1
The day 1 DLC that has everyone in a fritz is honestly utterly optional the only major concerning one is the  Number's Chaser which adds a Side Story for you to progress side by side with the main story and due to Atlus' habit of Royal/Gold/FES editions not including DLC you will more than likely have to rebuy this DLC when this gets the Rerelease (if they even rerelease it considering the backlash they are unnecessarily getting.) The biggest reason i'm ranking it so low is you can tell all of it is just content that was not complete at the game going gold deadline and they had this content almost done so they decided to finish it between the Going Gold time and Release time to give us Day 1 DLC. The reason i strongly believe this is 2 series signature Demons/Personas are in the day 1 DLC Satan and Mara, the 2 have been in every base game to my recollection of an SMT title (outside of Digital Devil Saga) to date.



Updated notes: Game is Persona 5 levels of easy and it is surprising a short campaign based on where I'm getting bored, the mystery and conclusion just doesn't feel great. While I enjoy returning to a standard story and gameplay for SMT, this is definitely leaving much to be desired, would recommend getting on discount as a bundle.

121356478.review:
This game starts a bit odd, but it's basically Devil Summoner + Persona, in a very streamlined way.

The only gripe I have is that it does not let you choose the zoom level in dungeons (which starts at maximum zoom by default), but if you change this to max, it's great, even supporting wide screen resolution and superscaling.

I really did not have an issue with the DLC, but the description of the DLC leaves a bit to be desired, to be honest, at least in the main store page. For example, "Ai-ho Demo" is meant to be Ai-ho demon, which is a special demon fusion found in game, that can't be done until you are able to do fusions. The rest of the DLCs are mainly costumes (only visible on battles or after battle scenes, in battle-mode) or overpowered demons you can get for free later on to help you a bit earlier in the game.

Get it if you're a fan of either series but want a different story, and don't mind it being oddly hacker-theme related.

121339174.review:
I adore the Megami Tensei franchise. I love the sweet anime-like wholesomeness of the Persona series and can't get enough of the poetic hopelessness of the mainline SMT titles.
Soul Hackers 2 is the first spin-off title in the franchise for the last decade that is not Persona. I can't emphasize how big that is. Every fan was over the moon when ATLUS announced that a sequel to the long-forgotten Devil Summoner: Soul Hackers is coming out soon.

I truly wanted to love this game. Even if it wasn't up to par with P5 or SMTV, I still wanted it to perform well enough so we could get more spin-offs. However, it saddens me to say that Soul Hackers 2 feels like a game that predates P4 or any modern ATLUS title. The game has so many questionable design choices in the name of streamlining that it's no longer fun. For a game called Soul Hackers, very Little soul can be found in its dungeons and levels. I never went in expecting a meticulously designed game packed with content like P5, but I expected something that would make it stand out. So far, I haven't been able to find it, and I doubt I will ever be.

I cannot recommend Soul Hackers 2.

121335183.review:
I waited for this game for months and I got what I wanted.

There is a lot of things to say about this game, before you even get interested in the story, characters or anything else, you will probably end up seeing people getting mad about Day 1 DLC's.
I can understand some people think of it like a "greedy" way of making people pay for games, but you have to remember ATLUS is probably one of the most honest company.

Yes they make Day 1 DLC's, but it's just bonus content that you DON'T have to pay if you don't want to. Also, compared to a lot of other companies, ATLUS is just beginning to make profit of the SMT franchise, which exists for about 35 years, and the cost of making all these games is not cheaper than before, so if you have to pay 70$ for the full game + bonus content, which is now starting to get translated in a lot of other languages than Japanese and English only before, I don't think it's a bad thing, considering the qualities, and the time you can spend on the title too.

I have played the 3DS version of the first Soul Hackers game, and I loved it, I have played a few other SMT games, SMT 5 being the last one I've played, not my favorite at all, but still cool.
When this game got announced, I haven't played the first one before but it got me interested because I loved the cyeberpunk aesthetic of the game.

I've only played 10hrs at the time I'm writing this review, but ATLUS killed it with this one, the story isn't the most impressive or innovative I've seen but it's really well written, which makes it interesting and makes you want to know more about the characters, the city etc...

Talking about the characters, I really like them, the fact you can get to know them more when doing their Soul Matrix is really cool (btw the camera angle in dungeons being right on Ringo's ass is the best thing lol)

For the gameplay, I like how they managed to reuse Persona 5 mechanics but still changed them a bit to make it unique for SH2, it's smooth, really well animated, nothing else to say.

I'm playing in hard difficulty and I honestly think I'm gonna try to complete the game at 100%
If you want a good SMT game before Persona 5 Royal coming this October 21st, do not hesitate to purchase this game.

121327255.review:
Seems like a pretty solid middle ground between a more "traditional JRPG" approach like persona, and a mainline SMT game. 
The demon's as equipment approach provides more customization and Flexibility than you'd get in a persona game, while keeping a small, focused party of developed characters that an SMT game's mix and match monster party's have to rely on nonplayable story NPCs to have. 
Instead of the extra turn mechanics or knock down into all out attack combos of the other games, elemental weaknesses in this game build up an aoe attack that scales based off of each attack targeting a weakness, instead of an all or nothing approach. The enemies do not get this feature, but can still ambush you, which is a legitimate possibility based off of their spawning patterns.
The dungeon system works pretty well, with your demons popping up around the map for a chat and a quick mid-dungeon recovery or gift, and the sword swing letting you knock down map enemies without starting a fight unless you intentionally run into them afterwards in case you just want to keep moving. This game also has "high risk" enemies (sort of like persona Q's FOEs), that cannot be knocked down, but can still be pushed away if you want to run past them.
The bonuses for leveling a demon enough to learn all of their skills provide a nice little pseudo 'job' system, and I'm curious to see where this system goes later in the game.

Non gameplay things: Pretty art, enjoyable characters, solid music. Animated portraits in dialogue is a nice touch. English voice acting is pretty good, though there's a kind of disconnect in RIngo's voice acting outside and inside of battle. Her battle line's seem higher pitched or something? Maybe I'll get used to it. Anyway I'm hoping for more PC releases of SMT games in the future, and this is a pretty good one so far.

121315741.review:
I've only grasped the first few dungeons, so I'll give my review out so far.

[h1]Story/Plot Progression[/h1]
I have not played the previous Soul Hackers title, only Persona and SMT titles, but from what I've seen so far: [b]the story progression felt a little too quick for my comfort.[/b]

You play as Ringo, an AI agent created to prevent apocalypse, maybe that's why it seemed like the plot feels a little too rushed. Right after the prologue, Ringo would automatically thrown to a dungeon in order to start her mission of saving the world from the apocalypse. The goal is to save a certain someone whom later joined in on her party, Arrow.

Meeting Arrow would give the player the mechanics of the 'Soul Hack'ーWhich is a skill unique to Ringo where she could 'hack' a soul in order to revive them from death. Once Ringo saved Arrow, it was then revealed Arrow had a connection to the other characters that later became the rest of the party members. This would all be done in just [b]less than four hours.[/b]
It is unbelievably fast if compared to Persona series in general.

[h1]Character Dynamics[/h1]
So far, I don't really see the appeal of the character dynamics other than Ringo and Saizo's (And when Ringo picked the Saizo's preferred options)ーThe quirky answers are amusing. But then again, it's mostly because it reminds me a lot of the quirky answers Persona series has.

As for the party's dynamics (as far as this review goes), the current atmosphere feels like they're only characters bound by the same reason of "being revived by Ringo" and currently shares the same goal. But other than that, I have yet to see connection between each of the party members.

Now onto Ringo and the other AI agent called "Figue". Again, for me, their dynamic felt a little too rushed for my comfort. They are both AI that was born on the same moment, with different personalities. In-game, they should only know each other a day or two, but the game made it seemed like Figue had known Ringo for a long time by worrying every each one of Ringo's actions like a doting parent. For me, it seemed incredibly stupid. So it's a bit hard to have attachments as of this time of writing.

[h1]Graphics & Gameplay[/h1]
The graphics are phenomenal, especially the character models and designsーI fell in love the moment I first saw the trailer (esp. knowing Shirow Miwa is the character designer. I have loved sensei's design since 7th Dragon 2020), and it was actually the reason I bought the game in the first place.

The UI is clean and attractive as well. However, my only complaint so far would be the design for each dungeons. It felt so empty if you compared them to the Persona series.

The gameplay felt a little bit too repetitive with no real consequences (I play in Normal difficulty).
With no in-game days mechanics, you can go back and forth between the dungeons and the safehouse with no consequences other than your meal buff effects wore off the moment you leave a dungeon.

[h1]Would I recommend others to buy this game?[/h1]
Again, I have not put in enough hours to give an overall verdict, but putting all my impressions so farーI would say only to get them if the game is on a discounted price (I bought the Digital Deluxe edition and for me it's honestly pricey. I would not say it if the game is otherwise worth the money). Just buy Persona if you want a much more fun ATLUS game experience with that much amount of money.

121313895.review: A good balance between classic Shin Megami Tensei (or basically just old JRPGS) and more modern design choices, the story and characters are surprisingly compelling too.

121311944.review:
If you are coming from a Persona series perspective, here's what I can tell you. The gameplay is closer to P4, but slightly simpler. There is no schedule mechanics, so if anything is similar with P5 Strikers in that aspect. You can and should build relationships with your party which is easy. Overall the game is good.

If you are wondering about negatives, there are few in my opinion. The party doesn't grow beyond a total of 4 members. The dungeon(s) that are dedicated to party members are generic in design (literally all look the same). You acquire the full party pretty quickly at the start since the story depends on having all 4 during the whole time (this may be seen as a negative to some).

In terms of DLC it is mainly cosmetic with 3 exceptions. 1. is a side mission DLC. 2. is a demons pack DLC which is probably the one that annoys people the most. 3. is a boost pack, which doesn't automatically break the game since every boost is actually an item so you have full control over when to use it. It can be useful if you are stuck, but generally the money boost is the one that may make the most difference without actually breaking the game.

Let me say it from the start: The thumbs down is purely because the company decided to separate important parts of the game into day 1 DLC, which includes a side mission with (apparently) quite a bit of context to the story and the ability for enemies to drop certain helpful items and an extra difficulty option (seriously?). The game itself is fairly good. Characters are interesting, each one with a decent personality and backstory you can explore. The combat feels like any Person / Shin Megami Tensei game, just a little bit easier somehow. For those who have not played any of those titles, it is turn based fights that heavily rely on identifying and exploiting your enemies weaknesses, with a big part of the game being mix and matching (or merging) demons to get the upper hand.

121300144.review:
To sum up the review im about to post: I think If you come into this game accepting it for what it is and not comparing it to other Atlus games, It's not a bad game. I'd give it a solid 6.5/10. 
A good majority of the criticisms about this game will probably be centered around it not being enough like Persona or SMT; but as its own stand alone title it's not bad..
some of the issues I have with this game are as follows;
1.Kinda pay to win. - First of all... Day 1 DLC??? I bought DLC with the game and I found out that as a level 15 I could summon a level 90 demon. On a normal occasion when doing fusions, it's impossible to get a demon higher than your level. I understand that you could easily just NOT summon them, but I know a lot of people wont really enjoy the game for what it is because they'll cheese it as much as possible. I also feel like this game will lose some replay value due to this as well. 
2.Fight mechanics- There is not really a system to hold people accountable for any combat whatsoever. You can literally hit most enemies, knock them down and run away. In fights It never seems beneficial to be conservative with your MP because you can always go back to the safehouse as much as you want without the story progressing to rest. 
3.Current state of game- Without making immediate adjustments to the game it feels like an Atlus game I would have played 10 years ago. After making some camera adjustments, It felt a little better, but it just doesnt feel up to par with most of the other current 60$ games to be released. I would 100% buy this game for 40$; but buying it for 60$ doesnt feel quite right. 
4.Graphics??? - 95% of this game is really graphically amazing. I think the stylistic choices made for this game carry it quite a bit. The only issue I have with how the game looks is just that some of the textures look like this game was made for the switch, and not for a new console with improved graphics. 
5.Story- I dont feel like there's a huuuuge amount of development in this game. Its probably better than SMT for sure but not persona if you /had/ to compare it to others. It just feels like you know where every avenue of the story is going :(

ALL OF THIS BEING SAID; No. I dont dislike this game. I think this is worth a buy if it were 40$. It feels like a game made by the B team for sure, but I dont regret my purchase.

121296085.review:
I'm just a few hours into the game but, so far. I get this strong sense of the game being mostly handled by Atlus's B team while the A team works on an unannounced P6. 

This game was built on Unity which, at least seems to offer a little more stability than UE4 did for Shin Megami Tensei V. Still, it leaves a product that feels less crafted and polished than P5 with it's proprietary engine did. 

The textures, effects, lighting shadows, etc. Seem fine enough but they all have an early Ps4 game feel to them rather than a game that just released. No idea how long the development was on this title. 

Ultimately, I am enjoying the game and will probably finish it. However, for anyone with a medium to low income, I'd say wait for a sale because this game doesn't seem to do anything to warrant a triple A price tag.


Edit September 5, 2022:
I have now finished the main game and the little DLC completing *most little side stuff and achievements along the way. 

In my opinion the worst part of this game by a wide margin is the Soul Matrix. If you're at all interested in completing all 5 floors for each character you're very likely to spend more time in the Soul Matrix then the rest of the entire game combined. Considering that it basically looks the same on all 5 floors, with the addition of teleport pads on the higher floors, it is very, very tedious. 

The second worst part of the game is the DLC dungeon "Hachigaya Training Field". This, much like the Soul Matrix but arguably worse since it's most the exact same floor duplicated over an over is extremely tedious. The actual Lost Numbers story and the character Nana is pretty fun and adds to the game but, this dungeon was super lazy. It could have all but 1 of it's floors removed and would pretty much be the same dungeon. 

In a nutshell, those 2 dungeons feel like pitiful attempts to add playtime bulk to a rather thin game that is asking a triple A price. 

The actual characters imo, are somewhat endearing however, 2 of them--I won't spoil much--just grow too quickly and end up acting about as off the rails stupid as I could imagine. The whole game feels like it takes place over the course of just a few weeks and it just doesn't track at all with the character progression for those 2. There needs to be like a whole middle of the game added to this game.

For people complaining about it being compared to Persona or Shin Megami Tensei get real... Even Atlus immediately threw Persona content into this game. Besides that, as far as the genre goes the easiest other games in the genre to compare it to are Atlus's other IPs. While this shouldn't be another Persona or SMT it should be comparable in detail quality or superior even now that Atlus is a much more successful studio than when they were developing P5. 

The Joker costume for Ringo imo, is the way to go, I super dislike her vanilla outfit. Some of the Persona 5 music is being reused here but, that's not a bad thing, frankly the original music for Soul Hackers for me personally is a let down. 

Otherwise, it's a fun if a bit generic JRPG that feels like an early PS4 release despite being a 2022 release. If you've played hundreds or even just dozens of games in the genre you'll see tropes everywhere some bad some fine. I'd say wait for a sell unless you're a big JRPG fan that has money burning a hole in your account and you've already exhausted Steam's list of JRPGs that are better than this game.

121294223.review:
EDIT: I beat it. More on that below. The main paragraph here still applies.

Buy on sale if you really need an SMT hit. It's not bad, but they brought in a lot of persona influence and it feels like some weird middle ground between mainline and persona. Nothing wrong with the core gameplay loop, just a bunch of small things that drag the whole experience down. I wouldn't pick this as someone's first SMT game either.

No way Atlus looks at this, but Fog Breath's description is wrong. It says it lowers all stats, it actually only lowers attack/accuracy.

Good news: looks good, combat is surprisingly interesting (although I'm at level 20 so who knows about later), battle transitions in dungeons are snappy. A lot of Raidou love (PC port where).
Things I would love options for but don't expect: Remove the danger alert owl in the top right, he clashes with the background, is real noisy, and provides little useful information. I can hear when the demons spawn in...
Lower the amount of in battle dialogue, they are giving xenoblade a run for it's money and I've already given up and muted character voices.
Let me walk faster. Please.
Let me just warp into shops and save a load screen. Even on PC, on an SSD, it's ~5-10 seconds to load the area the shop is in, then enter the shop, buy my items and another load screen to leave. God help switch players.
Similarly, let me use safehouse functions from the map field. Spare me the load screen to heal.

Major whine: Main cast is main girl and 3 walking anime tropes. That wouldn't be a problem except a fair amount of this game is running their social links and helping them through their trope issues. So you know how their characters will work out, it's just waiting for the plot to catch up, and until then angst. 

--- I have now beaten this. I'll keep it basically spoiler free.

This was a surprisingly short SMT game. My profile says 55, I'd peg more around 45, I got distracted and idled a fair bit. That is also ignoring the 5 hours I spent wandering around quest locations looking for a doohickey, and the hours I spent half awake in teleporter mazes.
Not sure how I feel about that, it didn't feel like the game got compressed or anything, it's just a shorter game. Except one way teleporter mazes where I can't mark the map, those suck. I hold by my original opinion: buy if you really need an SMT hit. Skip the DLC, even the extra story DLC, I assure you the extra story isn't worth 10 bucks.

Things that fixed themselves: 

You can unlock an ability to run faster. Shame you get it pretty deep in the game, it lasts for maybe a minute, and costs 10 mp. It also requires some very specific ability choices.
The cast's anime character tropes get resolved pretty fast all things considered. Mostly because the game moves fast but still.
You also get an "instantly leave the dungeon" spell. Very good.

Things I am now confused about:

You can get equipable items that buff damage types, IE +50% fire damage. No such items for physical/gun damage... Why?
It has the SMT5 thing where you are constantly low on mana, but the game really wants you to spam spells to activate sabbaths. So lots of safehouse trips to top up...
DLC demons get 1 free compendium summon, so you could just grab Satan from level 1 and steamroll.
The mistique thing is a real cool concept, to make you specialize what spells people are using. In practice to optimize sabbaths you want to zap the enemy with what they are weak against, so everyone is blasting the same spell type. So besides when you're farming the risky spawns for XP, or you die to a boss and are party rejigging, it doesn't see much play.

Things I really grew to dislike:
There is a final alignment choice. I thought it would be determined by which party member has the highest soul link. It's actually SMT5 where they just ask you in the final dungeon which ending you want. It also appears to be 1 of 2 options, although I didn't reload to find out. I'm not even sure why the choices I picked gave me my ending, or why I should care.
I wasn't exactly enthralled with the plot, but I was actually expecting a twist at the end, just because it felt like nothing happened. Nope, that was it.
You can only recruit demons by fighting them, then hoping you have a map event to recruit them. Makes it a PITA to drum up fusion fodder. Certain items and killing them with sabbath damage helps but you still don't get to pick who you want.
Fusing demons is also a pain, because demons have at max 6 skill slots, and are very restrictive as to what skills they will take. Not only are you trying to optimize the end result, you're also optimizing the intermediate demons so you can actually pass on skills you want.
The mind dungeon/Tartarus is... real dull. All the objectives in there, also real dull. Long, same looking, and teleport mazes.
A real lack of scenery variety. You go to the docks twice, the sewers twice, and the office building twice. Only the last dungeon looks even remotely interesting.
Big whine: some sidequests are basically: go to location X, find dude Y, do something. They don't mark where dude Y is on your map. Those 5 hours looking around dungeons to find dudes? I am not kidding. My advice, is look in the box rooms near teleporters, or when available use a guide.

121292922.review:
Disappointment, as a Megami Tensei fan since 2018, I had low expectations and somehow they still made me disappointed (most likely after beating Devil Summoner 1). Hard Mode is "difficult" not because of my strategy was wrong, but because my Level was too Low, absolutely annoying to deal with a boss that one shots you just for the sake of it.

Compared to Soul Hackers 1 or even dare say Devil Summoner 1 (Sega Saturn), I can be underleveled but I can still defeat a boss with the right strategy, ex. a lvl 43 beating a lvl 60 boss, yes you heard that correct, a LVL 43 CAN DEFEAT A LVL 60 BOSS with the right strategy, doesn't exist in this game or any other JRPG that's not Megami Tensei. Mind you Devil Summoner 1 and Soul Hackers were never hard to begin with (Nemissa and Rei Reiho are OP AF), except for like three bosses in both games respectively (Orogone Ghost, Mayone and Inaruna). What I think is the most disappointing aspect is them removing negotiations to just talking to a demon, they ask for money or items and then bam you got a new demon, I tried to push through to see if they will introduce that into the game later on, but WHY TF do I have to wait for a staple of Megami Tensei since 1987 to be in the game, It should be there in the beginning. Never mind the scummy dlc demons or the battle items, but basically dumbing down negotiations just make me say, "This ain't it Chief". I did praise the buff system until I realize it is just like SMT V, it only lasts for three turns, smh. Just make everything a damage sponge, that seems to be the philosophy at ATLUS now instead of what made their series unique in the first place. I have no idea why the Loyalty System was removed, why not just make it like Raidou 2 where you level the loyalty up by grinding. The loyalty system was a hit or miss (Devil Summoner 1 is a prime example) but it was a chance for people that dislike it from SH1 to enjoy it.

The story isn't what makes me interested in Soul Hackers 2 or in Megami Tensei in the first place (SHOCKING! But it's true), it's a hot take but honestly the only games in the franchise that had stories that stood out to me were SMT II, SMT IV, Strange Journey, Persona 2 Eternal Punishment, Digital Devil Saga duology, and Raidou 2 (and maybe Majin Tensei 2, DeSU1 and Devil Summoner) compared to the rest of the series. So nothing more needs to be said about it.

The music is very underwhelming, One track to me felt really good to listen to and that was around the beginning of the game. Compared to both Devil Summoner games, those had amazing osts that oozed with style and atmosphere, thanks to Toshiko Tasaki and Tsukasa Masuko bringing it to life, now I don't have anything against okabe, but he doesn't scream Devil Summoner like Tasaki and Masuko does. Couldn't they just get Toshiko to supervise, it's one of the reasons why Soul Hackers ost is the way it is. 

For me I would not recommend it full price but wait for it on sale maybe, but take my opinion with a grain of salt and formulate your own opinion, because you never you might actually enjoy the game.

121290811.review:
Very promising for future PC titles from Atlus. Game runs like a charm, after Persona 4 Golden's release to PC and Soul Hackers 2 being released day 1 on PC as well, I'm confident that Atlus intends to keep this quality for games to come. Performance aside, I'm a big fan of Ringo as a character, I'm going into this game as someone who's experienced both Persona and SMT:V and to be fair, this is closer to Persona, but not quite Persona either. There's similarities but there's no date system so I don't feel as if I'm in a rush or got to be careful with who I spend my time with. Soul Link is similar to Confidants/Friendship from Persona, however its score based. Not a bad thing but it feels a little underwhelming so far probably because the characters haven't opened up yet.

Gameplay is fun and I know I'm going to get more crazy abilities later, decent PC controls, OST is pretty decent for its theme. I need to play more of the game to really make a decent opinion on this bit.

Dialogue boxes however are slow by default, and its annoying. It should be faster than that for "normal" speed in the options. Not a fan of Day 1 DLC.

121284431.review:
Lower budget Atlus title made by a team of great devs. There is a lot of really small details that are expertly made/decided in this game that make the experience super smooth. This includes super reactive and clean menus, one of the best UIs in turn based RPG ever (just the commander skill cooldowns should have been displayed at all time imho), great battle theme, really fun cinematography in combat.

The themes and atmosphere feel genuinely adult which is rare for JRPGs even Atlus games (despite SMT dealing with apocalypse characters are often very young especially in recent iterations aside from Flynn in SMTIV). The cast of characters is interesting, the story is engaging so far.

Is it the best videogame in human history ? Nope, but it really doesn't need to be.

If you enjoy turn base RPGs with a good amount of challenge that is actually fair then go for it. (I particularly like how tough the risky monsters are in this game and they feel a lot less BS than in Tokyo Mirage where they were insanely overleveled compared to you and unbeatable at level, here it's feasible if you have a really flawless strategy, for the most part).

I love all of the characters and new combat mechanics too. Dungeons reminds me of SMT3 and Pearsona 3/4 with elements of SMTV. 121263823.review:
7 Hours of gameplay opinions and tips:

     - Very approachable for newcomers, a good entry for veterans but may feel a little oversimplified at times if you're used to the difficulty curve for SMT/Persona/DS games
     - English voiceover is okay, but Japanese audio will make the game feel less awkward
     - Agreed. Day 1 DLC is a pain, bought the extra story DLC and so far it has made very little impact on gameplay. Would love to see Atlus/Sega atone for this sin ;)
     - Default settings for the game are terrible, fix your camera, text speed, etc ASAP when you start the game
     - Music is solid
     - Demon merging system is nice and simple with the new "search fusion" filters
     - Character upgrade elements are an interesting take on the "Glory" mechanic that SMT 5 intoduced to the franchise
     - Dungeons haven't been anything special but they haven't been a pain either
     - Story is actually pretty good. Cutscenes and dialogue are a lot more lengthy and slightly less interesting than SMT 5 in my opinion, but if you're the kind of person who likes long storylines you'll like this one.
     - So far I think a $40-$50 price tag would have made more sense for this game on release day since it does feel a bit watered down for a SMT/Persona/DS game but honestly you can justify buying it for $60 if you're pretty diehard on the franchise and want to play it ASAP and want a solid PC option until P5R gets ported.

Overall I do recommend playing this game but perhaps waiting for a sale or solid free DLC drop if you've been on the fence about buying it. It doesn't quite justify the price tag just yet.

121259779.review:
If I had to recommend a good starting point into the SMT franchise, it would be this. 
I know, I know. Let noobies start on the Persona games or dare I even say to drop them straight into the pits of the hell pool that is Nocturne.
But genuinely, I recommend this to those who are interested in getting into the SMT series.

- There are no "press turns" [b](press turns are basically adding an extra turn onto one or more of your demons by exploiting the weaknesses of your enemies, or landing critical hits. You lose turns by hitting the wrong weakness i.e using ice moves on an ice enemy, and missing the target all-together)[/b]. [i]With the absence of press turns, there isn't as much stress about worrying if the enemy can abuse the gimmick and rinse your whole team[/i]

- The gameplay in this is very streamlined and user friendly. [b](info on sidemission progress is readily available at anytime, you can save at anytime)[/b]

I guess that's all I can think of right now that would make this my personal recommendation to starting the SMT franchise. All-in-all, the game itself isn't what I would call "SMT Quality", but it is at heart just a spin-off. A well made sequel to a spin-off.

121257714.review:
So, gonna say this right off the bat here.

THIS IS NOT PERSONA 5. IF YOU WANT PERSONA 5, GO PLAY PERSONA 5. THIS AIN'T THAT.

Okay? Okay.

What this game IS however is a follow up to the Nintendo DS game from 2013, Shin Megami Tensei Devil Summoner: Soul Hackers. They shortened the name for obvious reasons.

Personally I'm having a lot of fun with it. I find the cast entertaining, the aesthetic and imagery appealing, and the music and gameplay solid enough. Honestly, its a solid SMT game. A darker JRPG series thats been ongoing since the NES era. Its not doing anything amazingly new, but it does do what it does very well. If you've played most other SMT games, you've played this one, but just because I've eaten a lot of pizza in the past doesn't mean I'll turn up my nose at a nice hot pizza today.

If you're a fan of Atlus games, Shin Megami Tensei, or just JRPGs in general. Here's a lovely one for you to take for a spin. If you're not sure, wait until it goes on sale.

I'll be honest with you chief, save your money. 
This game feels extremely low budget, like 10% of SMT V or any Persona budget. But it costs 60 bucks? Nice.
From my 5 hours in I have only seen garbage trying so hard to disguise itself as a good game.

The most important part of an SMT game - combat, is so mind numbingly simple it's nuts. The enemy obtains no advantage for targeting your weakness, so you don't need to think about your demon composition at all.
Story is slow and idiotic, you would never believe these people are functioning adults while the MC Ringo talks like a Marvel character.
Dungeons are on the level of Persona 3 Tartarus if not worse. No memorable setup, music or encounters. "Guess he's just there, lets go" and you literally run in a linear hallway with 3 loading screens. It's pathetic.

Look, if you like this sort of thing - whatever floats your boat. But to me, I literally threw money to the wind as seeing how indie titles are priced for 10 bucks and have so much love and effort put into them. And I freaking LOVE SMT V, P3, 4, 5.

If you still can't hold it in for more Atlus goodness, just wait for a steep sale cuz this ain't it.

133922118.review:
8/10 - The SMT (Shin Megami Tensei) series may not be for everyone, but as a fan of turn-based JRPGs, I thoroughly enjoyed this game. If you're also a fan of the genre, it's definitely worth purchasing, especially when it's on sale. The game boasts a solid story, which seems like it draws inspiration from The Ghost in the Shell series. The characters each have their own personal traumas, which can be explored through the Axis, similar to Persona 5's Momentos level design. The game's artwork and sound are both exceptional, and the battle system, while different from previous SMT games, is still enjoyable, particularly with the addition of Sabbath actions that allow for customization and special actions that can be taken per turn that require some planning to make the most of out in boss battles. The character customization is a highlight, with the combination of augments and demons allowing for individual strengths to be maximized, individual characters affinity to be increased, and accessories and meals to buff the team.

However, the level design is lackluster, with poorly thought-out mazes that feel tedious to navigate. Boss battles are particularly punishing (as expected, I played the game on hard), requiring grinding that can disrupt the pacing of the story, although this is typical of SMT games. Overall, the game offers a challenging and enjoyable experience, with its art, story, characters, battle system, and customization all impressing. While the level design may not be the best, it's a great follow-up to the original game and references it in subtle ways, but falls short in similar ways the original did.
